PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the growing `Burkegate' saga and ask: is it considered appropriate for an ambassador to be interviewed by all television channels, do four major radio interviews-including trendsetting radio on `Ask the Ambassador', advertised in the West Australian that day-and press interviews in an attempt to get himself off a political hook? What instructions has the Minister given Mr Burke in this regard, after originally having instructed him not to make comment?

—These are matters for the good judgment of the individual concerned. There is something of a convention that ambassadors do not comment on political or related matters. Before any of this current excitement culminated in proceedings before a royal commission, there were no court or similar proceedings pending which made it appropriate or legitimate for that normal convention to be modified. However, in the environment in which Mr Burke presently finds himself, being confronted by hordes of media questioners and others less well motivated from the other side of this Parliament and their fellow travellers, it is perfectly understandable that he should wish to put his own view of some of these matters on the public record. I have not sought to second guess his judgment in that respect.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question to ask the Minister. Do I understand from the Minister's answer that he is saying that it is quite all right for ambassadors to make political comment repeatedly over the duration of a week on any subject they may wish to choose?

—That is stretching a rather long bow on what I have just said. In the particular circumstances where an ambassador finds himself having the status of a witness or the subject of some inquiry before a royal commission, and in an environment where there is a fever of politically generated frenzy, about which the other side has been entirely shameless in this respect, and in an environment in which intense media interest has been generated by that political shark feeding frenzy that we have witnessed on the other side, it is understandable that the individual concerned should want to respond. In the circumstances I have described, where proceedings of this kind are pending and it is not a normal ambassadorial situation where one is being drawn into political comment generally, I repeat: I do not think it is appropriate for me to be second guessing the judgment of the individual concerned.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister noted claims made by some Opposition senators that price inflation is currently at the rate of 10.8 per cent or 10.4 per cent? Could such figures have been obtained only by multiplying the latest quarterly consumer price index (CPI) figure by four? If so, is this a legitimate approach to the measurement of price rises in the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, my attention has been drawn to the comments which have been made about an inflation rate of 10.8 per cent. That sort of mathematics is impeccable, but is also misleading, misguided and perhaps intended to misguide. Maybe they are deliberate attempts to mislead.

ANSWER.PARA: For the benefit of those honourable senators concerned, I want to say something about the CPI. Simply multiplying one quarter's CPI does not give any indication of the trend in inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is running away at the moment.
—If that were so, people such as Senator Walters could have multiplied the previous quarter's CPI result of 0.7 by four and worked out--
—She could not have done that.

—Perhaps it was a charitable suggestion. She could have done that and worked out that we had an annual inflation rate of 2.8 per cent. That would be a rather dishonest exercise and one on which, I must say, the Government has never embarked.

ANSWER.PARA: The CPI figure of 2.7 per cent for the December quarter brings the annual rate to 6.9 per cent, up from 6 per cent in the 12 months to September. I think it is conceded by all fair minded commentators including, I believe, the Leader of the Opposition, that that is largely due to the effects of increased oil prices and some basically State administered charges.

The important measure to focus on is the underlying rate which excludes items subject to administrative price changes, seasonal influences and interest charges. This rate has been on a downward trend from about 6.8 per cent in March 1989 to 5.4 per cent in the 12 months to December 1990. This is down from 5.6 per cent in September 1990. This provides Australia with a rare opportunity to continue to step down inflation. I might say that that is an opportunity which has eluded Australia and Australian governments for two decades. Under this Government inflation has averaged 7 1/2 per cent compared with 10.3 per cent over the Fraser years. So that is just one useful measure of comparison.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long ago was that?

—I know it is difficult for Senator Boswell to concentrate on a long answer such as this, but if he did he might understand better. I could take a previous decade too, but as Senator Boswell has difficulty in remembering the Fraser years-something which he has no doubt blotted out of his mind as he has difficulty in remembering that-it is no good making comparisons with previous decades or earlier decades.

ANSWER.PARA: The point I want to make is that we have a good chance to secure a sustainable fall in inflation. This would be a remarkable achievement for Australia because we are one of the few countries where currently inflation is falling. The latest figures available--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp should stop chattering. The latest figures available for the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris reveal that in the 12 months to the December quarter total OECD inflation was 7.4 per cent-Senator Kemp will remember that a minute ago I said it was 6.8 per cent in Australia-an increase from 6 per cent in the 12 months to the September quarter.
—That is very good!

—We have the approval of Senator Alston. That is a great start. This compares with 6.9 per cent for the December quarter 1990. Over the same period the inflation rate in the United States was at 6.2 per cent, and the United Kingdom had an inflation rate of 9.9 per cent. Australia's inflation rate for the year ending in the December quarter was below that of the OECD and well below that of the United Kingdom. Australia in 1991 is therefore in a position to make our inflation rate competitive with that of the rest of the world.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and again relates to the Burkegate cover-up. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether he was aware that his Ambassador to Ireland, Brian Burke, was due to return to Australia on the weekend of 23 and 24 February, when on 21 February the Minister informed the Senate during Question Time that he had no advice about when Mr Burke would be required to return to Australia?
—I was not aware that his return was imminent, no.
—I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister inform the Senate whether he had discussed with the Minister for Social Security the imminent return of Brian Burke?
—First, it is none of the honourable senator's business, but secondly, no. Thirdly, I have 90 posts around the world and I do not keep track of the movements of ambassadors in this situation.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware that the receivers appointed to act on behalf of the John Fairfax Group Pty Ltd are legally challenging the validity of the long term contracts with ANM Boyer and Albury Mills for the supply of newsprint? If their actions are successful, does the Minister agree that the resultant loss of 25 to 30 per cent of production from those two mills will threaten their viability and cause further loss of jobs? Does the Minister agree that this type of action by major consumers in Australia, apparently for short term gain, will create great difficulties, particularly in Tasmania, for the development of downstream processing of our natural resources?

—I am aware that the Fairfax Group has long term contracts with Australian Newsprint Mills for the supply of newspaper. I am not aware of any legal challenge being mounted to the validity of these contracts by the receiver of the group. If such a challenge is to take place, it would be appropriate to place this question on notice until such time as the results of the challenge are known. Might I also remind Senator Devereux that there are other impediments to resource processing in Tasmania besides the recent actions of the Fairfax Group.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of the report of the Tasmanian Department of Parks, Wildlife and Heritage dated June 1990 and entitled Appropriate World Heritage Boundaries for a World Heritage area in Western Tasmania? Is the Minister also aware that this report, the most authoritative undertaken, has recommended that an extra 300,000 hectares of Tasmania's wilderness be added to the World Heritage list? Given that approximately 100,000 hectares would be placed in permanent logging zones covered by any Federal and State resource security legislation under any Tasmanian Government proposed forest industry strategy, can the Minister give a categorical assurance that areas identified as having World Heritage qualities or potential World Heritage qualities will not be placed in areas covered by any Federal resource security legislation? How does the Government propose to meet its obligations under the World Heritage convention to identify and protect areas of World Heritage significance identified in this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —No country in the world has gone further in meeting its obligations under that convention than has Australia. We have more places nominated. Fortunately, of course, we are blessed with places of spectacular natural beauty to nominate. We have done our fair share, and more, and I do not think that any Australian could be anything but proud of that fact. Whether or not we want to do any more is a matter for consideration of the Minister. There are a number of other possibilities for nomination which can be examined.

ANSWER.PARA: But in so far as the report to which Senator Powell refers concerns areas to be examined in Tasmania, all I can say is that I first heard of the report on Friday. Therefore, I have not read it; I am not certain whether the Minister has read it. As I understand it, it was published very recently, although I do not pretend to know on exactly what day. So what possible link there might be between the Commonwealth and the States, if they were to agree to resource security legislation with permanent logging zones in areas that this report has suggested might finish up in World Heritage areas, I really do not know. It is too far in the area of speculation. In any event, with the Government about to come to grips with this matter, I do not think it is appropriate that I pre-empt a Cabinet discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to seek further clarification from the Minister whom he represents in this chamber. In doing so, I ask the Minister, too, why the report has not surfaced for this long period-over six months. Was that suppressed and, if so, why and by whom? When is the Government intending to create an indicative World Heritage list, which is required of it as an obligation under the World Heritage convention, a convention to which, it seems we need to remind the Government, our country is a signatory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The supplementary question had a few parts and I hope I can recall all of them. The first part asked why the report has not surfaced and who suppressed it. I think it is a State government report, so it is a matter for the Government of Tasmania. I do not think it is up to the Minister, Mrs Kelly, to determine who suppressed it. It is not her report. I will not be asking her to do that, but I will be seeking further clarification on the report. Obviously, it is a matter of interest to me and I will chase it up.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the indicative list-I argued fairly strongly at, I think it was, the 1988 meeting of the World Heritage convention that was held in Brazilia that we should not be forced to prepare indicative lists, and that was accepted by the meeting at the time. I did so because there were many in Australia who were actively misrepresenting what World Heritage was about. I believe that, had the Government sought to even begin to look at an area, even if that area fell way below a World Heritage nomination standard, it would create confusion, fear and, in some cases, panic and I did not think that was a good idea. I will not personally be urging Mrs Kelly to prepare an indicative list. Anyone who talks to those people who administer the World Heritage convention will find that they are more than happy with the role that Australia has played and wish other nations would do the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the Government's reasons for reissuing Medicare cards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Foreman and other senators will know that in the Budget session last year the Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Brian Howe, announced that the Medicare cards would, in fact, become general health care cards as part of the reform of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). They will be used as evidence for eligibility for both the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and for Medicare.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister, Mr Howe, is determined to give the pharmaceutical scheme administration more integrity than it has had to date. There have been problems in the past of people claiming pharmaceuticals at a concessional price when they were no longer entitled to it, and we did not have a mechanism for accurate and timely eligibility checking.

Medicare cards need to be replaced for many reasons, for example to ensure that lost and stolen cards are not inappropriately used; to set up a continuing basis for reissuing cards to minimise their misuse; to establish a regular checking system to identify people who have died or have left Australia; to improve the efficiency of PBS and Medicare administration; and to protect doctors and pharmacists from providing free or concessional services or pharmaceuticals to those who are ineligible for them.

People are often not aware that they need to inform the Health Insurance Commission of the death of spouses or relatives. Because the Health Insurance Commission has not had any systematic way of updating its records, more names of people are enrolled as eligible for Medicare benefits than there should be. Reissuing Medicare cards will let the Health Insurance Commission update its records to account for the people who have died or who have left Australia.

We will gain significant administrative efficiencies by incorporating information on a magnetic strip on the back of the card. This means that pharmacists and claims clerks in Medicare offices will not have to key in numbers. They will simply have to swipe the card and the claimant's Medicare number, the card issue date and the expiry date will be recorded without mistakes. Mr Howe has made a commitment that computer terminals and the swiping equipment will be publicly available in each capital city so that people can satisfy themselves about the information encoded in the magnetic strip on the back of the card. I think that will be of great interest to most holders of these cards.

Finally, the Health Insurance Commission has been working very closely with the Privacy Commissioner to deal constructively with the privacy concerns which this change to the Medicare card raises. The Privacy Commissioner has approved the Health Insurance Commission's arrangements for reissuing Medicare cards, and the Health Insurance Commission will be working closely with him to develop guidelines for the way that they are used.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: is it true that he will be attending a lunch in the office of the Labor President of the upper House of New South Wales, Johnno Johnson, on Friday, 8 March 1991? Can the Minister confirm that a number of companies have been invited to attend, at a cost of $1,250 per head, with the proceeds to go to the Australian Labor Party? Can the Minister explain on what basis invitations for this lunch were made by the Labor Party, and whether it is true that companies invited have been given to believe that attendance will give them an advantage in picking up contracts for reconstruction work in Kuwait? Can the Minister assure companies not invited or, in the current economic climate, not able to pay the $1,250 that the Australian Government will seek to maximise the benefit to all Australians rather than to favoured companies?
—I am absolutely delighted to learn that I am worth $1,250 a head.
—It is what you are offering.

—No, because all that I am offering for that $1,250 is the pleasure of my company. Anyone who is willing to spend that for that purpose is an entirely welcome lunch guest, as far as I am concerned. I am not aware of the circumstances that are associated with the particular invitations on Friday. All that I am aware of is that this is one of a series of such lunches which are held from time to time. I think there have been at least half a dozen held involving different Ministers from the Cabinet.
—I was worth only $500.

—For Senator Collins, $500, Q.E.D. There you are, quite easily done. It is an entirely familiar fund raising device that parties go in for. The fact that the Opposition is demonstrating the kind of wistfulness and pain that we are hearing on this occasion is a demonstration of just how successful it has been.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Constituents have raised with me proposals to change air traffic systems in Australia. Can the Minister confirm that the changes proposed will involve having only two traffic control centres, one in Brisbane and one in Melbourne? What does this mean for air traffic control at our major airports? Will it be safer? Will control towers in our major airports continue to have visual back-up systems? What does it mean for staff? Will there be a loss of jobs and will people wishing to continue in their work have to move to Brisbane or Melbourne? What does it mean for control at regional airports and at airstrips that only have intermittent use-for example, the Birdsville strip for the annual Birdsville races?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm that the board of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has taken what is certainly a major decision in recent weeks in respect of completely reorganising the air traffic control systems in Australia. The reason it is being done is that it goes hand in glove with the changed arrangements with the actual control of Australia's air space management.

—That is not going to happen. The current system, which is anachronistic, has got six air traffic control centres which are based on State boundaries. They do not actually reflect the traffic flow of the aircraft themselves. CAA has taken the opportunity to completely move away from this to a modern integrated system which will have two major centres, one in Brisbane and one in Melbourne, which will control all of Australia's controlled air space. Control towers will still continue to exist at airports and they will provide the same services they provide now with approach, departure and surface traffic management at the airport itself. There will be an increase in the safety factor, if anything, provided by this new system, because it will cut down the unnecessary number of sector hand overs of an aircraft from one controller to another as it travels across Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the last part of the question about the Birdsville races: the CAA will continue to provide the same service it currently provides for one-off events where there is a very large amount of aviation traffic to an area that does not normally receive it. The CAA will provide mobile control facilities at those events.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to a speech on 22 February given in Washington by his colleague and former Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget in which he said that Australia's present recession is a function of fiscal policy being too loose and that the Hawke Government `has massively stuffed up the economy'. Does the Minister agree with those views and, if not, why not?

—I have not seen Senator Walsh's remarks. I assume that they have been taken out of context. One thing I would be pretty sure about is that Senator Walsh would not use an expression like `stuffed up' in any public audience. I will try to find out exactly what Senator Walsh said about fiscal policy and provide an answer in due course.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for that answer. I can assure him that Senator Walsh did use the term `massively stuffed up'.
—Were you there?

—No, but I have read the text of his speech, which was released in Australia. Therefore, I am very surprised that the Minister has not read it. I can assure the Minister that my quotes were not taken out of context. That being the case, I still ask: does the Minister agree with those views?
—Senator Short did not ask me at the beginning whether I agreed with those views; so that is not a supplementary question.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given the potentially damaging effects to Australia of the United States export enhancement program, can the Minister explain the purpose of the bipartisan trade delegation to the US this week and what the delegation hopes to achieve?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of interjections which I will not bother to answer, but one thing is quite clear: if Opposition senators want to interject about this, I remind them that they are the last people to get their act together in relation to this delegation. It was intended that this be a bipartisan delegation right from the beginning. It is quite astounding that the Opposition has been unable, it seems, to make a sensible selection in respect of that delegation.

ANSWER.PARA: The purpose of the delegation is simply to emphasise an issue which has been a running one between the Australian and United States governments over the trade enhancement program. It is hoped that the delegation will be a comprehensive one and will at least have some impact prior to the resumption of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Round on the United States Administration, because of essentially farm subsidies. That, of course, has done immense damage to Australian producers.

The delegation, which follows delegations which have been sent to the United States over many years by various governments, comes at the most important time of any of those delegations because the problem is greater than it has ever been in the past. So I think the Senate should wish the delegation every success. I understand that Mr Downer will be attending the delegation as a sort of late entrant. I hope that he will contribute to the delegation's success as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. How much of the 1990-91 $8.1 billion Budget surplus estimated at Budget time last August was earmarked for payment of the Government debt? What effect will the now forecast near or total disappearance of this surplus have on the Government's debt redemption program, and what effect will it have on Australia's foreign debt position?

—The Treasurer has indicated quite recently his view of what the surplus or deficit is likely to be. Of course, the payment of government debt is an important contribution to that deficit. But I cannot give the honourable senator the precise figures at the moment. I will get a precise statement on that for him as soon as I can.

—I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: what assessment has the Australian Government made of the outcome of the weekend's referenda in the Baltic states? What is the Government's response to these developments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reports we have to hand to date suggest that the results of the referenda in Estonia and Latvia over the weekend on 3 March produced a very strong vote indeed in favour of independence. It will be recalled that the poll held in Lithuania in January, in which there was a turnout of some 84 per cent, produced a 91 per cent vote in favour of independence. That was a particularly high vote, of course, not least because some 80 per cent of the Lithuanian population presently resident in Lithuania are ethnic Lithuanians. It was not anticipated that anything like that result would be achieved in the other two states, where the percentage of ethnic Latvians, for example, is only 54 per cent, with the bulk of the rest being ethnic Russians and, in the case of Estonia, where the locals constitute only 65 per cent of the population. But in the event the figures were remarkably strong.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been some confusion in press reports this morning right across the spectrum, but the latest figures available to me suggest that in Latvia the yes vote was in fact 73 per cent with a turnout of 88 per cent. So it was not a question of the election being boycotted by the Russian speakers; it was a very high turnout, in fact higher than in Lithuania, with a very strong independence vote. In Estonia, with a turnout of 83 per cent, the vote was 77 per cent. If those figures hold-and they are only preliminary estimates available to me-they are stunningly strong. Of course, they represent very clearly, as did the declarations of independence themselves made by the Baltic states last year, the aspirations of the Baltic peoples to rejoin the family of nations through peaceful and democratic means-aspirations which the Australian Government has made repeatedly clear it very strongly supports.

Finally, without going back over the history of previous statements that we have made-I think our reaction to the very unhappy events in January is clear and on the record-I understand that Soviet and Baltic representatives have recently met to discuss the resumption of substantive talks on the future status of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. We are watching the situation very closely, hopeful that the proposed negotiations will take place in an atmosphere free of intimidation or threat of force. We hope-I know everyone in the Senate does-that those negotiations will produce results consistent with the legitimate aspirations of the Baltic people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: given that the private investment figures released yesterday showed an 11 per cent fall in investment for the December 1990 quarter-the largest quarterly fall since 1979-does the Minister believe that Australia will record its third successive quarter of negative growth when the national accounts figures are released later this month?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to foreshadow what may be in the national accounts figures; I do not know.
—You wouldn't.

—No, I would not know. Only a clever chap such as Senator Alston would know, probably by delving into the Statistician's department. We do not get that information; we get it when everybody else does. The decline in private investment is worrying but not entirely surprising.
—Not long ago you were talking about the investment boom.

—Absolutely; that is true. The data for the December quarter shows a large decrease in investment compared to the previous quarter. It has been felt equally in plant and equipment and in buildings and structures. The figures move fairly rapidly from quarter to quarter. For example, the September quarter showed an increase in total investment of over 6 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: There is also a large degree of variability in these figures across sectors, which I think is important. In the finance, property and business services sector, the falls were large. Manufacturing and mining recorded slight gains in investment for the quarter. That does not say anything about anticipation; all it says is that there were things in the pipeline but slight gains were shown in respect of manufacturing and mining.

Longer term data is perhaps a better guide to the investment performance of the economy. Manufacturing investment has been quite strong over the last few years. It has grown at an average rate of 11.5 per cent a year. I make the point that total investment performance has also exceeded past experience with business fixed investment equivalent to 12.9 per cent of gross domestic product over 1989-90-that is, two percentage points above the average.

However, the point of Senator Chapman's question is that we can all draw conclusions from those figures. I am pleased, in a sense, that the fall in mining and manufacturing investment is not as significant as it is in the service sector-not that I welcome that, but it is good that the figures are better in those two sectors. With regard to the national accounts figures, I cannot prophesy anything but I anticipate that there would be negative growth in this quarter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from the Supreme Soviet of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, led by Dr Tabeev. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome them to the Senate and trust that their visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. In relation to the massive oil spill in the Persian Gulf, a result of the Gulf war, and now regarded as one of the most environmentally dangerous problems to come out of this conflict, I ask: following the ending of hostilities in the Middle East, what is the Federal Government doing to assist in the massive clean-up of this oil pollution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be very difficult to imagine a more criminal action than that conducted by the troops in Kuwait in deliberately destroying and firing 900 oil wells and dumping a massive amount of oil into the Gulf. The amount of oil in the Gulf is estimated to be somewhere between one and two million barrels. To this point in time the efforts have been concentrated on protecting the desalination plants from fouling because the war itself has prevented a more comprehensive effort being directed to doing something about this massive oil spill, certainly the worst the world has ever seen.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of requests from Saudi Arabia and Bahrain to the international community, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority has made available a technical expert in oil pollution and the Australian Institute of Petroleum Ltd has also made available one of its experts. Both of these experts left Australia for the area last Sunday. They will be part of an international team that will now direct its efforts to cleaning up the spill.

As I say, to date the efforts have concentrated on protecting the desalination plants from the worst ravages of the spill. This will not be a completely one-way exercise so far as Australia or, indeed, any of the other participating countries are concerned, because with the sensitive areas in Australia, such as the Great Barrier Reef, we stand to gain much from the knowledge that these experts will receive from participating in what I hope will be, as much as it can be, a successful effort in doing something about this massive spill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. In light of the critical worsening situation in various rural commodities and taking into account his answer to Senator Childs earlier in Question Time on the importance of the trade mission to Washington, I ask the Minister why the Prime Minister refused to go on the bipartisan mission as suggested by Dr Hewson and Mr Tim Fischer.

—I must say that the National Party of Australia got it right for once. Mr Fischer probably did not have anything else to do besides go on the trade mission; the Prime Minister does, of course, and Senator Brownhill is fully aware of that. Prime Ministers have an enormous range of responsibilities. The Prime Minister has been in regular contact with the United States Administration on this issue.
—Has he phoned the President about a game of golf?
—There seems to be a babble of excitement over here because the Prime Minister had a game of golf.
—Cricket, golf.

—Or he goes to the cricket. I suppose that it is fair to say, when we cast our memories back, that if Prime Minister Menzies had not spent six months in a year going to the cricket when he was Prime Minister the country might have been better off than it is now. I think half a day at the cricket is a legitimate pastime for any Prime Minister, even in present circumstances-which, of course, are admittedly difficult.

—I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the results of the Australian workplace industrial relations survey. Is it true that the response rate to the survey was nearly 90 per cent? If this is so, given that this is a particularly high response rate for such a comprehensive survey, should users of the survey results, such as academics and industrial relations practitioners, have confidence in the accuracy of the results? Is there any information in the results of the survey which debunk some of the conservative myths about the industrial relations system in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last question is yes, but I will come to that in the answers to the other questions. Last Thursday in Melbourne I had the pleasure of releasing a seminal work in industrial relations. This study, conducted by my Department, covered interviews with some 4,500 managers and industrial relations practitioners on the union side in 2,300 workplaces around Australia-workplaces representative of the spread of industry that this country has. The survey took two years to complete. It was supervised by the Australian Bureau of Statistics to ensure statistical accuracy and had a compliance rate of 87.5 per cent, which is near to the 90 per cent figure mentioned in the question. I think we can now confidently, for the first time, talk about what in fact is the case in workplaces in this country where more than five workers are employed.

ANSWER.PARA: There are three major issues highlighted by the survey which I think are important from a policy point of view. Firstly, there is a distressingly low level of communication between management and employees in this country compared with other countries. We languish at the bottom of the class in talking to one another in the workplace. Secondly, unfortunately there is little infrastructure in place for enterprise negotiations to succeed, which is a salutary comment, coming at this time with the national wage case decision, which will set down guidelines for enterprise negotiation, only weeks away. As well, there is a distressingly short life span for industrial relations representatives on the company side. Most hold their position for only two years, meaning that corporate memory in companies about industrial relations practices is quite short. There is equally a very high turnover rate on the union side with shop stewards, which perhaps means that frequently there is a recasting yet again of the wheel that was invented in the past.

One of the myths that were exploded by the survey is that Australian industry is in a constant state of disruption; it is not. Nearly three-quarters of all workplaces reported that they had never ever experienced industrial action. The second myth, I think, is that the arbitration system is inflexible; that myth is exploded comprehensively. A small minority of managers said that they thought there was some inflexibility. Overwhelmingly, most said they did not believe that. They were satisfied with the progress made in award restructuring that has been achieved; they were satisfied with the spread of hours and the hours of work during which they supervised their workers. Most of them overwhelmingly expressed no need for change in that area. The third myth is that the Australian workplace is somehow static and rigid and does not change. Eighty-seven per cent of companies reported significant organisational change in their enterprise in the last four years.

Let me conclude by saying that I have now received a press release issued by the shadow spokesman for industrial relations, Mr Howard. He should really get his facts right. —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Firstly, can the Minister advise the Senate what procedures are involved in authorising an official telephone tap-for instance, by whose authority are telephones tapped; what steps have to be taken to commence the operation; is there a time limit and, if so, can it be extended? Secondly, has the tapping of any Federal parliamentary member been authorised in the past five years? Thirdly, if any individuals suspected that their phone was being illegally tapped, as both I and John McLennan do, what steps does the Minister recommend they take? Fourthly, what protection in relation to unauthorised tapping is available to witnesses appearing before parliamentary inquiries, such as the bank inquiry, to give them protection under parliamentary privilege prior to their appearance before the inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is always a temptation in any society fighting organised crime or dealing with national security questions to vigorously employ all means to achieve the desired social goals, and that includes telephone intercepts, but this Parliament has laid down very stringent rules governing the obtaining of warrants to enable the interception of telephones in order to deal with law enforcement and national security matters. They are set out in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to law enforcement, it is quite clear that the offence being investigated has to be of a serious character, such as murder or drug trafficking of a particular type, but the most important protection is that a warrant must be obtained from a Federal judge-not a magistrate or a Supreme Court judge but a Federal judge-in order that the intercept be lawfully undertaken. The judge has to satisfy himself or herself as to whether the particular lines of law enforcement investigation have been exhausted, which would leave telephone interception as a last resort in the investigation of a particular matter.

The warrant is issued to the Telecommunications Interception Division of the Australian Federal Police, which executes the warrant on behalf of the Federal Police or any State police force which may be participating in the telephone interception arrangements under the Act. A time limit of 90 days is imposed by the Act and extension is possible through the warranting procedure. Each warrant obtained by the Australian Federal Police is brought to my attention, and in relation to State police forces warrants are brought to the attention of the relevant State Minister. In relation to security matters, a warrant must be obtained from the Attorney-General, and in emergencies, where stringent conditions are once again imposed, it may be obtained from the Director-General, but I think only for 48 hours. The warrant is executed by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and may remain in force for up to six months.

In relation to Senator McLean's question about whether the tapping of any Federal parliamentary member's telephone has been authorised in the past five years, in accordance with long-established practice I will neither confirm nor deny that any particular person has been subject to telephone interception. I think I have indicated that there is, certainly in the case of law enforcement matters, stringent judicial control, and, in the case of both law enforcement and national security matters, political responsibility is taken by the relevant portfolio Ministers in relation to the obtaining of warrants for interception.

Senator McLean claims that both he and a Mr John McLennan suspect their phones have been illegally tapped and asks me what they might do in this situation. Quite clearly the appropriate course-and it must have been known to Senator McLean-would be to contact the Australian Federal Police in so far as an offence under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act is alleged. I must say that when I first had some notice that this question might be asked-I got notice at about midday-my immediate reaction was to have phoned the Assistant Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, who deals with operational matters, in order to alert him to this allegation.

I would have thought that rather than Senator McLean coming to Question Time and giving the alleged tappers public notice of the fact that he harboured these suspicions and that an investigation might be undertaken, he ought to have undertaken the very sensible course of contacting the Australian Federal Police. I understand that his office was advised over the lunch hour that that would be a proper course to undertake. If an irregularity in the line has given rise to this suspicion, then quite obviously it might be appropriate to check with Telecom Australia as to the technical reason for the irregularity.

The Telecommunications (Interceptions) Act prohibits anyone from tapping a telephone line except in the circumstances I have outlined. A penalty of $5,000 or imprisonment for a period of up to two years is provided for the offence. As to the question of parliamentary privilege, I believe that is a question which is best answered by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration undertaking the bank inquiry. I believe that any concerns in that regard ought to be directed to that Committee in the first instance.

Senator Bolkus: On 20 February 1991 (Hansard page 906) Senator Reid asked me a question without notice concerning the Government's response to recent reports on the Institute of Advanced Studies (IAS) at the Australian National University (ANU).
The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, the Hon Peter Baldwin MP, has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question.

The Government commissioned a review of the Institute of Advanced Studies (IAS) in January 1990 headed by Sir Ninian Stephen. In announcing the review, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the Hon J S Dawkins MP, said the need for a comprehensive review of the IAS had been recognised both by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) and by the University itself. The IAS had been established in 1946 and it was considered that it needed a new mandate to take it into the next century.

The Review Report (Stephen Report), which was presented to the Government on 5 November 1990 and publicly released, concluded that the IAS continues to have an important role to play as a major Australian centre of research and of research training at the highest level. However, it also recommended that the Institute's charter be extended to include the additional role of being a research resource for the whole of Australia's higher education research community and indeed Australian research generally. It recommended that the IAS should forge stronger co-operative links with State universities. This calls for some changes within the IAS.

In December last year, Mr Baldwin sought advice from Professor Chubb, Chair of the Higher Education Council, NBEET, on the implications of the Stephen Report with particular reference to the provision of higher education in the ACT.

Professor Chubb's advice to the Minister on achieving the Stephen recommendation in relation to the IAS was that national acceptance of the Institute would be most readily achieved if it were a free-standing research/postgraduate institute, as it began.

He then went on to advise the Minister that if this approach was adopted it would be appropriate to look to a merging of the ANU Faculties, the University of Canberra and the Canberra Institute of the Arts to provide a strong higher education resource for the ACT and region.

Mr Baldwin is currently consulting with all interested parties in the ACT and the Government intends to move quickly to announce its decision on the future structure of ACT higher education to remove any uncertainty about the ANU's future.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator MacGibbon asked me in Question Time on 21 February 1991:

Is it a fact that around December last year the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation called for expressions of interest from the aviation industry to operate and maintain its F27 aircraft? Is it a fact that contract has been awarded to the Civil Aviation Authority? If so, why are the regulators of the aviation industry competing in a commercial area?
The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

The CSIRO advertised nationally on 30 November 1990 inviting expressions of interest to meet their requirement for a suitably qualified contractor to operate and/or maintain its Fokker F27 aircraft for a period ending on 30 June 1992. A submission was lodged with the CSIRO by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) on the basis that the CAA's Flying Unit only be considered if aviation industry agencies cannot fulfil the requirements of the work.
I am advised that the CSIRO has not finalised the assessment of the expressions of interest.

The CAA as a Government Business Enterprise has a policy which allows its Flying Unit to make specialist services available in Australia on commercial terms in circumstances where the aviation industry does not have the capacity to fully meet the requirement. On occasions at the industry's request, the CAA has previously entered into joint ventures in order to retain business in Australia which would otherwise have gone to foreign aviation interests.

14 February 1991
The Hon Peter Staples MP
Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Peter

I refer to the Therapeutic Goods Regulations, Statutory Rules 1990 No. 394, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 14 February 1991. The Committee also noted that the Explanatory Statement did not mention that various provisions of the Regulations implemented undertakings given to the Committee. Patricia Giles
Chair
Hon Peter Staples MP
Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services
18 February 1991
Senator P.J. Giles
Chair
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
The Senate
Parliament House
Dear Senator Giles
I refer to your correspondence of 14 February 1991 regarding delegation of the Secretary to waive or reduce fees under the Regulations to the Therapeutic Goods Act (1989).

The circumstances under which the fees may be waived or reduced are set out under Regulation 45 with sub-regulations 45(1) and 45(2) requiring the delegate to exercise judgement in making the decision.
