SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition parties have been spelling out the solution for many years. In simple terms the solution is, firstly, that we must become more productive and more competitive and, secondly, that we need to increase our savings and our investment in Australian business. They are simple propositions-not complicated. In a nutshell, we must become more productive and competitive and we must save more. This Government seems to be unable to implement policies to effect those ends.

We have debated these proposals so often that I think Government senators are now beginning to understand and agree with the proposal; but not the Australian Treasurer (Mr Keating). Faced with this major problem of increasing foreign debt, which is getting worse by millions of dollars every month, he pulled the big lever of high interest rates to cut imports. I ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President: how on earth would that increase productivity?

Senator McMullan is going to follow me in this debate. I ask him to tell the Senate how increasing interest rates would increase productivity. Does he agree with me that increasing productivity would have been one of the solutions to our problem and continues today to be one of the solutions to our problems? I ask him: how would high interest rates increase productivity? Of course, they would not. Then the Treasurer, having pulled that lever, kept it on too long, as we continued to tell him week after week, month after month that it was on too long--

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not.
—We certainly did. We continually told him that it was on too long. Now we are faced with a major depression.
—When we eased interest rates in January 1990, you opposed it and said it was too soon.

—In January 1990 you introduced it? That is about it. I understand that. Now we are faced with a major depression brought about by this Government's policy of high interest rates imposed at too high a rate and kept on for too long. This might have reduced our imports but it has destroyed investment in this country and it has broken the morale of many of the people.

SPEECH.PARA: This was the recession that Mr Keating had to have. Why did he have to have this recession? He and Mr Kelty have entered into an agreement which has left the Treasurer with no alternatives but to increase interest rates. The Australian community is now paying dearly for that liaison between Mr Keating and Mr Kelty. Has nothing been learned in the 60 years since the 1930s? Have those people over in the Treasury offices learned nothing?

When Senator McMullan gets up to speak, it will not do him any good to refer to the problems of the Fraser Government in the 1980s because at least the Fraser Government had two good excuses for the situation then-a world recession, which the Government does not have, and an Australia-wide drought, which broke almost immediately Mr Hawke was elected. So the Fraser Government had two good excuses for the problems of the early 1980s.

This Government has had no such problems at all; it has had no excuse at all. It has introduced this recession for one purpose only-to cut imports. It has done that because it was not game to do any of the other things which should have been done. It did not have the courage to take on the trade union movement; it did not have the courage to break the agreement with Mr Kelty; and it did not have the courage to face the left wing of the Labor Party. What it did was squeeze the economy dry, and it is now carrying the responsibility for that.

Has the Government no compassion for what it has done to the people of Australia? Small business is hurting desperately-perhaps most of all. I might say that small business employs about 50 per cent of the work force and is responsible for about 40 per cent of Australia's value-added product. We know that small business does not have a high profile. It is not spectacular and there are few stories about it in the papers. But the hurt is deep.

Figures for the 1990 December quarter-the last quarter published so far-show a 56 per cent increase in Australia's bankruptcies over the December quarter of 1989. That included an increase of 69 per cent in Victoria, 60 per cent in New South Wales and 89 per cent in Western Australia, which my colleague, Senator Knowles, will refer to during the course of this debate. But they are only figures. Think of what it means to the people who have gone bankrupt-people who have given their all for their business but who are now owing debts beyond their ability to repay. Think of the effects of bankruptcy on them and on their children.

What about those people who have not gone bankrupt but who have had to sell everything in order to keep their business going? Close personal friends of mine-not quite my age, but approaching it-have had to sell their homes and all their assets in order to pay off their debts so they can keep their businesses going. They are working long hours-they have always done so-and are barely surviving. Their life savings have gone. They will not be able to make up the loss, even if their businesses could survive in the vile economic climate we are suffering at the present moment. I know of many who are in this position. I am drawing attention to them because they are not part of the bankruptcy statistics; they have sold their assets in order to pay their debts. It is perhaps fortunate that earlier in their lives they were able to save the assets which they have now lost.

What about the hidden consequences of bankruptcies? What about the employees who are being put off? We know that some of these figures are showing up in the unemployment statistics, but not all. It is no good quoting unemployment statistics. We must appreciate that there are a large number of people out in the community who have lost their jobs but who are still living on whatever capital they have left while they try desperately to obtain some decent job in this vile economic climate.

People living in my State of Victoria find that it is absolutely hopeless trying to get a job. Victorians have turned off their expenditure as they desperately try to save what little they have in the face of the Australian economic climate which has been compounded by the economic climate caused by the Labor Government of Victoria.

What do they say to the few people opposite who are prepared to take an interest in this debate? Are they going to sit there wringing their hands and waiting for something to turn up? Is that what they are doing? Has it never occurred to them that their Treasurer and Mr Kelty are still on the wrong track? What about those people who are working shortened weeks to help their employers survive? I will give another example close to me. The workers at Fletcher Jones in Warrnambool are now down to working a 4-day week. I picked up today's paper and read where the State Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Union of New South Wales, Mr Bill Taylor, talks about Australia's hidden unemployment problem. These are people who are not unemployed but are working shortened weeks. He said:
Workers are having their wages cut . . . every week. In my 36 years with the motor industry I have never seen it worse.
He has never seen it worse. Mr Taylor said that:
. . . while employees wanted to keep their jobs and accept a shorter working week, in the end they were only ``sharing out poverty''.

I emphasise the words `sharing out poverty' because that is what they are doing. Honourable senators opposite should not worry because the Labor Government will give them a $12 a week wage rise very soon and then they will be able to share out some more poverty as they take another cut in the hours they are working. Mr Taylor went on to say:
There may be work for six months on a four-day week, but there is no guarantee they will have a job after that . . .

We should blame the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer, the Reserve Bank of Australia and in particular the public servants advising the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Reserve Bank. As I said earlier, have they learnt nothing from the economic history of the free market world? Have they learnt nothing since the 1930s? They are squeezing the economy like a lemon. I suppose that, if I were given the opportunity to talk with them, they would say to me-and I would understand it-`Look, it was not us. We told the Treasurer what it was all about, but he had this agreement with Mr Kelty, and the only thing he could do to stop these imports was to increase interest rates.'

TALK.START.PARA: —That has increased imports but it has cut our manufacturing right down.

—As Senator Boswell said, in many cases it has cut our manufacturing right down so that we still have far too many imports. However, the Prime Minister and his Cabinet are also responsible. They will be dealt with by the electorate. The people of Australia will throw this Government out, as they should.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now turn to my State of Victoria, which leads the fall in job advertisements. In February there was nearly a 62 per cent fall in job advertisements. How would honourable senators like to be trying to get a job in Victoria? Retail figures have posted successive falls since December 1989, with Victoria recording a 7 per cent drop in retail sales volume over the past year. The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd's chief economist, Mr Ian Little, said:
The slump we saw in the December quarter-
that is, in retail sales-
was very large-a 7 per cent drop is almost unprecedented-it is huge.

It is not uncommon for business spending to rise by 15 per cent in a year but consumer spending moves around in a much narrower band- 4 per cent to zero but a 1 per cent move in consumer spending is much more significant.

Victoria has been destroyed by the Labor Party. Victoria has a typical Labor government. It is taxing the life out of business. It is imposing taxes, charges and fees, including registration fees-anything it can think of-to raise revenue out of business. It is imposing burdens upon business, which might be reasonable in good times but are certainly not reason- able in bad times-and it is not removing those burdens as we pass into bad times. The Victorian Labor Government is taxing the life out of business and out of the ordinary people. It is allowing its big mates to make a fortune, probably and preferably by ripping off the taxpayers. That is mostly what happens under Labor governments. It has destroyed private initiative and enterprise and has brought as many people as possible down to the lowest common denominator.

Let me assure honourable senators that Mr Cain and Mr Jolly will long be remembered by the people of Victoria. Their economic mismanagement has been compounded by that of Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. Now Mrs Kirner is being run by the Trades Hall Council and her solution to Victoria's problems is to give the Trades Hall Council what it demands. That will just keep it quiet for a short time while Mrs Kirner, like Mr Keating, hopes there may be some miraculous solution for the `lucky country'.

There is no doubt that that is what Mr Keating is waiting for. Last week an article by Alan Wood, the economics editor of the Australian, referred to Mr Keating's scenario, `Hang on and hope that some miracle will save the nation'. Mrs Kirner is the same in Victoria. Laura Tingle in yesterday's Australian said that the economic policy of this Government is quite rudderless. She said:
Maybe the reason that the Government's thinking about fiscal policy seems to be either confused or rapidly changing is the result of two things:
First, it doesn't know where the economy is headed.
Second, it doesn't know where economic policy is headed.

That is certainly right. Together the Labor Party in Canberra and the Labor Party in Victoria have ripped the heart out of small business. They have destroyed the confidence of many hundreds of thousands of people in Victoria. They have made life intolerable for those people. It is all very well for Senator McMullan to look aside and smile. I know it does not matter so much here in Canberra. After all, the people of Canberra have fixed jobs, good government jobs. Frequently both spouses are employed in good government jobs. They do not have to worry about unemployment. Let me assure Senator McMullan and other honourable senators opposite that out in the real world people are hurting desperately. No doubt, in a few minutes time, Senator McMullan will tell us we should all just wait and next Tuesday along will come the new economic statement by the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new figures!
—Yes, the new figures and the new solution to the problem.
—It will be the depression we had to have.

—That is right. The Budget surplus has blown down-they used to refer to it as blowing out-and we will probably end up with a deficit, but honourable senators should not worry because Mr Keating will have some explanation about why it will be all right. No-one will worry about what is happening to the people out in the community. Mr Keating will talk about his new solution. Will he have a new solution? I doubt it. My prediction is that he will play around at the edges. Let me give honourable senators an example of a solution put by Terry McCrann in the Herald-Sun last week. I do not say that this is necessarily the solution, but this is what he said should be done:

SPEECH.PARA: What Mr Hawke really needs to be doing on March 12 is standing up and announcing the immediate, total removal of all those impediments which prevent Australian industry operating efficiently in an international context.

I bet the Government will not be doing that. It will play around at the edges, produce a few more bandaids in some way or another and hope that it will be able to keep going just long enough until some miraculous solution comes along. I say to the Senate--

TALK.START.PARA: —There are only two Government senators over there.

—Yes, I know. However, I think a lot of them will look at this on television and say, `Lewis is right. Fancy us allowing this to happen'. We have reached the stage where hundreds of thousands of people out there are suffering desperate pain as a result of members of the Labor Government allowing Mr Keating to pull that massive lever, not taking it off early enough and not doing the other things that should have been done and about which they have been talking for so long. Mr Keating should go. He should resign or be sacked. Indeed the Labor Party in Victoria should go, and in due course the Labor Party in Canberra will go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance which has just been introduced and the support for it are merely another example of the lack of consistency of argument we get from the Opposition and the lack of intellectual rigour that is put in supporting it. I waited in vain for a positive suggestion from Senator Lewis. There may be something he thought we should do. The closest he got was a rather vague quote from Terry McCrann, which was speculative suggestion; he did not actually know whether it was the right idea or not. That was the closest we got to a suggestion as to what we should do. That really ought not to be surprising because the intellectual rigour and the economic analysis we get from Senator Lewis were highlighted, and some of his colleagues--
—The best you can offer is personal abuse.

—Not in the slightest. I am about to talk about the subject matter, unlike some others, but Senator Knowles would not understand that. The proposal last week was that somehow or other the inflation rate in Australia was running at 10.8 per cent because we could multiply the quarterly rate of 2.7 per cent by four and arrive at this miraculous figure. I have searched the record of the quarter before when it was 0.7 per cent. Was Senator Lewis cheering that inflation was somehow 2.8 per cent? Of course, there was a deathly silence. He did not bother to make that point because it was not convenient. I would be quite willing now to say to him: when the next inflation figures come out, on behalf of the Opposition he should multiply that figure by four, and recognise that that is the inflation rate for Australia. Of course, it will be nonsense then, as it was nonsense two weeks ago. It is just an attempt to throw any old statistics around-do not worry about their consistency or accuracy-and hope that it will impress somebody who might have the misfortune to be listening.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Opposition choose different signposts at different times. As different problems arise in the economy and they are resolved, they stop acknowledging the examples they used to use. When Senator Chaney was in this chamber, he used to talk about the problems facing Australian families, highlighted by the fact of how many weeks wages it took to buy a car. Suddenly those opposite have stopped quoting that because that statistic would not count for them. They know that the prices of motor vehicles are falling and the weeks of wages that it would take to buy a motor vehicle are decreasing. That is quite clear. They do not like that statistic, so they have moved away from it.

When the job boom was going on, Dr Hewson said, `Anybody could create jobs, that is easy'. But now he is moving away from that because it is no longer con- venient. Those opposite shift from argument to argument.

Nothing in that critique, that shallow approach taken by those opposite, says that the problems facing the economy nor the social consequences for the individuals affected by it are not very serious; of course they are. Anybody who pretends otherwise-and nobody here will-would be doing a grave disservice. We have to give people the courtesy of showing some consistency and some intellectual rigour in our approach to it. With hindsight, people might say that we could have avoided the recession, we could have avoided slowing down the economy. Everybody acknowledged that it was a slow down we had to have; to their credit, members of the Opposition did not disagree with that. Why should they? As I understand it, nobody has disagreed. Perhaps we could have avoided the recession. Nobody disagreed with the need to slow the economy down except possibly the Australian Democrats, who advocate zero economic growth, but do not want anyone to lose his job. They may have disagreed; I am not sure.

There was some argument in 1989 about what mechanisms ought to be used, but not about the need to do so. There was a need to slow the economy. Everybody realised that we cannot continue to have demand growing at 8 per cent and output growing at 4 per cent. That cannot continue. Even with a magic wand we cannot double output overnight; it is not possible. We can increase it steadily and gradually over the years. Over the last seven years the rate of growth of output has been remarkably high in Australia, the record of economic growth in Australia has been very substantial. But it cannot be doubled overnight; the policies to do that do not exist.

We had a very tight fiscal policy, the tightest fiscal policy Australia has ever had. Interest rates were used as the variable factor. It may well be-I do not think anybody would argue now-that interest rates were loosened too late. The information on which the judgment of timing was made was inadequate and interest rates were loosened too late.

We have had an amazing rewriting of history. Senator Lewis contends that the Opposition was urging us to loosen interest rates earlier. On the day that they were loosened-23 January 1990-the current Leader of the Opposition said that the Government was forcing the pace and we were taking a risk in lowering interest rates because it would cause a crisis for the dollar. He actually opposed the decision. He said that it was a mistake and we were doing it too early. Twelve months after the event he cannot pretend that somehow or other he was advocating that things should be done more quickly when, at the time, he was saying that they were being done too quickly. It may be that members of the Opposition think people do not keep records of what they say because it is not sufficiently significant to be recorded, but unfortunately they were. They opposed the reduction then and at every stage.

Significant measures to start to turn around the economy have been taken. Every reasonable commentator recognises that. There has been significant continuing lowering of interest rates. It is true that there is room for the banks to pass more of that on; much of it has been passed on. There has been a cyclical easing of fiscal policy-entirely appropriately, of course. One thing that most people have learned, but not Senator Lewis or the Opposition, in the last 60 years of economic policy is that there should be a cyclical element in fiscal policy so that when the economy is slowing the fiscal policy is eased to start to pick up that economy, to start to improve the economic performance. Of course it should, and everybody else thinks it should. There have been significant tax cuts at the commencement of this year, which will flow through to increased expenditure capacity for families.

What are the consequences of those policies? The package of policies is leading to falling inflation and creating the precondition for growth with lowered inflation. For example, Westpac, which I quoted the last time we had this debate in the Senate, in its February 1991 Market Insights revised its forecast for next year and said that it expected real gross domestic product growth to be 2.8 per cent, with inflation at 4 per cent. That would be a remarkable performance in Australian economic history. To be coming out of a recession and having a recovery at that rate of growth with low inflation would perhaps break forever the inflationary expectation cycle.

The concern for small business seems somehow to have been tacked on to this matter of public importance. I will address it to some extent, although I think the principal issue we need to be debating is the broader question of macro-economic policy. The best thing we can do for small business is to create a growing economy, to create opportunities which individual men and women and small companies can take advantage of. I did not understand the point that somehow or other small business, in particular, is the cause of the social consequences and problems facing families. I do not want to enter into any sort of textual analysis, there is no point in that, but it is just as painful to be laid off by Ford as it is by a small company.

The broad and most important thing one can do for any small business is to create a growing economy. A number of things have been done in recent times with the specific purpose of enhancing the climate for small business. I have been particularly concerned with tax. Substantial initiatives have been taken there to reduce the burden of compliance costs for small business: for example, by reducing the frequency of remittances and by trying to address the service needs of small business clients. The Industry Commission is currently examining the question of the availability of capital. We have improved the export market development grants scheme particularly so that small and medium sized firms can take advantage of it.

Coordinated measures have been taken by State and Commonwealth governments designed to assist small business in the first ever meeting of Commonwealth, State and Territory small business Ministers last year, and important initiatives are being taken in Victoria and New South Wales on a bipartisan basis, which I think is appropriate, to establish one-stop shops and to provide assistance for small business.

I return to the real issue-the question of macro-economic policy. What is the Opposition's prescription? We did not hear anything about it from Senator Lewis, but we have heard it before. All Senator Lewis added today was an attack on public servants, suggesting that somehow or other public servants were responsible. Notwithstanding that nobody would want to trumpet the current economic circumstances as their proudest achievement, it is entirely inappropriate-and I will not do so from this side of the chamber-to say that the responsibility for the outcome lies with public servants and to attack them for the outcome. Those opposite can attack the Government for sure-that is why we are here and it is our responsibility-but not the people who provide the advice. They must continue to be able to provide free and independent advice.

What is it about this Opposition prescription that will help families? Is it the consumption tax? Such a tax would make it more expensive to have children, more expensive to raise them, and more expensive to buy food and clothes. I can see families all around Australia cheering and saying, `Thank you very much. That is the one thing we need at the moment-the cost of raising our children, buying our food and our clothes made more expensive'! My colleagues on this side of the chamber will dwell on that matter a little more. Will Opposition members help families by cutting expenditure; by threatening the very support that is provided to those who have lost their jobs; by threatening the indexation of family payments; by reducing the assistance to child-care, training, Medicare, rent assistance and public housing that go to make life for Australians in greatest need more palatable?

Senator Lewis spoke of squeezing the economy. Tightening fiscal policy in the way Opposition members propose is the sure-fire guaranteed way to squeeze life out of the economy. That is not surprising. We have always had the situation with conservative parties that their only anti-inflationary strategy is to squeeze all the life out of the economy by fiscal policy. That is exactly what their proposals would do. But they do not understand two other very significant aspects of what is wrong with their proposal on fiscal policy. They fail to understand the fundamental interconnection between public and private sector expenditure. All the reputable recent research in the United States of America makes it absolutely clear that public infrastructure investment is vital to the success of the private sector. If one is driven ideologically to cut all public expenditure, one will guarantee that there will not be a viable private sector. The most recent research is quoted in an article by Robert Reich in The Atlantic Monthly of February of this year as follows:
. . . a one-dollar increase in the stock of public infrastructure adds as much to the productivity of Americans as a four-dollar increase in the stock of business capital.

There has been significant research by Australians associated with the Reserve Bank of Australia to reinforce that point in the Australian economic context, namely, that the success of the private sector is significantly dependent on the volume of public sector infrastructure investment.

We also have these grave proposals about changing education policy associated with the fiscal policy of the conservatives, who fail to see the social justice or economic implications. Recent United States research, which seems to be consistent internationally, shows that schools with smaller classes and better paid teachers produce young people who command higher salaries once they join the work force. All the evidence is that, when the role of government in equalising the provision of those facilities is taken away, the greatest assistance is provided to those already privileged. That is exactly what would follow from the Opposition's education policies, but it also has significant economic policy consequences because we are failing to train the future generation of Australians we need if the economy is to continue to grow.

The consumption tax that the Opposition proposes to introduce will not enhance the living standards of ordinary Australian families. Cutting expenditure will threaten the living standards of ordinary Australian families and the Opposition's attack on wages will certainly impair the living standards of ordinary Australian families for whom Opposition members profess concern. They always wail and weep about the living standards of ordinary Australian families and wage and salary earners, but every time there is a proposal to increase that wage, they attack it, as Senator Lewis today attacked the proposal for a $12 increase. Opposition members try to deny this and suggest that we should have a magical flexibility which will increase wages. But we see when we look at the aggregate outcomes about which they talk that their wages policy can achieve its economic policy objectives only if the increase in wages across the economy as a whole is less. It is true that some individuals may be better off, particularly those who are already advantaged, but essentially such a policy will attack the living standards of Australian workers because their wages will be less.

Without a wages policy Opposition members cannot have an anti-inflation strategy. They cannot make such a strategy add up if they cannot control wages, and they cannot. It continues to be the Achilles heel of their economic policy. Therefore they come back to the policy of slashing public expenditure, irrespective of the social justice implications, because it is the only semblance of an anti-inflationary strategy that they have.

Here we have for the first time in a generation, as every reputable economist in Australia recognises, the possibility of breaking the inflationary cycle and the cycle of inflationary expectations in Australia. But what do Opposition members propose? They propose a consumption tax that will put prices up and destroy that possibility, on the very eve of the most significant initiative that could be taken to enhance the long term viability and competitiveness of Australian business. It flows straight through into the price of capital for Australian business, which is always a problem for the competitiveness of Australian business and which is significantly influenced by the underlying rate of inflation. The expectation that Australians and people overseas have about inflation in Australia determines the long term bond rate; it determines the cost of money to Australian business. That has always been unacceptably high because Australia has always had an uncompetitively high rate of inflation. We are on the eve of the opportunity to break that.

If we are to come out of this recession with any advantage at all, it is vital that we come out of it in a situation where we can have broken the back of inflation and the cycle of inflationary expectation which has bedevilled Australia for a generation. That is absolutely fundamental, and any reputable economist-and there are none speaking in this debate from the other side-would acknowledge that that is vital for Australia as to where it must go economically from here. That requires no consumption tax and a wages strategy with some semblance of a capacity to control it.

In conclusion, in the week leading up to 12 March, when the Government's major policy initiatives between now and the Budget will be outlined, debate on this matter so far and the speech made by Senator Lewis has not said very much about the Government, but it has said a lot about the Opposition. It has gone back to the traditional Opposition formula that we have always had from conservatives for a generation. They fight unemployment by putting people out of work, they fight inflation by putting up prices, and they improve workers' living standards by attacking wages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that at least we agree on one thing in this chamber today, and that is that there certainly is a problem. It is unfortunate that we could not have heard a little more from the Government about its specific policies. I await with interest the statement that will be made next week.

SPEECH.PARA: As for looking at the problem, a great deal of hardship is indeed being felt in the Australian community. It is being experienced particularly by ordinary Australian families, many of them facing either the unemployment of their breadwinner or the prospect of their young people who are now finishing their education spending a long time on supporting benefits because they do not have the opportunity to find a realistic job with any prospects.

Many are facing the collapse of their small business and many farmers are, indeed, this year working hard to see only a negative income as their reward. This is all largely through no fault of their own but through a Government created environment of high interest rates, reduced protection, reduced public investment in infrastructure and the mindless pursuit of financial deregulation.

And still the recession deepens. Still ordinary families feel the blight of unemployment and financial ruin. But still we hear nothing specific as to what the Government will do in the short term, the medium term and the long term to alleviate the immediate hardship. Again, I say, I await with interest the statements to be made next week.

Along with all of this, and along with all the rhetoric and theories we have heard so far, there does not seem to be so much as a shred of sympathy, let alone concrete help, for the plight of those who have fallen to the bottom of Mr Keating's famous J-curve: those people who are now facing many months, if not years, of continuing hardship watching businesses that they have spent a lifetime building up crumbling around them.

Yes, Australia is hurting and it is ordinary Australian families who are hurting the most. It is all too easy to just look at the figures and not see the human and social costs of the recession. But we must look at these figures because they tell their own story. I want to go through a series of these figures now.

I will start with bankruptcies. These have skyrocketed as a consequence of the Government's high interest rate policies. The June quarter 1990 saw a 10 per cent increase over the June quarter 1989. By the September quarter 1990 there was a 32 per cent increase over September 1989 and the December quarter 1990 showed a 56 per cent increase over December 1989. In my home State of South Australia bankruptcies rose by more than 21 per cent in the December quarter. One can speculate only with considerable trepidation on what the figures for the coming March quarter will be, considering that the recession, the Government agrees, is continuing and is likely to deepen.

The second group of figures is the unemployment figures. Unemployment is reaching crisis levels. There are now 767,000 Australians unemployed-9.1 per cent of the work force; that is, 9 per cent of Australians are being tossed on to the unemployment scrap heap by a Labor government that does not even have the grace to apologise to them. Yesterday saw the Australian Council of Social Service predict that by the middle of this year one million Australians, including nearly a quarter of a million children, will be dependent on unemployment benefits. These appalling figures make a mockery of the Government's efforts to disguise the effects of the recession-the one that we had to have-and make it clear that child poverty, in particular, in this country remains a terrible and scandalous problem.

The third group of figures we should look at is job vacancies. Here the picture is certainly no brighter. The various indices used to measure job vacancies all show them to be fewer than during the corresponding period of a year before. Far fewer jobs are available for those people who are seeking them. In fact, there are now 18 unemployed people on average looking for every job. That is double the historical average.

Fourthly, I turn to private capital investment. This has fallen for the last two quarters. This is the investment which will create the jobs we need to alleviate the hardship of those who are now experiencing the unemployment that they had to have. Where are the Government's solutions to this shortfall? Other than the mutterings of some Ministers and backbenchers, the issue of increased Government investment in public infrastructure barely rates a mention.

Finally, I want to look specifically at farming statistics. The statistics from rural Australia tell a similar story. A recent Australian National Opinion Poll survey showed that farm incomes are expected to drop 67 per cent in this coming year. Wheat farmers have, on average, only a 2 per cent margin-that is, the difference between their costs and prices-and out of this they must meet the living expenses for their families. Of our 120,000 farmers, 74 per cent carry an average debt of $225,000. What these figures show is that the small farming business is feeling the effects of the recession, and feeling them very hard.

Then we must look at the reality behind the figures. What do they mean? The rural figures mean that in country areas the number of children living in poverty is double the national rate of one in eight. If I refer extensively to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of Tuesday, 5 March, we will see what the figures mean. The article states:
Cash-starved families in South Australia are now queuing for food and other assistance from welfare agencies.
But as the recession deepens and the number of people hit by unemployment and financial crisis rises, demand for emergency housing and food is outstripping supply.
More people are now being turned away from agencies than can be helped.
Help is no longer being sought just by welfare recipients, but by people in paid employment who can no longer make ends meet.
Four-day working weeks and cuts in overtime mean that many families are now struggling to meet their financial commitments and are going without basic necessities . . .
The Anglican Community Services (ACS) at Elizabeth issued food and cash to 197 people in January, but was forced to turn away another 540.
The trend continued for last month.
The article goes on to say that 196 people were actually able to get help, but 247 had to be turned away. It continues as follows:
The director of the Para District Counselling Service at Elizabeth, Ms Rosemary Thompson, said the agency handed out $3500 worth of emergency financial assistance in a three-day period in January.
The demand exhausted the agency's monthly budget and it had to refuse financial help for the rest of the month.
Finally, the article states:
When agencies which are seen as a last resort by many people can't help any more, where do those people go?

There is a series of other problems. I mentioned earlier the mindset that has gripped this Government on the issues of free trade and financial deregulation. My colleague Senator McLean has pursued for quite some time in this place the matter of the banks' unethical and irresponsible behaviour, and I will not go into it in any detail today. However, I wish to stress that it is clear that the banks have failed to support small and medium size businesses and that their practices have, in many instances, directly led to the ruin of farming families and small businesses.

Earlier this year Mr Phillip Holt, the Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, submitted to the current bank inquiry that small businesses were paying higher charges for services since bank deregulation. He said that small businesses considered that they were not only getting fewer services from their banks than previously, but were also being forced to pay more for these services.

In a call for tighter regulation of the major banks, the submission of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures went on to say that deregulation of the banking industry had not led to small businesses enjoying the same improvement in their ability to borrow money that larger corporations have enjoyed. Surely it is high time that the Government agreed to hold a full inquiry into the banking system. But we all know why it does not wish to do that: it does not wish to admit that its bright idea to deregulate the financial system has fizzled into a monstrous disaster.

I get many letters from small business people, farming families and working families expressing their views that they have been severely damaged by this Government's policies and its seeming inability to address the issues. This is what is hurting them the most: the fact that this Government is not addressing the issues and the community is sitting back, watching and waiting and, indeed, hoping that some major initiatives will be forthcoming to at least show them that the Government acknowledges the severe problems that they are facing.

I might add here that much of the legislation damaging to ordinary Australian business families over the past five years has passed through this Parliament because the Opposition has supported it. I just want to give one example as it is particularly relevant to this matter of public importance. The Opposition is currently complaining about the timing of company tax payments. On 15 July this year any company with a liability of $20,000 or more will have to pay 85 per cent of its tax liability up front.

When this legislation came before the Senate in 1989 the Australian Democrats accepted that there was merit in it, but we thought it was far too harsh on small business. The Liberal and National parties had identified the same concerns and spoke at length on those. That was, however, only their public position. When it came to the crunch in the Senate, the Opposition voted with the Government to defeat an Australian Democrats amendment that would have assisted businesses with less than an $80,000 tax liability. We see with interest that, while the Opposition says a lot, when it actually comes to voting in this place it often does not follow on with that final step.

I would like to close by specifically looking at a number of Australian Democrat policies and initiatives. We have always had a strong commitment to small business. Aside from its significance as a source of employment, we believe it has a number of qualities essential to the national well-being-to say nothing of the fact that it contributes nearly one half of Australia's gross national product. In the past we have supported measures to assist small business, including the taxation assistance that I mentioned earlier. We have indicated our support for the recommendations in the Beddall report on small business, including strengthening the Trade Practices Act, the establishment of a small business institute and the deferral of capital gains tax when one business is sold and another one is purchased.

We have also been very active in this chamber in moving a number of measures to assist precisely those families which are the subject of this matter of public importance. In particular, I refer to farming families and I call again on the Opposition and the Government to look very closely at the fact that ordinary farming families cannot receive the assistance of the family allowance supplement and Austudy, not because their incomes are minimal-if not zero-but because they have assets which are tools of trade and which, surely, they cannot be expected to sell off piece by piece in order that their families survive.

We have also called on the Government to provide additional assistance for welfare agencies, to provide improved access for people in need of unemployment benefits, to adopt more vigorous policies in stimulating exports, to rein in the banks and to get serious about major reforms of the taxation system-particularly to remove the present biases in favour of unproductive investment and corporate borrowing rather than saving.

It was with great pleasure that I saw the call from the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) for the Government to get involved in the economy. ACOSS called yesterday for the Government to `become more actively involved in identifying and encouraging economic activities which are in the national interest'. I think the Government and the Opposition would do very well to listen to this sort of message coming from the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a matter of public importance submitted by Senator Austin Lewis. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The ongoing pain and suffering inflicted on families by the impact of incompetent economic management of the Hawke government on Australian small business.

My colleague Senator Lewis put to the Senate a very succinct reason why we are concerned about this particular issue. It was quite concerning, to say the least, that Senator McMullan, in response, could only muster personal abuse of the Opposition and did not bother to even attempt to answer or touch on the issue at hand. He made many allegations and I will come to a number of those throughout my contribution. I suppose one of the most outrageous things he said was when he referred to former Senator Chaney always saying how long it took for an average family to buy a new car and how much of weekly earnings it would take to buy that car. He said, `They do not quote that any more'. Let me tell the Senate and the Government why we do not quote that any more. Average Australian families cannot afford new cars and no-one has bothered to tell the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come off it.

—Senator Maguire says, `Come off it'. Why does he not go down to the car factories? Why does he not go down to Ford and find out how many days work it has lost? Why does he not go around to some of the motor vehicle yards and find out how many cars they cannot sell? Why does he not have a glance at a television station occasionally and find out that the new Ford advertisements state that Ford is selling cars at 1988 prices just to quit them? Senator McMullan has the audacity to say that we do not quote the figure any more. What is the point in quoting the figure any more? No-one can afford a motor vehicle. Come off the grass, get down to the reality of it. This is a very serious subject. There are people in Australia who are literally going broke at the rate of knots and Senator Maguire does not give a continental. The Government wheels Senator Maguire, Senator Loosley and Senator McMullan out every time there is an economic debate. We have heard Senator McMullan's contribution. It was nonsense the first time and it remains nonsense the twentieth time around because not a jot has changed.

SPEECH.PARA: It has become almost commonplace to state the simple fact that this Hawke Labor Government is no friend to small business. When is this Government going to realise the effects that it is having on the whole country? This Government cannot avoid the responsibility for the general mismanagement of the economy that is destroying well managed enterprises, and it is equally responsible for the burden of uncaring regulation that further reduces their chance of survival. But the Government does not tend to care about all of that. It adds more regulations and it adds more bureaucratic control over small business. Its attitude is: let us play the new game of watching them go to the wall and taking all their employees with them.

Only today we learned that investment in new capital equipment has fallen by 11 per cent and that expectations for the 1991-92 financial year have fallen by 14 per cent. Once again, Senator McMullan said something along the line that all the Opposition does is throw any old statistic around. He is dead right. I say this in his absence because he has taken off and cleared out of this chamber. We will throw many statistics around. It is not a case of throwing any old statistic around, it is a case of quoting new statistics provided by his Government. If he is saying they are wrong, then tell us why. Just one more straw in the wind giving its own rebuke of the quality of Labor's economic management-spelling not only reduced profits but ruin for small business-is those figures that I have already quoted about the new capital investment.

I make no apology for returning to the theme of bankruptcy statistics that are so strong an indicator of what the Government is doing to small business. Once again, Senator McMullan would just accuse us of throwing any old statistic around. I will throw this one at him. Last year there was a 32 per cent rise in bankruptcies overall and a 57 per cent jump in the December quarter. In Western Australia the rises were 64 per cent-precisely double the national average-and 89 per cent respectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty-nine per cent!

—Eighty-nine per cent in Western Australia, and here Senator McMullan, and probably Senator Maguire and Senator Loosley who are yet to come into this debate, will say we just throw any old statistic around. If they think that 89 per cent is any old statistic that they can just throw away, then they should stop and think about the number of people who have been affected by those increases in bankruptcies. Again, this means the loss of employee jobs and points to a far greater number of enterprises that have closed their doors long before going into bankruptcy. I might add also that this means a loss of an awful lot of capital and that is capital that is lost forevermore to this country and lost forevermore to other people. In 1989-90, with a total of 8,500 bankruptcies, such losses totalled $643m. But in 1990-91 we are going to be looking clearly at a much greater figure since bankruptcies for the December quarter alone were 3,117. That is just for one quarter. Yet the previous year there were 8,500 for a whole year.

SPEECH.PARA: Small businesses are stating quietly and factually that they are struggling with interest rates in this economic climate. Taxes and the abject failure of labour market reform have created a massive problem. Yet once again we had Senator McMullan saying earlier that the Government could not do anything about it as demand was growing at 8 per cent and output was growing at 4 per cent and that we chose to do nothing about it. To start with, we are not the Government; it is the Government's responsibility to do something about that. We have been maintaining for a very long time that we need dramatic productivity increases and that we must have those as part of any survival package for this country. Does the Government want to do that? No, because the Australian Council of Trade Unions-its political master-will not allow it to do that.

The Government has sought to bang on the head many productivity cases around this country-for instance, the Mudginberri case, the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd case and the SPC Ltd case-and it continues to do so. While it continues to do that it should expect to see more and more people out of business.

Sixty-five per cent of firms reported a decline in turnover in the December quarter in a Western Australian business opinion poll taken recently, with 62 per cent expecting a further decline. That demonstrates the level of objectivity and hope that these people have in the future. Yet, once again, Senator McMullan said that a consumption tax and a goods and services tax that we in the Liberal and National parties are advocating was `not going to enhance the living standards of ordinary Australians'. He sure has not come up with any ideas of his own.

Maybe the following quotes would be interesting to Senator McMullan: `A consumption tax would create the foundations for a more efficient system to promote stronger economic growth and higher living standards'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—I will read another one: `It will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly ridden wholesale tax, which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions and fails to tax the services sector' and also, `Any claim that the proposed consumption tax makes low income earners worse off is not true'.
—Who said that?

—That is a good question. It was not Dr Hewson or Senator Lewis; it was Mr Keating. Ever heard of him?-the world's worst Treasurer. Even he said on those three occasions-and that is by no means a comprehensive list of his quotes in support of a consumption tax-that such a tax would get rid of the inefficiency of the taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: Small business is uncompetitive, especially for exportation of its goods. This Government will not do a scrap about making sure that it becomes competitive. Ah no, the Government says that that is its problem. Yet we have said that as part of our goods and services tax all exports will be tax-exempt. It will be interesting to see what happens with this miraculous statement on Senator Button's portfolio that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is to make next week-if he bothers to look at the export of goods to make sure that they are exempt, in line with the Liberal-National coalition policy. But we will have to wait and see until Mr Hawke makes Senator Button's statement for him. That will be interesting to watch-even more interesting for Senator Button.

The Hawke Labor Government must also accept its full share of responsibility for the burden of compliance that shackles small business in good times and helps drive it under in bad times. This Government has created 22,000 new Acts and regulations during its term of office, adding to the estimated cost of paperwork for the business sector of between $4 billion and $8 billion. The total cost of compliance to business could run as high as $60 billion, or between 9 and 19 per cent of gross domestic product, tying up business capital. It is not good enough to have instituted a Business Regulation Review Unit when at the same time the regulations just churn out. There is no end to the regulations. But does that matter? No; the Government has set up a Regulation Review Unit. That puts the lid on that, supposedly. Australia is crying out for a true free enterprise approach to business regulation that will presume in favour of a free market unless shown otherwise, and that will insist that benefits exceed costs to business and to the community that depends upon small business.

How typical of this Labor Government that it forced through massive changes to corporate regulation last year without thought as to the added costs on smaller companies which must pay vastly increased costs if they want to issue a prospectus to raise needed capital. That is just the typical approach of this Government: put another noose around their neck, making it more difficult for them to do anything and more difficult for them to survive because, at the end of the day, we pay them all on the dole.

The Treasurer has retreated from his Budget surplus figures over the last week, which went from $8 billion to $1 billion in one statement and then, a week later, from $8 billion down to a negative-no surplus at all; a deficit. But does the Government worry about that? Did Senator McMullan mention it and will Senator Maguire and Senator Loosley mention it? No, because it does not matter.

The mere fact is that has come about because there is not enough tax coming from the business sector; there is not enough income tax coming from individuals who have lost their jobs and are on the dole, and therefore not paying tax; and there is not enough tax coming from goods that are sold because people cannot afford them. Senator McMullan said that we do not quote motor vehicles any more. We do not do so because none are being sold. That is why this deficit is likely to come about. We will wait and see whether Senator Maguire addresses that. I think I can predict his speech pretty accurately. As I say, I have heard it 20 times before. How typical also to have only reluctantly extended the deadline for the display of the new Australian company number on all documents, with the threat of fines and invalidation of the documents. It is more Big Brother coming in and putting the screws on.

The recession that the Treasurer said Australia `had to have' has worsened but not created the suffering that results when the small business sector is in trouble. We are in a depression; we are not in a recession. It has come as the last straw to many well-managed enterprises that could not be expected to cope with a succession of neglectful and harmful actions by a Labor Government whose deeds speak louder than its rhetoric. The Prime Minister should sack the Treasurer. If he has not got the courage to do that, the Treasurer should resign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis has submitted a matter of public importance on the economy which talks about the pain and suffering inflicted on families as a result of economic policies impacting on small business. Senator Lewis, a backbencher, was chosen by the Liberal Party to bring this matter forward this afternoon. He is not a frontbencher. It was not brought forward by Senator Short, for example, or Senator Parer, who are frontbenchers. Senator Lewis was chosen to lead the attack for the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis is not a good judge of the economy. He is not a good commentator on the economy. In fact, as recently as last month he made a major mistake in an economic speech in this place when, on 14 February, he claimed that the current rate of inflation was over 10.4 per cent. Senator Lewis followed me in a debate in this place in February and claimed that the annual rate of inflation was 10.4 per cent. That is what Senator Lewis, who submitted this matter of public importance today, claimed. In the very same speech, Senator Lewis went on to say that the rate of inflation was nearly 10.5 per cent. First of all he said it was over 10.4 per cent and then he said it was nearly 10.5 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both times wrong.

—That is right. I had a close and careful look at Senator Lewis's speech, which is recorded at page 633 of Hansard. After examining it for some time I thought that the only way I could come up with an inflation rate of over 10 per cent, given that that is not the case-the inflation rate is not 10 per cent-was to multiply the current quarterly figure of 2.7 by four; in other words, multiply the four quarters in the year by 2.7. That was the only way one could get an inflation rate of over 10 per cent. But of course four times 2.7 is not 10.4, and it is certainly not 10.5. It is a wrong analysis anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that we cannot measure inflation on an annual basis simply by multiplying a quarterly figure by four. That is the level of Liberal Party analysis. One cannot do that because seasonal factors apply at different times of the year. Some quarters are heavily affected by seasonal products such as fruit and vegetables; therefore, one cannot assume that factors in one quarter apply right throughout the year.

Senator Lewis's central error in that analysis-he was the person selected by the Liberal Party to lead the assault on the Government today on this matter of public importance-was that he forgot that that particular consumer price index for the December quarter included the impact of the petrol prices as a result of the Kuwait crisis. As we know, petrol prices have already come down substantially. In fact, I think the price of petrol in my local garage in Adelaide is lower now than it was before Iraq invaded Kuwait.

That really makes the point about how fallacious this analysis is by Senator Lewis, who, after all, was chosen to front this assault on the Government benches. The price of petrol has already come down. It has not been high for 12 months of the year. That exposes the problems of multiplying quarterly consumer price indexes by four to get annual rates.
Senator Walters also compounded that mistake on the Opposition benches by claiming that inflation was running at 10.8 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a mistake at all. That is the rate at which it is running.

—It is absolute rubbish; it is not. The price of petrol has already tangibly fallen. This is voodoo economics in the 1990s coming from the Liberal Party. Senator Walters at least got it right: she knew that when 2.7 is multiplied by four the result is 10.8. She got the number right. As I said, Senator Lewis said that it was above 10.4 and nearly 10.5. Senator Walters at least got the figure of 10.8 right. On the basis of that analysis, perhaps Senator Walters should have been chosen to lead this matter of public importance; at least she got the arithmetic right, although the substance and the facts were wrong. The annual rate of inflation in this country is not at 10.8, 10.5, 10.4, 9.8 or 8.8; it is in fact at 6.9 per cent. That rate has applied from December 1989 to December 1990. It compares enormously well with the previous Government's record.

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis of those errors made by Senator Lewis and Senator Walters, it is pretty clear that the Liberals are just not capable of getting the sums right. That is the reality of what we have seen this afternoon. The simple analysis is that they cannot get the sums right; therefore, they cannot be competent economic managers. Of course, they are clearly not fit to run the economy.

Australia has a 6.9 per cent inflation rate and this is vitally important to small business. During Question Time today Senator Button correctly pointed out that under the conservatives in Britain, for example, the inflation rate is at 9.9 per cent. If we want to see how the Liberal Party policies would work in practice, were the Liberals to get into power, we need only look at the British Conservative Party policies because that is the model that they seek to emulate. The United Kingdom has an inflation rate of 9.9 per cent. Australia is also doing relatively well on the inflation front-and that is good news for small business-when we compare our rate with the rates of the 23 industrialised countries that make up the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. The average inflation rate of those countries is 7.4 per cent-some half per cent above the Australian inflation rate.

I admit, as framed in this matter of public importance, that there is pain and suffering in some sectors of the economy. We do not deny that there is a recession. Sections of small business are clearly hurting. But I think it is very important to note that the current economic situation reflects policies which were in place some time ago. After all, there are substantial lead times in economics. Moving an economic lever today does not create an automatic response tomorrow. What we are now seeing in the economy reflects the policy settings of 1990 and 1989. The tight fiscal policies in 1988, 1989 and 1990 were not ends in themselves; they were policies put in place for a very good reason-to try to reduce the impact of the balance of payments constraints on the Australian economy; to try to reduce the spill-over into imports that had been occurring apace in the Australian economy. That is why those policies were put into place-to slow down growth and the leakage from our economy into imports. It is a very well documented linkage in economics.

Policies have been adjusted enormously since the beginning of 1990. Interest rates have been significantly cut on five occasions. For example, in February 1990 official cash interest rates were 18 per cent; the inter-bank rates were 18 per cent. Late in 1990 those rates had been relaxed to 13 per cent. So there was a five percentage points reduction in those inter-bank interest rates.

Over that period the Government also took action to lower the level of the Australian dollar-the exchange rate of our currency compared with other currencies. Early in 1990 the Australian dollar was high. That made some of our exports relatively uncompetitive. The Government intervened to take measures to lower the value of the Australian dollar so that our exports would be more competitive and our imports less competitive.

There has also been a new round of tax cuts under the new version of the accord with the trade union movement. In fact, on 1 January Australian employees received two rounds of tax cuts, an initial round being supplemented by an extra round on 1 January. The aim there is to keep down wage demands on employers, including small business employers, to enable them to compete better while boosting the after-tax disposable incomes of Australian workers. Those tax cuts, which will help living standards, will cost $1.7 billion in the current financial year. The savings will ultimately be spent in the shops. They will help boost sales, production and investment. In that way the income tax cuts will help boost small business activity.

Let us not forget that small business proprietors are taxpayers. These personal income tax reductions will benefit pro- prietors of small businesses who pay personal income tax. For example, a person with a taxable income of between $36,000 and $50,000 per annum will see his tax rate cut from 47c to 46c in the dollar.

TALK.START.PARA: —There won't be too many in that category.

—There are many in that category. They will also benefit from the increase in the amount of tax-free income, which applies to all taxpayers at present. They are some important things that have been happening.

SPEECH.PARA: In his matter of public importance, Senator Lewis talked about the pain and suffering inflicted on Australian families. I would like to know which families Senator Lewis is referring to. In May many Australian families will get a $12 wage rise from this Government as part of the wages and tax package worked out with the trade union movement. I would like to know here and now the Liberal Party's position on this $12 wage rise. I have asked this question in this chamber three times now and I still have not had a ringing endorsement from the Liberal Party saying that it will support this $12 wage rise. What are the Liberals doing about this flat wage rise, which will go to all taxpayers and which will, therefore, give relative benefits to the lower paid members of our work force? What is the Liberal Party's position on this $12 a week wage rise, which will clearly top up household disposable incomes?

What would happen under a Liberal government if ever there were to be one in Australia? Let us look at its policies. It is always talking about the need for a mini-Budget. Whether it is at the State level or the Federal level, Liberals always want mini-Budgets. Of course, in the Liberal Party, that mini-Budget idea is shorthand for expenditure cuts. To the Liberals, mini-Budgets equal expenditure cuts. But the Liberals cannot deliver the expenditure cuts. There is a big gap between rhetoric and reality.

Look at what happened in this place during the last session of Parliament. We proposed legislation to put an assets test on family allowances; the Liberals defeated that. We proposed to sell the Sydney-Moomba Pipeline Authority, which would have been a negative expenditure and would have had the same effect as an expenditure cut; the Liberals opposed that. The total of those two items amounted to $750m. That was the impact on this Budget as a result of the Opposition's policies. Yet the Opposition has the nerve to call for continued expenditure cuts. When it comes to the point of offering expenditure cuts, the Opposition walks away.

Despite the rhetoric, all we can say about the Liberal Party's fiscal policy, seeing that we can rule out expenditure cuts, is that it refers to the consumption tax proposal. This is the tax the Liberals want on almost everything in the Australian economy. They want a broad based tax on items of expenditure in the Australian economy. This really gets down to the whole idea of the Rolls Royce-led recovery. The Liberals are really on about trying to get economic recovery in this country by making luxury cars cheaper. That is what they are on about.

At present luxury cars attract a 50 per cent sales tax. Under the Liberal proposal, these luxury vehicles would be taxed at the general rate, the same rate as would apply to food and clothing, that is, probably in the vicinity of 15 per cent to 18 per cent. My calculations show that the price of a vehicle retailing at $97,000 would fall by $20,000 under the Liberal Party policy. That figure of $20,000 happens to be the typical income per family in South Australia at this point in time. In fact, the Liberal Party policy is proposing to reduce the price of luxury vehicles by an amount equivalent to the typical annual income of a family in one Australian State. These are the people who propose to restore Australia's health by a Rolls Royce-led recovery. These are the limousine Liberals who are out of touch with ordinary Australian people. They propose unfair and socially unjust policies. They would tax equally Mercedes and margarine, yoghurt and yachts and shoes and Saabs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

If Government senators had any influence at all, any concern about Australia, and any concern about the States, including Queensland, they would get the governments of the States I have mentioned to resign now before the real havoc occurs.

We are hurting and hurting badly. We have had eight years of mismanagement, of falling living standards and of reduced profitabilities, all hatched in a hotbed of hotchpotchness.
