TALK.START.PARA: —But they're supposed to represent the workers.

—As Senator Boswell says, they represent the workers. How could a worker possibly do that? But we have not got to the best part of it yet. Having miraculously got themselves to the conference, having paid the cost to get there and paid for their hotel room, they walk in through the front door and are asked for a $540 registration fee. The Government wants to consult with rural and remote Australia, it says; and it wants $540 for the benefit of sitting there and hearing five of its Ministers plus umpteen dozen Canberra public servants tell these people--
—Who arrive on a VIP.

—On a VIP aircraft-tell them what is wrong with the trucking industry and what is wrong with road freight. What the Government should be doing is consulting, asking those sorts of people. So things go on. What has the Government done in waterfront reform? It has done practically nothing except give everyone the whip hand in the last couple of days because Mr Hawke wants to announce something positive in his economic statement. He has said to the wharfies and the other people, `Get me an agreement within the next two days because I have to say something about it'. Nothing will happen but he wants to talk.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan talked about the intellectual arguments on unemployment and the economy. I say to him that the people who are losing their jobs and the small businesses that are going bankrupt every day are not interested in intellectual arguments. They are not interested in the rhetoric and the clever academic phrases about the economy. They have seen their life savings go down the gurgler. They have seen the tragedy that it brings personally when they are going out of work. Many people who have never been out of work in their lives, who have always had employment-40-year-olds and 50-year-olds-are suddenly out of work. They are not impressed with the intellectual arguments and the smart figures that are thrown around. They know what is happening and they know that it is this Government that has brought this about. One does not have to be a professor of economics to work that out. One needs only to get out there and ask them. The Liberal and National parties have at least done that. We have got out and listened to people. It is obvious from the rubbish that, I say with respect, Senator Maguire gave us a minute ago that he has not been out amongst real small business where people are really hurting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell them about Saturday night when no Labor Party person turned up.

—We had another conference where we wanted people to give an explanation of their problems to politicians generally-the Government in particular. Does anybody know how many Labor politicians were there? The Mayor of Townsville, who has nothing to do with it anyway, was there. Mr Brown and Mr Hamill were not there. All the senior Australian Labor Party politicians stayed away in droves. The meeting was held in Townsville and not even the local member had the intestinal fortitude or interest to attend. So these suggestions of intellectual arguments mean nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the chamber would encourage people to work. I do not blame many of the people who are out of work and could get work but do not try and instead go on the pension, because they get more money doing that than they do when they are working. This is because we as a society-and this Government over the last eight years-have made it more profitable for people to be on the dole than to work. What we have to do is to give people the incentive to work so that they want to work and do not want to be on the unemployment list. We have to discourage those people who deliberately do not work because they are encouraged not to.

We have to reduce tax. We have to get tax from the avoiders. The Australian Labor Party supports the avoiders because it does not want a goods and services tax; that would get to the black market economy. Those opposite are now opposed to that. They recognised this argument some years ago, but now they have forgotten the black market that would be taxed with this. They are the friends of the tax avoiders.

Let me state very briefly some of the things that the Opposition would do. We would reform work practices, reform labour and encourage productivity. Since SPC Ltd has effected a half-hearted enterprise agreement, its productivity has increased 48 per cent. When questioned about it, it said that was only the tip of the iceberg. It was proved in Queensland with the voluntary employment agreements when productivity went up and up, and the Government has thrown it all away. It has an opportunity to do something about it. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is not trusted any more, but the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is going to make a great economic statement in a few days time. I ask those opposite to tell him not to tamper with the words; tell him not to fiddle around the edges; tell him to do something positive, realistic and meaningful to fix the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Resign.

—That is probably the easiest way to do it-for the Government to resign. Real incomes for rural people-and farmers are small businessmen-will fall by 67 per cent this year. So it goes on. I have the statistics on bankruptcies and unemployment in Queensland, where I come from. They are running at enormous rates in north Queensland. In my area the newspaper said, even back in November, that this year is set to be the worst year for bankruptcies in north Queensland since records were first kept in 1930. That is a throwaway statistic. All the statistics are there. I do not have time to read them into the record, but everybody knows them. This has had an effect on families. The small businesses have failed, families have suffered and houses have been repossessed. People in rural areas which have no schools and who have sent their children away to school have had to drag them out of school. Anyone with any connection with those sorts of people will know the absolute trauma that that has on that family-on the parents for having to do it and on the children for being brought out of the schools. There have been record repossessions of motor vehicles. Families have been uprooted from their normal way of living and have moved to other towns in search of work. People's self-respect has gone, marriages have broken down, there have been health problems and life savings have beenruined-all because of the economic effect of this Government's policy on small business.

SPEECH.PARA: I say again that if the Government has any sensitivity at all about this situation, if it wants to correct it, it should resign or take the opportunity in the next few days to say something positive and meaningful in the forthcoming economic statement. It should not fiddle with the edges. It should not give the smart, intellectual clevernesses that we have had from the other side in this debate. It should get down to it and do the real things that will correct Australia's problems. If it cannot handle the real reform, it should do the right thing by Australia and resign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the matter of public importance this afternoon is akin to a re-run of the debate in this chamber in the last sitting week. A proposition was advanced by Senator Short which related to the economy, but similar conclusions could be drawn about the lack of meaningful contribution that has been evidenced by the Opposition. In the debate last week, as again was the case this afternoon, we saw absolutely nothing advanced which would in any way suggest a policy framework from the Liberal and National parties. Again we have heard nothing but simple rhetorical expressions. A handful of slogans have been bandied around and a few cheap shots have been taken, but nowhere in any of the contributions have we seen anything that approximates a policy alternative. Nothing that has been suggested from the opposite side of the chamber can in any way pass for a serious contribution to the making of public policy in Australia at the moment. There has been an analysis which is entirely lacking, and it leads me to conclude again that the Opposition parties simply lack credibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot let a couple of Senator Macdonald's recent observations go without response. He made the claim-unsubstantiated and devoid of evidence-that people preferred unemployment and the resultant social security benefit to working. That is a simple expression of prejudice. There was no evidence advanced to support that. Senator Macdonald is simply being derogatory towards working people. That is the appropriate response to that prejudice. In terms of tax avoidance the outrageous claim made by those opposite that this Government has not cracked down on the tax avoidance industry cannot go unchallenged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly from someone who opposes a capital gains tax.

—Particularly, as Senator McMullan interjects, appropriately, from someone who has expressed opposition to capital gains taxes, which is one of the fairer means of tax collection-particularly from someone who comes from a political party or part of a coalition that presided over the great explosion in tax avoidance and tax evasion in this country during the latter part of the 1970s and early 1980s, when Barwick was Chief Justice of the High Court and Howard was Treasurer: the great period of bottom of the harbour schemes, which the Opposition now conveniently forgets. One of the things that is evident in this country now, in terms of a debate on public policy, is the total absence of an institutional memory opposite; there is no collective response--
—Are you going to support the GST?

—No, we will not support the goods and services tax. I am delighted that Senator Macdonald has raised the issue of the consumption tax because, come the time of the next election, that is going to be one of the great issues that divide us and on which the Opposition will be judged. It will not be a judgment that will in any way be favourable to it. This afternoon, the Opposition has given us all the reasons supposedly why Bjelke-Petersen should still be the Premier of Queensland. We heard that from honourable senators opposite. Senator Jones heard it. Senator McMullan heard it.
—But we didn't believe it.

—No-one opposite could believe that the Goss Government can in no way measure up to the fine record of Bjelke-Petersen! I thought that Bjelke-Petersen did as much damage to the honourable senator's Party and to the democratic processes as he endeavoured to do to us. I would be very interested to hear the honourable senator say at home, `Bring back Joh'.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macdonald says that he opposes the capital gains tax, and presumably those opposite oppose it. Why should they oppose it? For what possible reason? Why should they oppose not only the introduction of a capital gains tax by this Government but also the regular implementation of it? Unlike the consumption tax, which has been embraced enthusiastically by Mr Reith and our opponents, the capital gains tax is both effective and fair. Unlike the consumption tax, which the Opposition embraces now as holy writ-it will be discarded at some stage but, currently, for the purpose of debate, the Opposition embraces it and speaks of it as holy writ-the capital gains tax can be defended on the grounds of equity; it is paid on profits. The tax is paid on the basis of income. Unlike the consumption tax, which the Opposition has embraced and which it trumpets, capital gains tax is not inflationary and, unlike the consumption tax, which the Opposition trumpets in this chamber, it is a conscionable way for tax revenue to be collected in the interests of the community.

Let us look at another part of the conservative manifesto. We hear from those opposite a lot about pain. I am always interested to hear from the tories about pain-always. In terms of cuts in expenditure, who would find that painful? Let us stop and ask ourselves: who would find painful the $3 billion that Peter Reith is forever saying will be cut from the Federal Budget, especially now, as has been made absolutely and utterly clear to all concerned, that at least half of that $3 billion would come out of social security? As Senator Richardson made clear at Question Time today, there would be a lot of people below the poverty line who would find that extremely painful. I do not expect in any way to have an intelligent response from anyone opposite to the thought that people on social security might be spared pain as public policy; I do not expect that form of intelligent response in any respect from the Opposition. But the Australian people will know precisely how to make an appropriate judgment on that as policy: at least half of that $3 billion is to come from the social security budget.

Let us look at questions of fiscal policy and compare seven years of tory government under Fraser and seven years of Labor government. We inherited a $9 billion deficit-nine thousand million dollars Australian. That was the Opposition's record. The reason that we continue to talk about it is that the Opposition should never be allowed to forget it, and neither should the Australian people. That is the Opposition's record and monument as far as fiscal policy is concerned.

Do we call the current conservative manifesto Reaganite or Thatcherite? Those opposite enjoy both terms. Both, of course, are now discredited in their countries of origin, the United States and the United Kingdom. Or do we call the Opposition's manifesto voodoo economics or zombie economics, because either term is appropriate? We can take our choice on that.

In terms of Senator McMullan's contribution, I was pleased that he quoted from Robert Reich's article `The real economy' in the Atlantic Monthly because there were some very important points made in that article, particularly in respect of public investment in infrastructure. Again, there is not a constructive or positive word from those opposite on matters of public infrastructure, aside from a recent endeavour to abuse people in the public sector. I quote from the Reich piece in terms of the transportation network in the United States:

In the early 1960s the United States began building a modern transportation system. Spending on infrastructure at all levels of government then absorbed almost four per cent of the nation's GNP; it held that position through the 1960s. That's when we-
referring to the Americans, of course-

began to build the interstate highway system, for example. The productivity of the American work force soared. But the growth of public spending on the nation's transportation system declined throughout the 1970s, just as our productivity growth declined. Infrastructure spending declined even more sharply in the 1980s-
we are dealing here with the Reagan period, of course-

to the point where the nation was spending only two per cent of GNP on building and maintaining infrastructure. Hence the spectre of collapsing bridges, crumbling highways, and rush-hour traffic jams extending for miles.

Although part of the decline in spending represents a failure to maintain existing infrastructure, spending on new infrastructure has fallen even more dramatically, from 2.3 per cent of GNP in 1963 to only one per cent in 1989. As Western Europe and Japan lay plans for `smart' roads, high-speed trains, and national information networks, America lies dormant; the nation has not even built a new airport since 1974.

That in very large measure is the Reaganite legacy. Those opposite would cut $3,000m more from the Federal Budget, with a consequent impact on public investment and on infrastructure. Senator McMullan drew the intelligent link between public expenditure and productivity; it needed only that by way of reinforcement.

One of the key elements missing from those opposite-we did not hear it on the debate on Senator Short's proposition a week or so ago; we have not heard it this afternoon-is what the coalition embraces by way of a wages policy, because none exists. There is no framework for a wages policy; that was the great failing when the Opposition was last in power. It is the great failing now. No-one on the Opposition benches has produced anything that remotely resembles something that is workable in the industrial relations framework, be it a theoretical framework, about which those opposite speak, or the realistic framework, through the Industrial Relations Commission, that exists in Australia at the moment. Those opposite cannot try to pass off their rhetorical flourishes for a wages policy. The employer organisations-the Confederation of Australia Industry and the Business Council of Australia-and the Australian Council of Trade Unions are realities. The industrial relations system in this country is a reality. Rhetoric will not get the Opposition home. John Howard talks about lengthening the working week; that is not a policy. No-one is going to endorse that-not at an electoral level and not in terms of public policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't know about that.

—I would be delighted if the Opposition were to put us to the test on that by going to a poll promising to lengthen the working week; we would go to a poll committed to an orderly, predictable and stable industrial relations framework. I would be delighted if the coalition were to go to the next general election in favour of a longer working week. It would be the first time since the 1920s that the conservatives have endeavoured to lengthen the working week. The conservatives will not go to the polls on that. The silence of honourable senators opposite graphically illustrates that because they know that it will be abandoned; there is nothing more certain.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development figures for wages progressions during the course of the coming year we can see that Australia is doing relatively better than the United States of America, the United Kingdom or most of the other industrial nations grouped under the OECD. Senator Cook made that clear at Question Time a week or so ago.

It is absolutely and utterly comical when the Opposition suggests that there should be a degree of bipartisanship on economic policy and that, if only we were to implement its manifesto, it would be supportive. Let us look at an area where there should be a real degree of bipartisanship. I refer to the trade mission to the United States which is proposed-in my view properly-to comprise representation from the three major parties represented in the Federal Parliament, both at front bench and back bench levels. The Opposition cannot even get its act together on this; it cannot even propose a delegation without an internal row and some kind of public disagreement with the Government.

Senator Evans has just entered the chamber. I do not think he would disagree when I say that one of the great issues confronting this Parliament at the moment is the trading circumstance, the need to revive the Uruguay Round and to deal, under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, not only with our trading circumstance but also with the tariff barriers erected in western Europe, with the American exporting enhancement program and with some of the other problems that confront us in this area. There are very few things which are more difficult, more vexed and which convey a greater sense of urgency to those engaged in public policy in this country. However, instead of a policy framework, we have stunts. I do nothing more than quote from Laurie Oakes's column last week in the Bulletin entitled `Birth of a stunt merchant'. It reads in part:
. . . with the introduction of television to the House of Representatives, Hewson. . .
as in Dr Hewson-

has shown himself to be a stunt merchant. In the process, he has demeaned the Parliament. He has demonstrated that those who feared television would lead to a decline in parliamentary behaviour, not an improvement, had reason to be concerned. And his performance has aroused a suspicion in the minds of some that this former professor of economics may not have quite the depth which most of us had assumed.
There is no depth in the Leader of the Opposition because there is no depth in the parties that make up the coalition.

Whenever we are called on to debate any economic policies, the response of the Australia Labor Party (ALP) is normally a trip down memory lane-how bad it was in the Menzies era, the McEwen era or the Fraser era. But where is the vision of the Labor Party? Where is it going to? Where is it taking us? Where is the future? The Labor Party refuses ever to debate that. In fact, the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) has on many occasions had the right to put his Government's proposals before this Senate but he has never done so. He cannot defend the indefensible and sends Senator McMullan to do the job for him-a kamikaze pilot on a suicide mission.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter of public importance refers to the on-going pain and suffering inflicted on families. I can tell honourable senators that in 1983 there was a bump in the economy-but what we are seeing now is a great crater in the economy. Honourable senators opposite do not have anyone on their side to explain to them what is happening. I do not think anyone on that side of the House really understands what is happening out there in rural Australia and in small business Australia.

On Saturday night Senator Macdonald and I were at a trucking meeting which was attended by 400 people. If they did so, they would see exactly how hard people are hurting up there. However, honourable senators opposite will not do so. TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reynolds?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) relating to the Gulf crisis, and to move a motion relating to the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, the Gulf crisis has been the subject of great debate in the Senate and of profound interest across Australia. I therefore think it appropriate that the Government should report to the Senate and to the nation on the outcome of the multinational effort to free Kuwait, on what that achievement means, and on what remains to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will know that allied military operations under resolution 678 have been outstandingly successful; they have achieved their objectives more quickly than expected, and with very few losses to allied forces. This is a cause for great relief.
Australia's task force in the Gulf played a significant role in these operations, in cooperation with the forces of many other nations. We are proud of their contribution.
Discussions are now under way to achieve a permanent cease-fire and a definitive end to the conflict under conditions laid down by the United Nations (UN) Security Council last weekend.

Proud and relieved as we are, this is not a time solely for rejoicing. Kuwait and its people have suffered grievously in the months since 2 August last year. And Iraq's people have suffered great devastation and loss. The Government has said throughout this crisis that we have no quarrel with the people of Iraq, but only with the brutal and dictatorial regime which has imposed on them, as on Kuwait, so much suffering.

With our allies we sought to avoid using armed force by all means possible. We only accepted the need to fight when it became clear that there was no other way to reverse the aggression of Saddam Hussein and to free Kuwait. But from the start of this crisis we have understood that the issues at stake were so grave that if all else failed, the world would be justified in using armed force to resolve it.
We were concerned for the people of Kuwait and for the future of the Middle East, and we were concerned for the economic consequences of a world oil market dominated by Saddam Hussein.
But above all, we were concerned for the challenge that Saddam Hussein's invasion and attempted elimination of Kuwait posed to the international community.

It challenged each of us, as nations and as individuals, to balance our repugnance for war against our commitment to peace. It has forced us to study again the lessons of 50 years ago: that peace is bought at too high a price if that price is the appeasement of aggression.

In these aspects the Gulf crisis has drawn significance not just from the specific circumstances of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, but also from the great historical event of our own time; the end of the Cold War.
The Gulf crisis has been the crucial test of the world's hopes that, with the end of the Cold War, the United Nations would at last be allowed to fulfil the expectations of its founders.

Madam Acting Deputy President, our hopes have been fulfilled by a great victory. We do not speak here of the military victory by the forces of the coalition-for military victory, however sweeping, must always be shadowed with the tragedy of those who have fallen on both sides.
The great victory in the Gulf has been won by the international community, and by the United Nations itself.

At every step since 2 August 1990, the Security Council has focused the international response to Iraq's invasion. The Security Council condemned Iraq's invasion, it imposed economic sanctions, it authorised the use of force, and finally, last weekend, it stipulated the conditions for a cessation of hostilities.
These actions by the Security Council reflect the overwhelming consensus of the international community about the nature of Iraq's actions, and about the means to address them.

The members of the Security Council-nations large and small, developed and developing, drawn from every region of the globe-have truly represented the world's opinion that Saddam Hussein must not prevail.

Many nations joined in the military operations under the Security Council's authority. Pre-eminent among them has been the United States (US), which has used its power and influence with courage and generosity to serve interests which the United States shares with all the world.

But the coalition also included Arab nations such as Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Syria; European nations including France, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and Italy; and more distant nations like Canada, who understood, as we did, that the stakes in this crisis had no geographical boundaries. We owe thanks to all our allies in this endeavour.

Madam Acting Deputy President, the Senate has expressed its support for the United Nations position on the Gulf crisis in a series of debates and resolutions. The Government has been grateful for the support of the Opposition on this vital issue. A decision to deploy forces to combat is the hardest decision a government can take, and we are grateful for the intelligent, principled and conscientious support we have received from this Parliament.

In the last resort, this Parliament and this nation were prepared to meet the aggressor's challenge; we were willing to go to war, but only to preserve peace. With the overwhelming support of their country behind them, ships and personnel of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) were sent to the Gulf to help enforce sanctions and, later, to participate in operations under resolution 678 to expel Iraq from Kuwait.

The heart of our contribution to the multinational military effort in the Gulf has been a naval task group of three ships: initially HMAS Adelaide, Darwin and Success; now HMAS Sydney, Brisbane and Westralia. The task force has also included a clearance diving team to help deal with the threat from mines.

They have all acquitted themselves honourably. They have earned the respect of their coalition partners in the multinational force for their skills and capabilities. Make no mistake, although our ships have not been direct participants in offensive action, they have played critical and hazardous roles. They played their part in turning back Saddam Hussein.
They have been operating, and continue to operate, in a dangerous environment, and we are very fortunate, and very grateful, that they have taken no casualties.

Elsewhere in the Gulf we have had service personnel serving on exchange with allied forces, and up to 40 medical personnel serving on the US hospital ship Comfort. These people-including a number of reservists-have earned the respect of their colleagues and our gratitude for their service.

The Government has decided to recognise the special service of those who have served in the Gulf since the commencement of allied military action on 17 January by authorising the award of the Australian Active Service Medal, bearing the clasp `Kuwait', to members of the ADF deployed in the Gulf on or after 17 January 1991.

The award of the Active Service Medal provides due recognition of the service given by Australian Defence Force members during this conflict. It will be worn with pride by all who receive it-and rightly so. The Australians who have served in the Gulf have done honour to themselves, their service and their country. We now may honour them in return.

Our servicemen and women in the Gulf were supported in Australia by the work of many other members of the ADF, by contractors and by other government agencies. The Government's response to the crisis has been assisted in demanding circumstances by the Office of National Assessments, Defence Intelligence Organisation, Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade-I interpolate to pay particular tribute to my own officers, led by Mr Rick Smith, for their supreme and sterling efforts throughout the duration of this crisis-Defence and Prime Minister and Cabinet, and by many other State and Federal agencies. They have our thanks.

Let me also pay tribute here to the staff of Australia's embassies in the region, who have accepted serious risks in staying at their posts to help Australian citizens, protect Australian interests, and represent Australian views.
We look forward to bringing home our forces in the Gulf as soon as possible. This will be done in accordance with the decisions and requirements of the UN Security Council.

Madam Acting Deputy President, although the war itself is we hope over, there clearly remains much to be done before peace can be restored to the Gulf region. First we need to establish the short and long term security of Kuwait and other nations in the Gulf region, and also undertake the reconstruction of Iraq and Kuwait-including addressing the humanitarian needs of the innocent victims of Saddam's aggression, even among his own people. We are pleased to see that humanitarian considerations are being taken into account in the administration of the United Nations' economic sanctions still in place against Iraq.
How these tasks will be achieved depends largely on how things unfold in the Gulf in the coming weeks and months.

Beyond these issues lies the fundamental need to address the longstanding problems of the Middle East. Since the start of the Gulf crisis this Government has been concerned to see whether a solution to the invasion of Kuwait could not become a catalyst for solutions to the deep-seated tensions in the region; in particular the future of the Palestinians, the security of Israel, and the struggle to implement a settlement in Lebanon.

There is cause to hope that the spirit of cooperation which has seen the Arab members of the coalition and Israel acknowledge, even if only tacitly, their common interest in confronting Saddam Hussein, may pave the way for a broader understanding of the possibilities of cooperation.

But there should be no illusions about the difficulty of finding solutions to these problems. The leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organisation, by its support for Saddam Hussein, has gravely damaged its credibility internationally. But the voice of the Palestinians must still be heard.
And Israel, which during this war displayed admirable restraint against unprovoked aggression, may in some ways be more receptive to the logic of a settlement, but in other respects less so.
We will do what we can to assist the resolution of these tragic problems, and to help reduce the chances of future conflicts by supporting regional and global arms control measures.

Australia has important trade interests in the Middle East, including in the Gulf. A central element of our policy will be to facilitate the resumption and development of that trade. The Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Dr Blewett, will lead a trade delegation to the Gulf region next week, and we will appoint a senior officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade at the rank of Ambassador to coordinate the Government's Middle East trade strategy. We are also examining the establishment of a new diplomatic mission in the Gulf region.

I want to turn lastly to the new world order. The phrase has been much discussed in recent months. Most of what has been said has missed the fundamental point that the end of the Cold War has ushered in a new world order whether we like it or not.

The question we face is not whether we want a new world order or not; it is what kind of world we want. In every field of international relations-strategic, economic, ecological-the challenge of the 1990s is to define how the nations of the world will cooperate in the years ahead. The special importance of the Gulf crisis has been the chance it has given us to define the shape of this new order in the field of international security.

No-one believes that the world will be free of war and suffering but, because the world responded as it did to the invasion of Kuwait by Saddam Hussein, the new order will be one in which would-be aggressors will think twice before invading smaller neighbours; in which smaller nations feel more secure because they know that they will not stand alone if they are threatened; and in which all nations should know that the rule of law must prevail over the rule of force in international relations. That does not make the new world order any kind of utopia but it does make the world a much safer place than it would have been had Saddam Hussein's aggression been rewarded by his being allowed to keep Kuwait as the nineteenth province of Iraq.

That is in itself a great achievement. This Government, this Parliament and this nation can be proud of the part we played in bringing it about and, perhaps even more, this conflict, brought as it has been so immediately and dramatically into our homes by television, may demonstrate the ultimate horror of war, its necessity as a last resort against perverse and evil leaders not masking the human degradation that war involves.

If nations, if men and women who can influence the decisions of their leaders, have learned this lesson, then we will not just have made the world a safer but indeed a better place, a place where the resources of mankind may, with security, be directed less to the means of their destruction, but rather to the uplifting of those in need around the globe. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We in the Opposition welcome the Prime Minister's statement and, even more so, we welcome the end of the war. I take this opportunity to commend the courage and skill of Australian service men and women who served during this conflict. They performed at a standard commensurate with the high reputation of the Australian defence forces. In thanking them we also acknowledge the support and commitment of their families who had to bear the anxious days, weeks and months that their loved ones were at risk in the service of their country.

SPEECH.PARA: We also want to take this opportunity to commend the leadership of the alliance, particularly President Bush who remained firm and consistent throughout. He managed to find that which is rare-the correct balance between force and restraint, which kept maximum pressure on the opposing force while always providing an opportunity for Saddam Hussein to meet the United Nations (UN) resolutions and to withdraw without his people having to suffer any further. We also commend Prime Minister John Major of the United Kingdom who acquitted himself ably, and clearly the leadership of Britain remains in good hands.

The fact that the political leadership of the alliance, and indeed its military leadership, performed so ably in this conflict we all recognise as a positive sign for the future. This is some comfort as the world moves into a period which may well be marked by considerable instability. It was not long ago that we were talking about peace dividends being paid. It has now been clearly demonstrated that that was a little optimistic.

The much-vaunted new world order which was to follow the disorder of the Cold War was clearly also a trifle premature. However, it is interesting to note that some, even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his statement today, are trying to explain it in terms of not necessarily a new stability, but of there having to be a new world order after an old world order. With great respect to the Prime Minister, that seems to be a case of some recent thinking. It was not long ago that certainly the international community was talking of a new world order that provided greater stability and security than in the past.

There are some positive aspects that have come out of this conflict which, like all wars, was horrible and wasteful, no matter how just it might have been. I have mentioned the leadership of the West. It seems that we are now in a period of able leadership. The fact that some 30 nations were joined together under arms to enforce the United Nations resolution is a unique experience of collective security and it can give us some hope for the future. The fact that the United Nations could with such unanimity resolve to oppose the aggression is in itself a reason for cautious hope. I have always thought of the United Nations simply as a reflection of the resolve of the international community. It demonstrates some chance that the international community may be prepared to use the body in a way closer to that which was originally envisaged.

The support of the Soviet Union was vital to the alliance. Clearly the Soviet Union and its leadership did not find it an easy issue to stand up against a long term ally worried about the Islamic instability on its border but, nevertheless, with some wavering, it stuck. That must represent a hope for the future.

The reward was achieved for defence preparedness, technological edge and superior training. It all paid off and that should be a lesson to us now. Investment in adequate defence security is still a good investment. Investment in alliances still appears to be as important as ever. There is also some new modest, cautious hope in that forces of the West and the Arab nations were prepared to work together to repel an aggressor. That could all easily change very quickly but for now it is a positive sign and a moment that should not be lost.

It leads us to address the challenges that lie ahead-how best to heal wounds, how best to seize new opportunities, and how best to work for greater stability and security than existed before the conflict. I will not try to say that Secretary of State Baker has a harder job than General Schwarzkopf but securing the peace might turn out to be a more difficult challenge than winning the war.

It is a pity that as yet not a lot of ideas have come out of Australia on this issue. I remember in the earlier Gulf debate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) said that constructive thought for the future would come in due course, but not a lot of thought has come yet. Certainly I invite the Australian Government to seek to make a positive contribution in creative thought, because nobody has a mortgage on all knowledge in this area and there is a role that Australia can play.

Iraq's offensive capacity, it seems to me, has been largely destroyed. It will be some time before it can again threaten its neighbours. There is, however, an apparent political vacuum, which I feared and mentioned in the previous Gulf debate. It was probably unavoidable with Saddam Hussein having been so devastated. Internal revolution is likely and appears in some ways to have already commenced. A Shi'ite fundamentalist regime should not be regarded as unlikely. I note the latest press reports that the Kurds are also looking to seize their opportunity in the north. That should not surprise anyone when we reflect on the awful experiences that they have suffered in the past.

Certainly, this vacuum raises new issues and indicates that the war in itself will not necessarily lead to a situation of greater stability and security. While Saddam Hussein was lobbing scuds on Israel he was a hero to many Arabs and, in fact, many Muslims in places as far away as Pakistan, Bangladesh and even Malaysia. I was in Pakistan at the outbreak of the war and I experienced some of that sentiment myself. But he failed so badly in the end that I suspect his memory will quickly fade. The underlying resentment, oppression, inequality and exploitation felt by so many Arab people and so many Muslims, however, will not so quickly fade and must be addressed. It is so important, therefore, that the victors-in particular, the United States-do not now act as an imperialist power. They must be sensitive to these deep feelings of distrust if a new order based on political solutions rather than just military victories is to evolve.

Two objectives are clear. First, there must be improved Gulf security guaranteeing that the weaker oil rich States will not be threatened by their more powerful neighbours. Secondly, there must be improved security throughout the wider Middle East region, which necessarily raises the question of the relationship between Israel and its neighbours which, in turn, is linked to the Palestinian issue. These two objectives are not totally unrelated. The accommodations and agreements reached in relation to Gulf security issues will unavoidably reflect understanding about the way in which wider security issues will be handled.

I turn briefly to the first objective: the establishment of a credible Gulf security arrangement. Despite calls for Arab solutions and Arab security, Saudi Arabia and the Gulf emirates are likely to want to negotiate security guarantees with the United States. The United States is likely to accommodate those wishes, recognising that in such bilateral agreements they would best protect their own interests in maintaining oil supplies without having again to mount an enormously costly and difficult intervention as has been necessary to recover Kuwait.

There is not likely to be any function appropriate for Australia in such a security guarantee, although the United States might seek to share the responsibility with a few major European powers. The United States guarantee would more likely be enforced by an ongoing maritime presence, increased intelligence facilities and perhaps improved airfields and security arrangements for rapid deployment. Any significant long term on the ground military presence would be counterproductive to building confidence in the wider Arab world, and statements from the United States to date appear to indicate that that fact is recognised.

With regard to the immediate security of Kuwait during the process of rebuilding, it seems to me that this would be an appropriate function for a United Nations peacekeeping force under UN command. The UN could meet this function and would be less likely to raise the sensitivities of states such as Iran than the alliance force would do. There might be a useful role for Australia in this objective, bearing in mind our historical contribution to UN forces in the Middle East. I refer not only to UN forces but also to others. I remember the multilateral force serving in the Sinai which helped maintain the one peace treaty in the Middle East that stands today. I regret that it seems that Mr Hawke did not cover this potential for Australia contributing in this way in his address to the Parliament. I hope that that does not mean that the Labor Government has prematurely ruled out an Australian contribution in this way.

The alliance force is likely to remain, I presume for some little time, in and around Iraq-at least until peace has been guaranteed. Subject to what might happen within Iraq, it seems to me that it would be better if it was then withdrawn and disbanded, having served its purpose. Economic sanctions should be lifted as soon as the Security Council resolutions are satisfied and thus the objective of the alliance in relation to enforcement of sanctions would have been achieved. I see no reason for such sanctions to be maintained for an unnecessarily long period. I cannot see, for example, realistically how they would help with reparations.

Australia should take an interest in the process of the reconstruction of Kuwait and, I would argue, even Iraq. There is no doubt that our friends and allies will seize this opportunity to advance their interests, and Australia's markets of the past will not be guaranteed by our contribution to the alliance or our previous good trading relationship with Iraq. I note that the Prime Minister's statement refers to a trade mission to be led by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Dr Blewett, and I wish him well, but I have to say that the Government's record in relation to Middle East trade, particularly when I reflect upon what I can only describe as its incompetent handling of the live sheep issue, has not been good. I note also that we are now going to set up some missions in the Gulf states. I remind the Senate that it was only a few years ago that Australia was withdrawing its trade representatives from the Gulf states to Riyadh. It now seems that a lesson has been learned and that they will be returned to the Gulf. I notice also from the Prime Minister's statement that we are going to have someone of ambassadorial rank to coordinate our trade projects. Whilst I would not want to refer to that as gimmicky, because any effort is worth while, I think that something of greater substance will be necessary to protect and develop Australia's interests.

The second objective that I mentioned was a wider Middle East security, which is, of course, a more difficult objective. In some ways, Egypt has emerged with enhanced credit but it is economically impoverished, dependent on United States aid and will not easily be given the mantle of leader even of the more moderate States in a deeply divided Arab world.

Syria is stronger as a result of the war. President Assad may want to exert influence on the rebuilding of Iraq but he may trade that for further concessions in Lebanon. Whilst one is pleased about any peace in Lebanon, it seems that peace has come at the cost of effective control by Syria. One remembers, of course, the historic claim of Syria to Lebanon as part of Greater Syria. Syria wants Israel out of the Israeli security zone in southern Lebanon, and perhaps it is prepared to forfeit its claim to the Golan Heights to achieve that objective. The objective for Israel would be Syrian guarantees of an end to the Palestinian incursions. It is not inappropriate to say that it is fascinating to note the growing accommodation between Israel and Syria-traditional enemies-and it will be interesting to see how that develops. If it can develop to at least a more peaceful relationship than has existed in the past, then that is a positive achievement.

Jordan looks decidedly shaky in this evolving power play. Already some Israelis are again referring to Jordan as Palestine. The Jordanians are also mindful of the historical claim made by Syria on Jordan not dissimilar to the claim that was made by Iraq in relation to Kuwait; that is, as a post-colonial successor to a unit of the dismembered Ottoman Empire.

Israel holds renewed influence in the United States and enhanced influence in Europe. It will not, however, sacrifice security for peace. The restraint shown by Israel has introduced for the first time a sign that Israel can accept that its security interests may sometimes be best served by showing trust in other parties. It is a sign of hope when one tries to envisage a plan which will provide for an internationally guaranteed peace in the region. However, it does not, I regret, hold out much hope for the Palestinians, at least in the short to medium term. The Palestinians have lost a major backer in Iraq. Their leadership is discredited in the eyes of the West, financial sources such as Saudi Arabia and the Gulf emirates and political supporters such as Egypt. The best a moderate Palestinian leadership will be able to negotiate with Prime Minister Shamir for the foreseeable future, it seems to me, is some increased autonomy in the occupied territories, and even they would be now very difficult negotiations.

It will not satisfy the Palestinians. It is not a homeland. As this conflict has shown, long term gains in the Middle East in the current world situation will only come out of peace; they will not come out of force. One thinks of Egypt getting back the Sinai as just one example. Therefore, if in such circumstances there can grow some increased confidence between a moderate Palestinian leadership and Israel, there can be some hope for the Palestinian people in their aspirations in the longer term.

In such circumstances, it seems to me that it would be difficult to see what positive measures could come out of an international conference on Palestine at this time. Again, I note that the Prime Minister's statement was silent on that issue. I hope that that does not demonstrate that he is sitting on the fence. It is an important issue upon which Australia should have a view, and we have the right to expect that view to be expressed by the Prime Minister.

I suggested in the previous Gulf debate that perhaps the United Nations working group or a representative of the Security Council would be better to explore whether the Gulf experience has freed up any of the previous fixed positions. I think that might be a more constructive way to go-to look to an improvement of relations between Palestine and Israel-than an international conference, at least at this time. I am afraid I see it as a long, slow process. Orthodox thinking has been that there will be no further peace agreements with Israel without first a resolution of the Palestinian issue.

That might be so, but one can now see at least the chance of a less antagonistic relationship with some Arab states. As I indicated a moment ago, for those of us who see confidence building as important, particularly in this region, that would at least be positive. In part, it will depend on the Arab organisations, and organisations such as the Arab League are extremely divided at the moment and even reuniting such organisations will be a slow and painful process.

A peace would make supplementary objectives, such as a determination to avoid an arms build-up in the region, more achievable. The lessons of the West's supply of arms to Iraq should be learned. Suggestions of qualitative restraint are being floated, though the ultimate outcome will depend on the major suppliers. It is unlikely that the United States would be restrained in either quality or quantity in relation to the supply of such states as Israel, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. Some form of international register on the supply of conventional weapons might be useful, in that transparency could facilitate political and diplomatic pressure.

The goal of a convention or other agreement within the region to limit weapons of mass destruction, although worth while, will also be difficult. It is hard to imagine Israel giving up its nuclear capacity, while Syria will justify its chemical weapons as what it sees as a necessary balance. Therefore, I say that securing the peace is going to be an enormous challenge. There are great uncertainties: Iran comes out of the war more powerful, but we do not know how it will use that power; Turkey's position is enhanced, but we do not know what that will mean for its large Kurdish community; the likely process of democratisation in Kuwait will have a flow down effect in Saudi Arabia and the Gulf Emirates, and we do not know what that means; whilst we would always commend the democratic progress in the short term, it might lead to greater instability; a new leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organisation will evolve, but it might be more extreme. It is certain that the region will provide continuing challenges for the international community.

Australia can now do in peace what it did in war: that is, in a modest but constructive way, be a useful contributor in the support of the UN peace keeping, as I have indicated; in diplomacy, as continuing efforts are made to find common ground; and in building bridges through trade and infrastructure development, education and other aid programs which are a contribution towards alleviating poverty in the region. Therefore, Australia can play a role.

In the same way as Australia had vital interests which have justified acceptance of a military role to enforce UN resolutions, so the same vital interests remain after the war. It is worth, I would suggest, investing a little more towards a more stable and secure regional environment and thus an ongoing peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats share the relief of all Australians that a temporary cease-fire has been declared in the Middle East war and that a resumption of fighting between Iraq and the allied forces is most unlikely. We are particularly relieved that Australian service personnel are now very likely to return from the combat zone unharmed. We join the Government and the Opposition in commending them and our diplomatic staff in the region for carrying out their responsibilities in a competent and courageous manner. We hope to see our service men and women return to Australia soon, to rejoin their families and friends after their anxious weeks in the war zone. We, along with most Australians, will welcome them home.

SPEECH.PARA: We welcome too the Government's award, outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his statement, of the active service medal. It is due recognition for these service people. I certainly commit the Democrats to working in the best interests of these new veterans, members of our Australian veterans community, in the same way as we have done in the past for veterans of all theatres of war.

I want to rebut in the strongest possible terms a suggestion which has been made elsewhere, but was particularly made in a letter in yesterday's Australian, that I and all members of the peace movement would be sponsoring acts of recrimination against those who have served in the Persian Gulf. The Democrats have consistently directed our opposition to the war at those who made the decisions and not at those who carried out the consequent orders. I know that the overwhelming majority of other members of the peace movement share this view.

Referring to the Prime Minister's statement, which we are debating, I want to allude to two paragraphs on page 3 which, to my mind, imply that-with regard to entering into armed conflict in the Middle East-the Parliament had some kind of role in those decisions, with which the Democrats did not agree. I think it is important in this debate to make it clear that this Parliament has not been the decision-maker, that the debates that we have had thus far have been after the fact rather than before the fact and that it should not be understood that Parliament has been a decision-maker. Those decisions have been made by the Government, largely in the person of the Prime Minister, and a small number of people-and, in the first instance, not even by the full Cabinet.

The Democrats also wholeheartedly welcome Iraq's departure from Kuwait. Iraq's annexation of its neighbour was illegitimate and brutal, beginning as it did with an invasion, and had to be reversed. Again in his speech, the Prime Minister alludes to the question of appeasement and asserts that to do other than this Government chose to do, along with other coalition partners-to go to all out war-was to engage in appeasement. There is no sense in which at least the Australian Democrats and the vast majority of people with whom we have worked these past several months have been engaged in an exercise of appeasement. We strongly supported, as this chamber has been told, from the beginning the strong action that the United Nations (UN) first endorsed and supported. I have to ask in the context of appeasement where this Government, the other coalition governments and other governments around the world stood on the question of appeasement during the eight years in which Iraq perpetrated a war against Iran more or less on our behalf against Muslim fundamentalism.

It is not possible for us, in the context of the Prime Minister's statement, to endorse the Government's claim that a great victory has been won. The extent of the death, impoverishment and destruction caused by the war is now only beginning to be understood, and the extent of it all is rising. There are reports of outbreaks of cholera, for instance, in Iraq and there are reports coming in daily of carnage and of cruelty throughout the whole theatre of war in Kuwait as well. It is far too soon to claim that any kind of real victory will arise from the carnage.

Now that the video game reports of allied military prowess are no longer dominating the television news bulletins, the Democrats are concerned that the attention of the media and the public will turn away from the Middle East and that we will fail to learn the lessons arising from the aftermath of the war. As the full costs are counted, we must ask ourselves whether the price was worth paying or whether it could have been reduced without any sacrifice of principle. The final point made by the Prime Minister in his statement is this:
. . . if men and women who can influence the decisions of their leaders, have learned this lesson-
the lesson he refers to is that, in his words in the previous paragraph, war may, by necessity, be a last resort against perverse and evil leaders-
then we will not just have made the world a safer but indeed a better place . . .

It is important to note that the people of Iraq were not people who could influence the decisions of their leaders, in the way that the Prime Minister points out in his statement. Indeed, at the beginning of his statement the Prime Minister referred, with some apparent compassion, to the suffering of the Iraqi people. The first page of his statement reads:
And Iraq's people have suffered great devastation and loss.

Certainly they have-devastation, loss and suffering which they were already undergoing at the hands of their evil dictator. That was exacerbated massively by the decision to go to war and, as I say, the full cost of that is still not known.

When we are counting the cost-and we are talking about military casualties-it is important to remember that these were not people who could influence the decisions of their leaders. Indeed, those military casualties, in the vast majority, were conscripts. When they had the opportunity to defect they certainly did so. These people were not there from choice. That was part of the military victory, if you like-the very fact that this was not an army that was there doing something out of free choice. That is leaving aside the question of those civilians whose lives and homes have been devastated.

This must not be the last parliamentary debate on the Gulf crisis. A large part of the justification for the war was its alleged relevance to President Bush's grand vision of a new world order of peace, security and freedom. Whether the war has contributed to the peace, security and freedom of the Middle East will be much clearer in six or 12 months time. That would be the time for a further debate. The Democrats have a vision of a new world order which would meet the key challenges of the coming decade and the twenty-first century.

The first pillar of such a new order is respect for human rights and support for democracy and self-determination of peoples as enshrined in the United Nations charter. In, say, 12 months time, the Democrats would hope to see this principle rigorously applied throughout the Middle East. We would hope, for instance, to see fully-fledged democracy in Kuwait, with voting under universal suffrage as per the charter of the United Nations. We expect the West to be responding to the human rights abuses of Syria's President Assad, so recently our ally, with the same outrage as it expressed over Iraqi atrocities in Kuwait-an outrage which we share.

We look forward to real progress towards a Palestinian state and assured security for Israel. We assume that the United Nations will have recognised the claims of the Kurdish people for their own state. We would hope that the civil unrest now growing in Iraq, fuelled in the south somewhat ironically by Shi'ite fundamentalism, will not lead to a destructive civil war, but that the end result, by some means, will be a more enlightened and humane government in that country.

Secondly, the new world order should strive for economic equity. In 12 months time-should we have this debate again-we would hope for progress towards a fair distribution of the Middle East's oil revenue. We also expect that the impoverishment of ordinary Iraqis, caused by their nation's massive debt and the destruction of its oil facilities as a consequence of the war, will be alleviated in a way that avoids the perils associated with the squeeze placed on Germany, for example, after World War I.

Thirdly, the new world order should be based on environmental protection and economic sustainability. In 12 months time, the Democrats hope that, after this latest reminder of the fragility of Middle East oil supplies, the industrialised nations will have made real progress towards an international agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and our own economic dependence on oil.

Finally, the new world order should be based on the just resolution of conflict, with emphasis on non-violent means. In 12 months, we hope to see an end to Syrian and Israeli intervention in Lebanon. We look forward to a comprehensive embargo on arms sales to the Middle East and progress towards arms reductions agreements in the global context. We expect that Syria's ambitions to become a leading regional power, based on Chinese and North Korean weapons, which it is now reportedly paying for with Saudi war donations, will have been thwarted by concerted international action.

The Democrats hope that a new world order will produce all these benefits. But we are under no illusions that progress will be made on any of these issues, much less all of them. Indeed, the Government's statement has taken several large steps away from the grand new world order foreshadowed by the Prime Minister in earlier speeches on the crisis.

The fact is that the Middle East war was not fought to usher in a new world order. It was fought to prop up an outdated and corrupt regime, an old world order based on inequalities in wealth and access to resources, selective and cynical support for human rights and democracy, and disregard for the environment. In 12 months time this will be much clearer than it is in the euphoria of a military victory. The Democrats look forward to further debate.

The Government's statement claims that the outcome of the war is a victory for the United Nations. Again, the Democrats cannot agree. It would be far more accurate to describe it as a victory-if it is a victory-for the United States over the United Nations. In the early stages of the crisis, the UN did take charge by imposing the most comprehensive sanctions in world history. Thereafter, however, it was reduced to rubber-stamping the Bush Administration's military plans and actions, progressing from a naval blockade to an all-out war. The UN has been marginalised and its authority and standing have been damaged. Its role in the Gulf crisis is certain to be put under the international microscope. We hope that, 12 months from now, this will have stimulated an overdue debate on reforming the United Nations system. In no way at all should a global policeman be allowed to also sit as judge and jury.

I want to expand a little on the question of arms sales, which I was amazed to find did not rate a mention in the Government's statement. The most obvious lesson of the Middle East war is that the international arms trade is an explosive boomerang. It was fine, as I said, when Saddam Hussein was fighting a war against Muslim fundamentalism-a sort of arm's length policeman for people of the West and indeed of the Eastern bloc at the time. However, boomerangs do have a way of coming back. Having bought arms from many industrialised countries, including major Western powers, Iraq then turned those weapons against the interests of its suppliers, particularly the oil interests.

If the new world order is to achieve anything, major progress towards restricting the arms trade is essential. Australia, which has a strong international record as an advocate of disarmament, could and should play a leading role. Indeed, Senator Robert Ray, who I am pleased is in the chamber, was quoted in the Australian of 2 February as saying that this Government would push for a world review of arms transfers. I hope this idea has not been dropped.

The Democrats support a United Nations review of military transfers and conventional arms purchases. Indeed, a UN imposed moratorium on arms sales would be most appropriate at this time while such a review was under way. Australia should review its export guidelines. As foreshadowed, the Democrats believe that we and the Opposition in this chamber should set the ball rolling with a Senate inquiry. I am encouraged by Senator Durack's statements, whom I am also pleased to see in the chamber, to the media on 1 February this year. I quote:
The Government's policy on the export of defence equipment is in total disarray and needs urgent revision.

The Shadow Minister for Defence, Senator Peter Durack, said today that the Government had ignored Opposition calls to revise defence export guidelines in spite of the problems created by recent export approvals.

The Democrats agree with Senator Durack-this is a vital matter. We will bring before the Senate a proposal for an inquiry to deal with those issues. In that context we certainly look forward to productive discussions towards something positive here, in Australia, at least.

As I have said, this is not really the time for us to assess the result of the war perpetrated in the Middle East. The Democrats regret that time was not given for the sanctions and diplomacy regime initially established by the United Nations to have some impact; five months was never enough time.

We regret the loss of life and the destruction to the nations involved and to the environment in the Middle East, and, indeed, as a consequence, to the global environment. We welcome home our Australian service people. We look forward to further debate on the questions of the Middle East and the Gulf crisis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is time for me to put some acknowledgments on the record. There is not a lot I can add to the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Gareth Evans about the overall situation. I acknowledge the Government's and the country's gratitude to all Australian servicemen. I thank, first, those sailors who served on HMAS Adelaide and HMAS Darwin for their efforts in enforcing the sanctions. They had to leave at very short notice. They went to an environment that was very uncertain. At the time no-one knew the potential dangers. The fact that many dangers did not eventuate should not take away from the psychological pressure they were all put under. The ships Adelaide and Darwin did an enormous job in enforcing sanctions in the Gulf of Oman. They proved that they could work with other allied ships. They proved that they could have a high work rate and do their job very efficiently. To all their crew we must be grateful.

SPEECH.PARA: The contribution of HMAS Success, which served in the Gulf for many months, was enormous. It serviced many ships in the Gulf. At the end there was a saying around the Gulf that, if the Success could not procure the equipment, it was unprocurable. Mr Acting Deputy President, your State gave the sailors on that ship an excellent welcome back last Saturday. They were all proud to come back to Adelaide and drop off the Army team. They had an Army team on board for their protection with the Rapier anti-defence system. We should acknowledge the role that they played.

I also thank those who served on HMAS Sydney and HMAS Brisbane. They were required to go into an even more threatening situation than that faced by those on the Adelaide and Darwin. They served in the Gulf with high commendation. The allies certainly appreciated their presence. They were given all sorts of roles in the Gulf. Again, it proves the benefit derived from the interoperability of equipment, well trained personnel and regular exercise with our allies. Those two crews certainly performed very well. HMAS Westralia joined and replaced the Success. It also paid a very active role in supplying the various warships in the Gulf.

I also pay tribute to some other Australian servicemen. First, the logistics team, who went over very early and made sure that all our ships there were supplied correctly. It was only a small team of eight to 10, but they did an excellent job in making sure that the rest of our service personnel were well fed and well armed and that any maintenance equipment got there quickly and was quickly sent out to the ships. I would also like to thank, without naming, their host country for the enormous amount of assistance that the logistics team and visiting sailors received while there.

I also put on record our appreciation of the effort of the medical team-60 personnel in all. I am very grateful that they had essentially nothing to do. But they did have to wait and get ready and continue to stay ready for a potential job. We are all pleased that they did not have to do it. I understand that the hospital ships will be leaving the Gulf very shortly. I hope to see our medical team back here promptly.

I also put on record my thanks to the divers who had to leave in January. Very few of them were in fact deployed. I was one of the first to know that there would not be an amphibious assault because they were never deployed to the Gulf. However, most of them are now in the northern Gulf and most will be involved in mine clearance. For what period I have yet to make a decision. But I certainly believe that they can use their skills to make the Gulf safe for civilian shipping. I am sure that no-one in Australia would deny them that humanitarian role they can now play.

I thank the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) for the transport job it did. At least once a week a Hercules would fly to the Gulf region with supplies, equipment and sometimes personnel. RAAF personnel also had to be on stand-by and face very rigorous conditions for Operation Ozone, the operation designated to get out Australian civilians from that region, if necessary. The RAAF performed very well.

I also compliment the diplomatic staff in the area, those that stayed under very onerous conditions and served their country very well. At times it is very easy to be glib about people working in Foreign Affairs and about their being in privileged la-di-da positions. But the reality is that they work extremely hard under very trying circumstances and serve their country particularly well.

I congratulate Commodores Chambers and Oxenbold, who headed our Gulf commitment at different periods. I also place on record my appreciation of the work done by Rear Admiral Doolan of Maritime Headquarters and, of course, his ultimate boss, Admiral Hudson. It is a very appropriate time for Admiral Hudson to be retiring, knowing that the navy that he has headed for the last six years performed so well. I also congratulate him on his promotion to full Admiral on the eve of his retirement.

I also put on record the hard work done in Australia by some of the Australian military people. It is hard to individualise, but I particularly congratulate Major-General John Baker from Defence Intelligence for his brilliant assessment of what was happening in the Gulf. Time and time again his predictions proved to be right. He impressed everyone with his knowledge. Sometimes his predictions were based not on any inside information, but just on what he regarded as military logic. So often it came true. I also thank Rear Admiral Taylor, who heads up Operations, for the excellent job he did. On the whole, Australian defence forces, from top to bottom, did a good job in this exercise.

Some immediate lessons are to be learnt from the Gulf conflict. I do not intend to canvass all those here tonight. I have, through my officers, organised for a small parliamentary delegation to visit the Middle East for two to three weeks to have a look at the situation on hand. It is very hard to organise this in a hurry, so rather than going through the normal party room ballots, et cetera, which would have meant that we would never have got the delegation away, we suggested that the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade go to the Middle East. Senator MacGibbon and Mr Lindsay left yesterday. I hope that they will be able to go throughout the region to make their own assessment and report back to the Joint Committee, to the Parliament and to their party rooms on exactly what occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was putting on the record the Government's and the country's acknowledgment of the efforts made by the Australian Defence Force in regard to our Gulf commitment. I also noted the fact that a small parliamentary delegation was going to the region and that its members would report back to their party rooms and to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, some questions arise as to the future of our personnel in the Gulf. In regard to the Sydney, the Brisbane and the Westralia, a decision will be made following a formal cease-fire-and let us hope it will be in a few days' time-as to a timetable for their return. I indicated earlier that I think the medical teams will return fairly quickly but the divers may remain in the Gulf for some time clearing mines. Those Australian personnel who are on exchange with other units will either rotate back to those countries to fulfil the rest of their term or, if their term expires, will come back to Australia.

Senator Hill raised the question of future security arrangements and was critical of the Government for not detailing them in the policy statement delivered today by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I think that is a very inept criticism. The situation is far too fluid at the moment to determine what the future will be. One does not know what the regime in Iraq will be. One has no idea of the role the United Nations will lay out and it would be far too premature to be making any bold statements on this particular issue.

However, I must also put on the record the appreciation of this Government for the support by the Liberal and National parties. I think it is true of the major democracies involved in the Gulf conflict that in each case there was bipartisan support from the two major parties in each country. That did greatly enhance the commitment and the efficiency of the commitment. The service personnel very much appreciated the fact that this Parliament and at least 90 per cent of the Australian people were fully behind them in the Gulf. That was reinforced when the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Tim Fischer, visited the ships over Christmas. It has been reinforced at the return of every ship. There has been a great turnout of Opposition and Government members to welcome those ships back. That is very important.

The scars of Vietnam remain. I am not revisiting the rights and wrongs of that. They have remained in the Australian Defence Force for 20 years, passed on from generation to generation. Of all the issues in the Gulf-be they conditions, medals, danger or anything else-the biggest concern and the first and most persistent question asked of me was, `When we return to Australia will we, in fact, be treated like lepers?'. Of course, the moment Darwin and Adelaide arrived, word sped back that that would not be the case.

Tonight Senator Powell made a very unequivocal statement about the troops coming back and the Australian Democrats not taking a critical stand. On behalf of the Democrats she is right in doing that, and I welcome her statement. Her position is not true of all members of the peace movement but it is true of the majority of them. But even on Saturday we had to have the few clowns protesting at the wharf. I do not know whether they were demonstrating against the Government or the sailors. I quite expect them to demonstrate against the Government. Nevertheless, it still hurts the seamen who think that it may be against them. I would prefer to think that those people were demonstrating against the political decision makers rather than the Australian defence forces.

Senator Powell could not resist raising the full Cabinet issue again. She asked why the full Cabinet could not have made the decision. It did so unanimously five days after the decision. This was another red herring. I thought that Senator Powell's speech was fairly defensive and I am a little disappointed that some of the lessons of the Gulf have gone over her head. However, past is past; let us look to the future.

I think it would be wrong if I did not make some comments on some of the other effects of the Gulf war. First of all, let me say something about Kuwait. In every war, propaganda always emerges about the horror of the other side. That is an inevitability and such propaganda is normally exaggerated. But it is very little exaggeration to say that Iraq's treatment of Kuwait, its destruction of Kuwait-the setting of fire to oil wells, the pumping of oil into the Persian Gulf, the mistreatment of Kuwaiti citizens-are very hard to comprehend. It is not simply just a propaganda exercise.

The Kuwaitis will have a very hard job when it comes to restoration and they will have to learn some lessons. I think the first lesson they have learnt is not to pump billions of dollars into a neighbour for the purpose of buying arms which in turn will be used against them. I hope they have learnt that lesson. They may also be a different society in the future with broader citizen participation within the government, probably with less dependence on and exploitation of guest workers.
