Kuwait really will go through difficult times. The days of the odd Kuwaiti citizen dropping a few million dollars at the tables in London should be far gone.

In terms of Iraq, it is very hard to predict the future. My view is that reparations should be demanded of Iraq. But we should also give consideration to forgoing reparations if Iraq agrees to a constitution with a limited defence force-a defence force based on self-defence and not on aggression.

The Prime Minister and other speakers have noted that they have taken no pleasure-nor do I-in the quite heavy casualty rate that the Iraqis suffered. There are many wives, mothers and fathers, who will be bitterly disappointed and grieving in the next few months. We take no pleasure from that. On the other hand, I do not believe that the war and conflict could have been prosecuted in any other way. Our first responsibility was to our own troops and, in prosecuting the war in the way that it did, the coalition had that foremost in its mind. It is quite clear that many of the Iraqi troops were conscripts, many were there against their will, and many did not believe what they were fighting for. There was no doubt that if they had tried to get out, they would have been shot and their families punished. It is very sad for all those people that these things have been visited upon them.

It was also sad to reflect on the opportunities that were forgone by Iraq. It had many opportunities to bring this conflict to an end. How Iraq must regret that it did not respond to the 15 January deadline. And how much must Iraq also regret that it did not respond to the further American deadline before the start of the ground war. But it did not and it paid the price for it.

I do not want to say a lot more on this matter but I do want to respond on another issue. Throughout this whole conflict, this Government had its critics-I assume that they were just as critical of the Opposition, although governments always tend to be a primary target-of the decision to get involved. Their arguments were quite diverse-some better based than others. I thought that those who tried to draw analogies with Vietnam failed abysmally. They were simply trying to jump on the surfboard and ride on the wave of previous sentiment, and that failed fairly abysmally.

Those who tried again to introduce the red herring of conscription-on the whisper, on the talkback and in all of the areas that those people specialise in-did a fair bit of damage around the place. Again, that was very poorly based. There were others, pacifists, who took a very consistent position on this conflict as they have on many other conflicts. We can understand that. Many of the other critics were really recidivists from the old anti-American days. I believe that our reason for being involved in this Gulf conflict was one not only of self-interest but also of principle; it was a moral decision to be involved.

I suppose I spent a lot of time over two or three months wondering what my reaction would be to the first casualty. I must be the luckiest Defence Minister in the history of Australia never having that worry come to fruition. I dare say that there are other people in this chamber who were similarly worried. It is a great relief to know that there were no Australian casualties.

I believe that we were right to be involved in the conflict from the very start. I conclude by again thanking all those members of the Australian Defence Force, both here in Australia and those who served overseas, for a job well done. They have done this country very proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the fourth occasion in a little over six months on which this Parliament has been called upon to discuss what is now usually called the Gulf war, although it was not when we first discussed it back in August. That is not entirely appropriate because of the enormous responsibility that we have to undertake in facing decisions of this kind. When I spoke in the first of those debates in August last year I said that I was very conscious of the fact that that was the most important speech that I have made in the years that I have been in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: As the events since August last year have unfolded, right through until the great news of last Thursday about the end of hostilities in the Gulf, the significance of the events which we embarked upon just over six months ago became more dramatic almost day by day. There was an extraordinary escalation of what was occurring throughout that period. Certainly it was not just confined to the last few days of the land war. Thankfully it lasted only a short period. It has been a major experience for the nation and for a new generation of Australians. There has been no more visible a sign of that experience than the 1,000 or more defence personnel who were engaged on our behalf as citizens of Australia in the sharp end of this conflict.

At the very commencement of my remarks tonight, I would like to add to what was said by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) who has just spoken and by many others, including the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), in extending the Opposition's gratitude to all those members of our defence forces who have taken part, particularly those who have been serving in the Gulf region, those who have supported them both in the Gulf region and back in Australia, and particularly the crews of the six Navy vessels who have played such a valuable role. It could have been a very dangerous role from the beginning and certainly became a dangerous role from the time the ships moved up into the Persian Gulf itself from the Gulf of Oman. As I have said before in this debate, as Australians we should be-and we are-very proud of the efforts of our servicemen and women who have performed their duties in the highest traditions of the Australian Defence Force.

I think it was very good of the Minister, with his intimate knowledge of those who served, to detail in his speech tonight the extent of that operation, the numbers of different personnel and the different aspects of the operation. I was pleased that he put it on the record. I associate my colleagues in the Opposition with the expressions of gratitude to all those people in the various capacities.

It was a very difficult task to get the first ships ready to leave at short notice. That in itself was perhaps one of the more impressive aspects of this whole operation. I think there was a week between the time that they were tasked and when they sailed from Sydney. Although it was a fairly frenzied task to achieve that result, it was achieved. To prepare the second fleet-the replacement ships HMAS Sydney and HMAS Brisbane-a great deal of additional work had to be performed at the Garden Island Dockyard, particularly in the case of the HMAS Brisbane, to get it in a safe condition to engage upon its deployment. The extent of the work that was done there and the timely way in which it was done to enable that ship to go with the vessels that went to replace HMAS Darwin and HMAS Adelaide was a most praiseworthy effort by all concerned. I want to particularly mention the civilian workers at the Garden Island Dockyard who really put their shoulders to the wheel and made it possible for HMAS Brisbane to actually be deployed when it was required. There was a very impressive joint effort by a large number of people. Of course, as I said, particular thanks must be primarily given to those who served in what became a theatre of war in the Persian Gulf.

The other pleasing aspect of the operation over these months has been the overwhelming support of the Australian people for this exercise. That has been most important for those who served. They can be assured of, and indeed have already experienced, the obvious appreciation of the Australian people by the welcome home that was extended to the frigates in Sydney just before Christmas and HMAS Success at Port Adelaide the other day. When HMAS Brisbane, HMAS Sydney and HMAS Westralia return they will be received, as everyone wants to be associated with winners, with even more enthusiasm than those ships that have already returned. I do not think that there should be any worry in the minds of the Australian Defence Force or of the Australian community generally that there is going to be a lack of recognition for the efforts that our defence personnel have made.

I think it has also been important that there has been, on an official basis, bipartisan support in this Parliament also for the deployment of the force in the Gulf. I am pleased that the Minister has acknowledged that tonight. I am also pleased that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) even acknowledged it in his speech in another place. I must say that I have been a little disappointed throughout this period that the Prime Minister did not seem able to bring himself to acknowledge the important role that the Opposition has played in this deployment and in this commitment of Australia; not just a commitment by the Australian Government or the Australian Parliament but a commitment very much by the Australian people, with few exceptions, and they have been the minority. It has been a very important feature of the whole Australian commitment to this operation that there was that commitment from both sides of the Australian political scene.

As the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has pointed out today in another place, during the special sitting of Parliament in January every member of the Opposition in both the House and the Senate voted in favour of the resolution proposed by the Prime Minister. Where we have had some disagreements with the Government on very minor matters, I believe that we have sought to express those in a cooperative way which would assist the operation rather than in a negative sense, and certainly in no way have we tried to play politics.

This is a democratic society and people are entitled to express dissent. The only thing that disappointed me about those who dissented is the sense in which they sought to appropriate all moral value for their side, and in fact made claims that they represented the Australian view. That was a very significant, extraordinary feature of the speech by Senator Powell in this Parliament when we debated the Gulf crisis in January. Senator Powell seemed to believe that she was speaking on behalf of the majority of the Australian people, which was shown in the polls within a day or two-if we needed it-not to be the case. Certainly, for all of us on both sides who have supported this deployment, it has been very important to have the support of the Australian people. We did not need the polls to tell us that we had that support; we knew that from the feelings expressed so many times by people whom we have been meeting and from whom we have received that solid support. The decisions made by the Government, supported throughout by the Opposition, have now been fully justified.

Again, I was surprised to hear Senator Powell saying tonight that we could not really say whether this exercise had been justified or not. It was not sufficient, apparently, that victory had been achieved with, in the case of Australian personnel, no casualties whatsoever and, in the case of our allies, extremely light casualties. That has been one of the outstanding features of this war as far as our side has been concerned. Regrettably, it has not been the experience for the Iraqi forces or, perhaps most sadly of all, the Kuwaiti people who have been so brutally treated by the Iraqi occupation forces. There has been a great loss of life there. There has been terrible damage in Kuwait, and a great deal of damage in Iraq, despite the fact that another notable feature of this conflict has been the ability of the allied forces air power to be on-target with their weapons and therefore to minimise greatly the damage that would have been caused in any wars of the past, as occurred particularly in the Second World War.

Comparisons that have been made between the sort of damage made by old-style bombing and now the limited damage from modern weaponry are very impressive indeed. Nevertheless, there clearly has been a great deal of damage inflicted on Iraq. Although the Australian Democrats seem to be emphasising that, it is not something we need emphasised; it is apparent. It is the conclusion that is to be drawn from this which is the important matter. The conclusion to be drawn is clearly that the world body, the United Nations, and those forces which, under the leadership of the United States, participated in giving effect to the decisions of the United Nations, have achieved the purpose in a very definite and clear way. I suppose that is why it can be clearly claimed to be a victory.

The critics who point to the devastation should bear in mind why that devastation occurred. It occurred simply because of the totally unjustified invasion of Kuwait by Iraq. There was the brutal occupation of Kuwait without any justification. It does not matter what form of government there was in Kuwait; the fact is that the United Nations is not there just to protect democracies from invasion by their neighbours but to protect nations which are members of the United Nations. That was the issue. In the end it was not simply a question of the interests of nations. It was not just a question of the economic interests; it was in the end a moral issue that this type of behaviour is not going to be tolerated. Certainly, it did become a question, I believe, of right and wrong. The action taken by the United Nations was certainly a most impressive exercise in its history. That was done entirely of its own free will. It was not being imposed upon it by any power. It is true that it could not have been achieved had it not been for the leadership given by the United States, and President Bush in particular, who has established himself as a world-class statesman and a most distinguished President of the United States.

I think we should be proud that, as Australians, we were part of the wide response to the United Nations call for action to be taken, firstly with sanctions and, subsequently-unfortunately but by necessity-war, to achieve its purpose. But it was vitally important for the future security of certainly the smaller nations of the world-of which we are one-that those steps be taken by the United Nations, through the leadership of the United States, the United Kingdom, France and all those countries which participated in the necessity of this war. It was the only way that a result was going to be achieved, and we should be grateful that it has been achieved. My colleague the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill, has indicated the problems for the future, and so have the Australian Democrats. They are great problems-problems that no doubt we will have to debate in this chamber on other occasions.

However, in this debate let us reflect, as I have tried to do, on why it happened. We can regret very much the need for it; we can extend our sympathy to those who suffered from it; and we can express our horror at events such as the environmental damage that was caused, particularly by the actions of the offenders themselves with their firing of oil wells and their releasing of vast quantities of oil into the Gulf and so on. But let us not allow these concerns-or all the horror that we may feel-to deflect us from the fact that it had to be done and it has been done successfully and swiftly, and it has probably been done with much less damage by the military than has ever before been afflicted in previous conflicts of this kind.

We can draw many implications for the future from this experience. I do not propose to dwell further on those which have already been mentioned by Senator Hill or by the Leader of the Opposition in another place. However, I would like to add that the Opposition believes implications can be drawn for our defence capability as a result of this experience. The Opposition is disappointed that the Government does not seem to share our concern about this matter. Although the Minister did not do it in his speech tonight, he has, as has the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on other occasions, claimed that the Government's White Paper of 1987 is quite adequate to meet exigencies of this kind and that we do not have to do more than keep it fine-tuned. That seems to be the view of the Government. However, the Opposition believes that a far more thoroughgoing review of our defence capability is required.

Problems emerged during this conflict. I do not want to dwell on them, but there were problems of a relatively minor nature in relation to getting the ships ready and having them sufficiently stocked. Such problems are obviously to be expected but there are perhaps lessons to be drawn from them. Certainly there is a lesson to be drawn about the adequacy of the size of our fleet. People may debate whether that is being addressed sufficiently with the new ships being built, but to say that we do not need to look at these matters seriously is, I think, foolish.

Clearly there is a most important implication about the nature of weapons of modern warfare, their use, their production and the requirement for them. Perhaps no previous war has been dominated quite so much by technology and the nature of the weapons used, and we must ask ourselves whether we are sufficiently prepared for a modern war in light of the experience we have just been through.

There are many implications for our defence policy. I am pleased to say that the Opposition has embarked upon a thorough review of those which will continue for the rest of this year. I hope the Government realises that there are such major implications for defence policy and, instead of taking a negative attitude-as it has done so far-to the efforts of the Opposition in this regard, will also recognise that those defence capabilities must be under question in the light of recent events in the Gulf. I hope the Government will also agree with the Opposition's view that these matters should be addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks in this debate on the parliamentary statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on behalf of the Government about the Gulf crisis, which to all intents and purposes concluded with the success of the United Nations (UN) forces last weekend.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously many ramifications of the success of the UN forces will be debated and there will be ongoing developments in the Middle East and in the Gulf area in the coming months, if not years. However, it must be noted that the decisions of the United Nations and the allies have been absolutely successful. The decisions taken by the United Nations in the period between the beginning of August last year, when Kuwait was invaded and occupied by Iraq, until the end of last week indicate that it has, in my view, come into its own. It has done so in a way that has vindicated what many of us-both in this place and elsewhere in the community-argued was the sort of United Nations we wanted. I make no bones about the fact that I have always supported Australia's involvement in the United Nations-sanctioned allied forces. I think our response was appropriate to our interest and to our role as a middle sized power in the world. Had Australia not participated in the allied forces, I think we would have been in dereliction of our duty as a middle sized power within the United Nations.

I know that many people-perhaps not in this place but elsewhere in the community, although not a majority of Australians-opposed Australia's involvement because they claimed to be opposed to war. I suspect some of those elements based their opposition to our involvement on a fundamental anti-Americanism in their attitude towards international affairs. I think that has been most unfortunate and that they have allowed their judgment to be coloured by the fact that they saw this purely as an American inspired initiative, vis-a-vis what occurred in Vietnam.

Had this been similar to the Vietnam conflict and had America been acting by itself without the sanction of the UN, I would not have supported Australia's involvement in the Gulf war. However, I believe one cannot have it both ways: one cannot argue for the United Nations to be effective in international affairs and yet when a crunch issue comes along bale out by saying, `It is all too terrible' or `Because the Americans may have too much influence and may have been able to convince the United Nations Security Council to vote a particular way, therefore we should all bale out on it'. I believe that is a negative approach fundamentally aimed at destroying the effectiveness of the United Nations.

No other international organisation exists which can deal with these sorts of events as does the United Nations. We must make the United Nations effective. I, like many people in the community, have often complained that the United Nations has not been used as the appropriate forum to resolve disputes and to overcome war and deficiencies in the international political order. However, in my view, the Gulf war is the basis of a turning point in the international political order. In his statement the Prime Minister talked about a new international order. I think that is an appropriate statement and description; it is not overselling in any way the consequences of what has occurred in the past eight months in the Gulf war and the involvement of the United Nations.

For something like 45 years since just after the end of World War II we were locked into what was called the Cold War, in which the two superpowers basically neutralised each other in the forum of the United Nations. The veto was used by both sides from time to time against the interests of the other. It was a sheer fluke that the Soviet Union was boycotting the Security Council of the United Nations when North Korea invaded South Korea in 1950, thus enabling the Security Council to vote to take action against the North Korean aggression. Had the Soviet Union been present, it would have used its power of veto and that aggression would have gone unchecked.

I believe that the events of the last eight months have been most significant in that none of the five superpowers-some of them are not very super any more-with a veto in the United Nations Security Council used that veto to stop the UN carrying resolutions empowering member countries to take whatever necessary action was deemed appropriate to liberate Kuwait. I think in the long run that will mean that the superpowers can no longer, of their own volition, of their own choice, ignore the importance of the UN. I certainly will be one of the first people in this forum, or any other forum, to complain if, in the future, the United States, the Soviet Union or any of the five superpowers that have the veto in the UN Security Council choose to ignore the United Nations as the appropriate forum to overcome disputes, whether they be of a conflict nature such as the Gulf war or whether they be of more mundane or prosaic issues dealing with international law in the environmental area, international trade or developmental aid. The United States of America, the Soviet Union and the other superpowers have chosen to use the UN as the basis for the justification of their action. They got the support of the UN; they got the overwhelming support of the countries of the world irrespective of the ideological bent of many of those countries. Very few countries-maybe only two or three-used the forum in the UN to defend what Iraq did. Countries such as Cuba or the Yemen, which are presently on the United Nations Security Council, in criticising the allied military plans also made sure that they did not support the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq.

We had absolutely overwhelming support in the UN, in the family of nations, against what Saddam Hussein and his military regime carried out against Kuwait. I know that people use the argument that Kuwait is not a democratic country and has many features that we, in this country, would abhor. That is very true, but we cannot ignore the fact that one sovereign country chose to invade and wipe off the map another sovereign country-a sovereign country that was recognised by the Arab League and the United Nations as a sovereign country. I think that is a very simple and fundamental test that the United Nations looked at and chose to act upon. It is a simple, commonsense test that a sovereign existing nation was invaded and incorporated into the invading country. There was no pretence about supporting a revolutionary movement, it was just sheer naked greed on behalf of Saddam Hussein and his military regime in Iraq to get hold of Kuwait and the oil that went with it.

I believe that it is correct for the Prime Minister to talk about a new order in his statement-a new order that we should all welcome. I know it is tragic that that new order, in part, has come out of a war which has cost many people their lives. I know that in one sense our media and the Australian people are very happy that no Australians lost their lives and that only a very small handful of people on the allied side lost their lives in this conflict. It gives me no joy, and it should give nobody in the world any joy, that quite clearly tens of thousands of Iraqi soldiers lost their lives in the last 40-odd days of the war. What is particularly tragic is that they lost their lives because they had no choice in the nature of their government. They were conscripted overwhelmingly; they were conscripts. They were put into the army and if they objected or ran away, there is evidence from Amnesty International and other sources that their families paid a penalty. The Secret Police were used to ensure that they did not run away once they were placed near the front line or in the front line around the Kuwaiti area. Plenty of evidence is emerging that the Secret Police and special squads of the Iraqi army were used to ensure that there were no desertions, and if people deserted or were suspected of deserting they were executed.

I think it should be noted that only a totalitarian regime that has no compunction or no conscience can get away with imposing that sort of position on its own citizens. I hope that with the success of the UN and allied forces in the Gulf other tin-pot dictators in the world take note that maybe in this new order they will not be able to act with absolute arrogance towards their own people and have some assurance that because of the superpower rivalry that existed in the 1950s, 1960s, 1970s and much of the 1980s, they will be able to snub their noses at world opinion as to how they treat their own people.

It should be remembered that in the last 30 or 40 years during the Second World War period dictatorships started wars because they have no responsibility to the wishes and desires of their people. Those democracies which have attempted to be involved in wars or to start a war have paid terrible penalties, just like the Americans paid a terrible penalty in getting involved in the Vietnam war. In the end, it destroyed a presidency, it destroyed the moral position of the American people and it created enormous divisions in that country all because a democratic country went to war, in my view illegally, with no authority and no justification against a people in another part of the world; namely, Vietnam. But dictators do not worry about conscience.

I welcome the fact that a dictator has paid what I hope, in effect, is a supreme penalty for a dictator-losing power. Maybe in the next few weeks the Iraqi people will throw Saddam Hussein out and, hopefully, will adopt a more democratic form of government. I hope that other tin-pot dictators elsewhere in the world-and there are many still-take note of what has happened and note that the UN at long last has credibility and clout to deal with international issues.

Our Prime Minister has made it quite clear that we expect the new order to be able to deal more effectively with the long running disputes of the Middle East, particularly Lebanon and the Palestinian-Israeli issues. I support those remarks completely. I believe it will be absolutely tragic if, in this new order, this new environment that has been created by the UN's actions, we were not able to deal with the issues that have bedevilled the Middle East for so long. But closer to home, I hope that the UN peace plan, which Australia has played a part in putting together to solve the problems in Cambodia, will come back into focus in our own region. Only the UN has the opportunity of bringing together a peace arrangement in Cambodia that will stop what has been a 50 year war in one form or another in that part of South East Asia.

Burma is a country that is hardly ever heard of in publicity in the west because it has been locked away for nearly 35 years now. It has a military dictatorship which has totally rejected the democratic result of an election in May last year. When we raise issues about democracy and human rights in Burma, I hope that the military leaders of that country will not take so lightly the UN's decisions on debates about what they are doing to their own people. Various civil wars have been fought in the Horn of Africa-Ethiopia, Somalia and Sudan. Unfortunately in the past many of them were provided as proxies for superpower rivalry.

I hope that the people involved in those countries now understand that the UN will be better able to get a peace settlement. Discussions are now going on in respect of the 30-year war between Eritrea and Ethiopia because the superpowers have agreed that this long, needless war can have a negotiated settlement. Even one of the worst political leaders in the world, who has created so much misery for his own people, Mengistu in Ethiopia, is starting to respond to pressure. He is talking about parliamentary democracy, and agreeing to the Eritreans having federal autonomy within Ethiopia. If such things had been agreed to 30 years ago by Emperor Haile Selassie, hundreds of thousands of Eritreans and Ethiopians would not have been killed.

I refer to another long running dispute that is taking place in the Western Sahara. This is an issue that most Australians would not have heard about. I do not know too much about it, other than the fact that for some 15 to 20 years there has been a form of guerilla war taking place in that area. That happened because the superpowers neutralised the effectiveness of the UN and it was unable to get a settlement of that dispute. As a result, many ordinary citizens in that area lost their lives or have suffered appallingly.

There have recently been successes in the UN because the superpowers have agreed to a new order. For example, the superpowers were able to impose a settlement on the recalcitrant countries of Angola, Cuba and South Africa, to enable Namibia to attain its independence. I was in Namibia only a few weeks ago as that country celebrated its first anniversary of independence. Namibia now has bright prospects of prosperity for its people as it has adopted a democratic constitution with democratic features and a democratic parliament.

Discussions, debates and negotiations are now taking place to try to bring an end to long-running civil wars in countries such as Angola and Mozambique. Maybe they will come to an end again because the superpowers are agreeing that the UN is the appropriate body to resolve these disputes. Therefore, I think the Prime Minister in his statement is right to talk about a new order. The bottom line of a new order is that the UN will be able to protect more people from being killed by tin-pot dictators and idiotic military leaders around the world. I believe that the United Nations also will be able to encourage countries in the developing world, the Third World, to adopt more democratic features in their form of government.

One matter that has not been remarked upon is that the countries that took on Saddam Hussein are democracies. Those countries had to debate whether to go to war. Their representatives have to stand up in forums such as this to explain to the people why such action is necessary. That is something Saddam Hussein has never had to do: he has never had to explain to his people. All of the countries that were involved in this dispute that took place many miles from their shores-countries in western Europe, the North Atlantic countries, and Australia-are democracies. I concede that some of the Arab countries that were in the allied coalition are not democracies. But I hope that as a result of the UN success, as a result of the successful allied military initiatives to free Kuwait, the feudal features of Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and the Arab Emirates, the military dictatorships in Iran and Syria, can be ameliorated so that the people in those countries can live a better lifestyle and have a better choice of the government they need and the government they want.

I argue that as Australia has participated in the allied effort to free Kuwait, we now have a moral right to say to Kuwait, to Saudi Arabia, to Syria or to the other Arab countries that we want them to improve the human rights of the people in their countries. We have the right to say that we want them to adopt democratic features and all the features that we in this country and the countries in the rest of the Western world hold so dear. If one asks the ordinary citizens in the Middle East-in Syria, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the Arab Emirates or Iran-whether they want a form of government in which they have some say or a dictatorship, overwhelmingly they will say that they want a choice of government. They want the right to criticise their governments or to change them.

I think that out of this very unfortunate episode of the Gulf war we may have the opportunity to encourage those countries in the Middle East that are not democratic to adopt more democratic forms of government. Australia has the right to put on the public record that that is what we want. As a member of the Labor Government, I shall certainly be encouraging our Government to put that on the public record.

The fundamental issue in the Middle East is that of the Palestinians and the associated issue of Lebanon. We will not get overall peace in the Middle East unless the Palestinians get their own homeland. It has been Labor Party policy for two decades that we support the right of Israel to live in secure negotiated borders, and also the right of the Palestinians to have a homeland with secure borders, with the Israelis and Palestinians living in peace as neighbours. I think the opportunity has now been established where we, again as a country which has participated in the allied effort to free Kuwait, should demand of the various players in the Middle East in the Palestinian-Israeli dispute that there be a peace conference in which all forces come to the table to negotiate, including the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO).

Although I am critical of the PLO for the way it supported Saddam Hussein in a number of aspects in this war, I do not deny the right of the PLO to be a central force in the negotiations for a Palestinian homeland. Still the PLO represents the overwhelming aspirations of the Palestinian people. I am sure that if the dispute in the Middle East between Israel and Palestine is resolved, getting a peace settlement for Lebanon will be so much easier.

I congratulate the Australian armed forces who have participated in the allied effort on the outstanding way in which they carried out their duties. They deserve every commendation from this Parliament and from the Australian people. I do not think that is in dispute anywhere.

The Australian Labor Government took a tough, courageous decision in August last year to support the resolution from the United Nations calling for the unconditional withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait and for the imposition of sanctions. I remember in this place in August and September last year that we were criticised for sending our ships to impose the sanctions on Iraq and to make them effective. Yet by early January of this year we were being criticised for not giving sanctions enough time to work by the very people who did not want us to make sure that those sanctions worked by sending our ships there to carry out the naval blockade of Iraq.

Right from the beginning we have been up-front in our involvement in the UN in supporting the resolutions and in the UN allied force. I think that brings great credit to this country. In five years' time or in 50 years' time it will be written that the decision of the Australian people and the Australian Government was correct. I think that is something of which we can be proud.

Although there has been large loss of life, particularly among the unfortunate conscripted Iraqi soldiers, I believe that in the end we will get out of this a stronger UN which in future will make it impossible for the Saddam Husseins of this world to take action such as Iraq did in August of last year when it invaded and took over another country.

I believe that the UN has given notice in its efforts over the last seven or eight months that tin-pot dictators have had their day. I hope that we can use our clout within the UN to argue against those dictators and their abuse of human rights. That is something which, in the long run, will stand the UN and this new world order in good stead. Therefore, I commend the Prime Minister for his statement. I commend the Prime Minister and the Government of which I am a part for their courageous role in ensuring that we stood up for the cause that was good and right, that is, opposing oppression by a military dictatorship against another nation. I commend the statement to the Senate and to the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the parliamentary statement on the Gulf crisis made on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) earlier today. I only want to make a few points. The main thing that I wish to say to the Senate is that the debate so far has been marked by a considerable non sequitur in the logic which is used to support the actions that have been taken with respect to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Very often in life one is faced with two mutually exclusive choices. If one takes one of those choices and certain things happen afterwards, it is not logical to assume that the other choice could not have led to the same outcome. That is the flaw in logic which lies behind the Prime Minister's statement and most of the comments which have been made upon it.

SPEECH.PARA: The position of the Australian Democrats is that we totally support the resolutions of the United Nations. The resolutions of the United Nations decried the invasion, they called for the withdrawal of the Iraqi occupation from Kuwait and they called, finally, under resolution 678, for measures to be taken including, if necessary, the use of force. At that stage everybody, including a number of spokespeople for the Government, recognised that sanctions were in place, that sanctions were being very effective and that sanctions would not bring about the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait within the little time which had been allowed-five months.

We have seen the prosecution of a war which, clearly, is a mutually exclusive choice compared with the continued imposition of sanctions, and which has resulted in the devastation of Iraq and the eventual withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait. But it does not logically follow that had the alternative course been pursued-had sanctions been kept in place for some further period of months-exactly the same outcome may not have been achieved without the considerable loss of life and destruction of property which has followed.

It is a simple matter of logic and it seems to have escaped everybody who has entered this debate tonight. I am not surprised that Senator Schacht does not see the illogic of his argument. I was a bit surprised that Senator Durack, with his legal training, did not see that what he was really arguing was not logical, that it was a non sequitur.

Equally, it may well be that sanctions may have been kept in place for another three or four months, that Saddam Hussein himself may have started a military conflict and that we may well have finished up with very much the same situation that we now find ourselves in, that is, we may have been forced to use military force. What we regret above everything else is that for the first time-and this is where I come back to what Senator Schacht was saying-the nations of the world had come together and applied almost universal sanctions. Those sanctions were working, but they were not given sufficient time to see whether they would have achieved the desired outcome, namely, the withdrawal of Hussein from Kuwait without the absolutely incredible loss of life.

Let us remember that 100,000 to 200,000 people have lost their lives in this conflict, that the estimated cost of the war is $255,000m and that there have been absolutely enormous environmental costs. We face the largest oil spill the world has ever seen in an area where there are unique species which may well disappear for ever. We have seen the deliberate setting on fire by the Iraqi forces of some 700 or the majority of Kuwait's oil wells with massive air pollution, massive additions of greenhouse gases and massive loss of resources which the world desperately needs because oil is one of the most precious of fossil fuels. It is really in very short supply when one thinks of the totality of human existence on the face of this planet.

I cannot say that those consequences may not have happened had we continued with sanctions any more than others can argue that we went to war because this was the only way that this very serious problem could be solved. The point I wish to stress is that we have lost an opportunity to establish a much better new world order, one in which the nations of the world come together and do not force a recalcitrant dictator-led nation to toe the line by the use of military force, with $255 billion worth of damage. We have lost the opportunity to see whether we could have achieved exactly the same end without that enormous damage to property and enormous damage to life.

Several years ago I was in the Middle East. I was part of a delegation as you will know, Mr Deputy President, because you led the delegation. You will recall that, as we flew over Saudi Arabia and having landed in Abu Dhabi, we looked out of the aircraft and we could see these perfectly green circles on a sandy white desert. We were told afterwards that they were areas where the Saudis were growing wheat under irrigation. The wheat was being sold at four times the then world price.

We also learnt later on that the water tables throughout that region were dropping so fast that within a very short period the aquifers would have dried up. Essentially, they were exploiting fossil water. We also learned on that trip that by the year 2000 that situation would obtain throughout the Middle East; that there would be no ground water left in Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Syria, Jordan, Israel, Palestine, Lebanon and, indeed, right down into Egypt; and that whole populations of many tens of millions of people would be dependent entirely upon annual rainfall.

I believe very firmly that the reason we chose a military solution to this problem so rapidly and so readily was quite simply the desire to have continued access to oil. Of all the United Nations resolutions-a list longer than one's arm-none has been prosecuted with the vigour that resolution 678 was prosecuted. Reflecting on what Senator Schacht has just said, I hope that the United Nations will now take up resolution 242 with respect to the Palestinians and that the Government of which he is a part will see that the United Nations takes that up most vigorously. None of those other United Nations resolutions have been prosecuted in this way simply because a significant resource, in terms of Western needs, was not involved.

The reason I mention water is that this resource war in the Middle East will be as nothing compared with the resource wars of the future unless the new world order includes doing something about equitable access to resources, about the increasing population, which is becoming dependent upon those resources; and about helping deprived people around the world have a fair share of access to the resources. Of course, that also means the sorts of democratic revolutions to which Senator Schacht drew our attention.

One of the other things that will be a necessary and absolutely vital component of the new world order is that we must stop the international trade in arms. I hope that in view of what Senator Schacht has said and what others have expressed tonight about dictatorships-Senator Schacht said that it is `only dictators that start wars'-perhaps as a first effort, Australia should move in the United Nations a motion to completely ban the movement of arms internationally to any nation which is not ruled by a democratically elected government. There are very few countries around the world ruled by democratic governments.

It seems to me that those, in this chamber and outside, who have accused the Democrats of appeasement with respect to Hussein have totally ignored the fact that throughout eight years of the Iraq-Iran war, throughout a period when the Iraqis were bombing their own Kurdish citizens with poisoned gas, it was the Western nations which turned a blind eye to those atrocities and continued to supply arms to that obvious, brutal dictator and it was the Western nations, including the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which created the ability of Hussein to prosecute that war and to carry out the invasion in the way he did. If there is one thing which must mark this new world order, it must be that we stop the trade in international arms. Let us stop initially by not trading with any country which is not ruled by a democratic government. Not that one has not seen the overthrow of democratic governments and their replacements by dictators. One only needs to point to the example of Chile, which had a democratically elected government that was overthrown at the instigation of the United States and now lives under a brutally repressive dictatorship. I certainly extend the idea to stopping the international trade in arms altogether.

The other thing that I remark on, which relates back to statements that I have made on many occasions in the Senate, is that in recent days a number of newspaper articles have been looking to the opportunities for trade and for economic advancement in Australia and other countries presented by the wholesale destruction of Iraq. Several economic commentators have pointed to the way in which inflation will be down, economies will boom and gross national products will rise because of the need to repair the $255,000m worth of damage caused by this war. I simply draw attention to the fact that the way in which we do our economic analyses, which leads us to those sorts of conclusions, should also lead us to conclusions that some of the ways in which we do our economic analyses are deeply flawed and not in keeping with real human values.

As Senator Powell said earlier, we also welcome the return of the sailors and soldiers from overseas. They are people who enrolled in the armed forces to do their duty. They have done their duty and they have done it well. We have no argument at all; we have only praise for those people. It is with our Government and with the other governments which so precipitately, in our view, took a course at a time when it was not necessary to take that course, when more time could have been given for sanctions, that our argument over this war lies.

I simply repeat my earlier assertion that it is not logical in any sense at all to assume that the outcome that we now have-namely, the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait-could have been achieved only in the way it has been achieved. Although one cannot prove this, it may well have been achieved through sanctions. That conclusion is just as logical as the one that has been drawn by many other people tonight, and it is a great pity. It is a great step backwards in terms of the effectiveness of the United Nations as a peacekeeping force in this world that that opportunity was not allowed to run a reasonable course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like all speakers, I am glad that the killing is over and, I hope, permanently. Like all speakers in this debate, as I said earlier today, I am glad that no Australians were among the many casualties. I am also very glad that the Australian forces will be home safely and, I hope, soon, to be reunited with their families. Indeed, they will be welcome home. But, unlike most other speakers, I will not wax lyrical about the rightness of might, the triumph of the United States led forces-better called the cash box coalition-or herald in the so-called new world order. I will say more about that later.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to disagree with most other speakers, both here and in the other place, that it was a just war. I am very, very sad that Australia participated in this war and that Australian service men and women were put at risk by a Labor Prime Minister quickly and foolishly rushing in to support a military solution to the crisis in the Gulf. This was not a war that we had to have. It should never have come to war and, as I have said many times since August, all other options were not exhausted-far from it. I support what Senator Coulter has just said about the fact that sanctions should have been given more time to work. I totally reject the claim of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his speech today:
We only accepted the need to fight when it became clear that there was no other way to reverse the aggression of Saddam Hussein and to free Kuwait.

That is simply not true. We did not try every other way. We did not give sanctions a chance to work. We did not work hard enough in the diplomatic area. I do not think that Australia made one creative, diplomatic move to try to solve this crisis and, after all, that is the job of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). I am afraid to say that he failed badly once the Prime Minister had committed Australia to the path towards war.

I am proud to have participated in the peace movement's opposition to this war. Australians' voices were not heard by our Government, but the residue of disquiet within the community and within the Australian Labor Party will not suddenly disappear. Anti-war voices were raised and heard in many countries and in all countries which sent forces to the Gulf. All countries found that there was great opposition to the war mentality and to the prosecution of that war. Although our voices were unheeded by the powerful forces of militarism, I am proud to have stood against that tide which must become the way of the future if humanity is to survive.

Critics in Australia have claimed that the peace movement has failed and that might has proven to be right as a result of what is superficially seen as the speedy victory by the US-led coalition forces in the Gulf. In retrospect, a number of points need to be made for the record. The peace movement in Australia and I believe overseas as well-from all that I have read and heard from my colleagues overseas-was never in favour of appeasement and I do not know of anyone in Australia who advocated letting Saddam Hussein maintain his grip on Kuwait, despite the reference by the Prime Minister to the lessons of the 1930s.

Contrary to some claims made in this chamber by honourable senators who should have known better-because they claim to have been members of the peace movement, although we never saw them at any peace movement demonstrations against this war-that we had not been critical of Iraq, condemnation of Iraq's aggression in Kuwait was clear and constant from those who opposed the war. Like those who supported the war, we were adamant that Iraq had to leave Kuwait. What we disagreed about was how Iraq should be removed. In the end, the war option was quicker than sanctions would have been, but the human and environmental costs are far more expensive than the sanctions option would have been. As Senator Coulter has pointed out, we will never be able to prove that sanctions would not have worked because they were never given a try.

We will probably never know the full extent of human casualties in this war. The estimates of 75,000 and 100,000 are probably conservative ones. There were the young men drafted into the Iraqi military, the civilians who were what the Pentagon now clinically refers to as collateral damage in bombing raids on military targets in Iraq, those who died in Israel as a result of Scud missile attacks, the casualties of the coalition forces and the Asian migrant workers-all of these were victims and represent the real cost of war, along with the victims of Iraqi repression in Kuwait. There were many victims on all sides.

These victims of war often seem to be forgotten as the military planners work out their strategies and even afterwards as the politicians who sent victims to their death claim victory. Where is the angst being expressed by anybody for the victims of this dreadful butchery which we have seen in the Middle East? Those who profit are the political leaders whose popularity rating always increases in time of war and the merchants of death who sold the weapons to Iraq during the last decade and who are now rubbing their hands with glee at future sales prospects in the Middle East-that is, unless we learn from our mistakes. We have only to look at the recent massive increase in share market values for companies such as Raytheon, Boeing and General Dynamics to see the proof of the obscenity of this trade by the merchants of death.

With reference to the global arms sales, I am glad that Senator Ray has said that he for one is thinking about the issue. I hope that he will have the foresight to withdraw Government support from the Australian International Defence Equipment Exhibition 91, the huge arms bazaar planned for Canberra in November this year. That withdrawal of Government support may lead to its cancellation, as happened with the Pacific Area Defence Equipment Exhibition in 1986. Interestingly, the Prime Minister forgot to mention the arms trade in his speech. What a gross omission. There was not one word in his statement about arms sales. After all, if we and other countries with which we choose to associate very closely had not been party to the arming of Iraq, this diabolical invasion of Kuwait would never have occurred and the war would never have occurred either.

Another huge omission from the Prime Minister's speech was the role played by the United States bases on Australian soil-much more significant than the contribution of our three warships in the Gulf. The war fighting role was not acknowledged by the Government but it was absolutely crucial. Those bases have got to go. Their negative value has now been absolutely proved beyond doubt, but it is a value which our Government will not admit to. These bases could be legitimate on Australian soil only if they were genuinely under United Nations control, and that is not the kind of UN activity which we have seen in the last few months-a United Nations which has been severely badgered and bullied by one of the members of the Security Council. That is the only way that we could allow these bases to continue on Australian soil, because their war fighting prowess has been proved. The fine-tuning of the targeting would not have been possible without the satellite pictures transmitted through Pine Gap.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should be glad of that. It made it much more accurate.

—Of course it made it that much more accurate. Is Senator Newman interested in killing human beings? Is that her goal? Is that what she likes-killing human beings? The result of correct targeting is the death of human beings. That is what people on that side of the chamber seem to forget. They seem to ignore that there are dead bodies-over 100,000 of them-as a result of the accurate targeting that comes through bases such as Pine Gap on Australian soil. Those bases have got to go and the Government has to admit to the fact that that is the role of those bases on Australian soil. They are there to help with the war fighting strategies of our ally, and that is exactly what they did in this war. It was a very crucial role too, but the Prime Minister never mentioned it in his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Now I am concerned about the future and what happens following this debacle. One of my staff was in the Middle East in June 1967 when the six-day war saw a fast Israeli military victory against Egypt, Syria and Jordan. He recalls how he went over from the West Bank to Israel and how everyone there assured him that at last there would be peace now that Israel had beaten the Arabs for the third time in 20 years. Having lived on the West Bank for a year, he begged to differ and said that although Israel might have won the war it would not win the peace unless it was a just peace. History has shown that he was correct. Triumphalism was the mood in Israel in June 1967, just as it is today in the United States. But peace is much harder to build, especially in a part of the world where the bitterness goes back many decades.

I am not optimistic about any settlement in the Middle East if there is a permanent US presence in the region acting as a focus for extremist anger and frustration. I certainly hope that Australia does not again fall into the trap of following the United States if its forces remain there. Our ships should be brought back immediately unless there is a United Nations peacekeeping force installed which would have to be very different in character from the cash box coalition which Australia so quickly and readily joined.

I do not feel confident that the United States will put the hard word on Israel to talk to the Palestine Liberation Organisation for extremist movements such as Hamas make even the PLO seem like doves by comparison. Any student of the Middle East knows that the PLO represents the vast majority of Palestinians and that if Israel will not talk to the PLO there is really no-one else to talk to. If the Prime Minister of Israel had said last year that he would open talks with the PLO there would have been no war over Kuwait. In the end, Israel will have to talk to the PLO, or there can be no peace. Sooner or later the demographic factor will overwhelm that country. Many nations have appeared and disappeared in less than 100 years. Israel could be one of them if it does not face up to reality. I sincerely hope that Israel avoids such a fate.

There are many questions to ask about the future role of the United Nations. Obviously the current situation is thoroughly unsatisfactory. This was never a United Nations war; nor was there any consensus that the war option was the right way to proceed-whatever the Prime Minister said in his statement about victory in the Gulf being won by the United Nations. It was more war by default in the absence of any other applicable mechanism. I believe that the United Nations was set up, as the preamble of the UN charter says, to save succeeding generations from the scourge of war; not to rush into war options again and again as fast as possible.

There have been considerable doubts about the way in which the United Nations handled this war, given the lack of any effective existing structure to respond to the kind of aggression that occurred on 2 August last year. The Prime Minister echoed the United States Government in arguing that the war was acceptable in terms of the UN charter, but other qualified experts on UN procedure have grave reservations about this analysis. The United States, supported by Australia, took the position that article 51 of the UN charter, which affirms the right of individual and collective self-defence, allowed the United States to liberate Kuwait by armed force. The critics argue that this ignores the specific language of article 51. This permits:
. . . individual or collective self defence . . . until the Security Council has taken measures necessary to maintain international peace and security.

Once the Security Council has adopted collective security measures under chapter VII of the charter, as it did with the sanctions initiated in August last year, member states, they would argue, are constrained by the charter from acting unilaterally or multilaterally to launch an attack. Essentially, the United Nations has to be given time to try all possible non-military forms of resolving a conflict before resort to armed force is taken up as a final option-and that was not done.

The United Nations was established to put an end to fighting, not to authorise the kind of high-tech slaughter that we saw in the Arabian desert last month or the bombing of cities, even if the planes were ostensibly seeking military targets. The key to a well ordered world is not the endowment of the United Nations with the coercive capacity of a planetary police force operating in the interests of the industrialised world, but the power of the credible threat of collective action to create conditions for seeking peaceful and diplomatic solutions to international disputes. It is a mystery to me that anyone can justify the deaths of perhaps 100,000 people or more in the name of the United Nations.

Another question mark hangs over the funding of these military operations. It is obvious that the United States cannot afford to lay out the kind of money that the Gulf war cost in order to counter every act of aggression that may occur in the last decade of the twentieth century. Member countries of the United Nations would be squandering scant resources were the United Nations to go on a war footing every time there was a resource dispute or a power struggle in which the United States decided to engage, trying to take the Security Council with it.

Obviously, massive reform is needed in the United Nations. It is very obvious that high-tech weapons cost a fortune. So does transporting tens of thousands of service men and women around the world. The United States and its allies hope to recoup the costs of the war by demanding reparations from Iraq, just as the allies demanded reparations from Germany after the First World War. I cannot help but ask whether the United States has any intention of paying reparations in Vietnam and Cambodia 16 years after a devastating war finished in Indo-China. Of course, we have not seen that happen.

That brings me to my next point-the issue of selective indignation. There have been many letters to the press since last August drawing our attention to other acts of aggression condemned by the United Nations but ignored by the great powers when it did not suit their interests to take action. I have already had a pathetic excuse given in response to a question I addressed last year to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade about the parallel between East Timor and Kuwait-a dismissive reply. Others have drawn attention to the occupation of northern Cyprus by Turkey in 1974; the occupation of Tibet by China; the occupation of West Papua by Indonesia; and, of course, the occupation of southern Lebanon, the West Bank, Gaza and the Golan Heights by Israel-all since 1968. There was also the case of Iraq when it invaded Iran in 1980. The world community did nothing about that. Indeed, some 26 countries sold arms to both sides over the following eight years. It was the debt that Iraq incurred due to its massive expenditure on arms that in part led to its decision to invade Kuwait.

Despite the new-found enthusiasm by the United States for the United Nations, the United States Government has never given an adequate explanation of the difference between its intervention in Grenada and Panama and Iraq's act of aggression against Kuwait. The United States seems to engage in these invasions and expect the rest of the world to stand by and silently applaud it, as of course Australia did, much to my shame. I also believe that there must be substantial changes to the UN Security Council, as I said, reflecting the world that we live in almost half a century after the end of the Second World War.

I will address the issue of the new world order, given that Mr Hawke referred to it in the last part of his statement. He said that the end of the Cold War has ushered in a new world order, whether we like it or not. I do not know what was very new about the industrialised world lining up against Iraq in what was essentially a resource war triggered off by Iraq's post-war problems and its invasion of Kuwait last August. Nor do I know what was new about the use of superior fire power to win a war, right or wrong. A most perceptive editorial in the Canberra Times on 27 February observed:

The danger is that the next decade will be one of such disturbing upheavals that such qualities as humanity and commonsense might be obliterated. The winding up of the Cold War will certainly defuse the stand-off between the US and the USSR but it will also flood the world with surplus bombs, military aircraft and destroyers and turn loose into civilian life millions of demobilised soldiers.

I find that very worrying. This process is already under way with the United States intending to move tanks from Europe to Egypt that would otherwise have been destroyed. Doubtless, the Soviets will want to push their old military hardware in the Third World in order to raise cash from overseas while they are in such an economic mess. France and Britain have shown few scruples over selling military equipment, while Germany was so embarrassed by the revelation that it had supplied Iraq with the wherewithal to make chemical weapons that it is now offering Israel millions of deutschmarks as conscience money. It is not only the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, who has spoken about this new world order, but we have yet to hear from its proponents in the US exactly what it is. It is one of these undefined euphemisms that is very conveniently thrown around.

The most perceptive comment on the new world order to date has come from Neal Acherson, whose article on the subject was reprinted in the Canberra Times on 24 February. He asserted that the war in the Gulf was not the beginning of the new world order but the last act of the old one. He quoted the historian Immanual Wallerstein, who wrote in the Berlin Tageszeitung that the great American peace is now ending, not beginning. He went on to claim that we are not moving from a situation in which world peace is secured, but in the opposite direction. He drew a parallel with past empires which have felt it necessary to go on sending armies across continents and fleets across oceans long after they have ceased to be able to afford it. He foresaw a world where there would be three power centres: North America, Japan and Europe. Around them there would be grey margins, which would include North Africa and the Middle East, the Soviet Union, and the southern cone of South America. These countries will seek to enter the walls of the power centres and to become part of them. The article states:

Correspondingly, the power centres have an interest in keeping them out for as long as possible, maintaining them as dependent territories which provide raw materials and food and migrant labour when required and which will absorb the small part of foreign trade which is not exchanged between the rich three.
I suspect that Australia will see itself in this category. Already we are being marginalised with regard to wheat sales in the Middle East. It is unfolding right before our very eyes.

Beyond the grey areas, there is the third helpless zone where most of the wars will be fought. This is a pretty depressing scenario, I must admit. The ideological enemy of the rich three will be nationalism, not communism. There are two kinds of nationalism: the genuinely dangerous kind that threatens the interests of the rich three, as Saddam Hussein did; and the tame sort, which can even be useful to the rich three at times. Neal Acherson warns that there will be much conflict as tame nations make the transition to dangerous ones. He writes:
Because we in the West have thought it more important to bribe their oligarchies than to help their people to justice, they have poverty and tyranny but now also modern weapons.
Second, all the immigration laws and frontier barriers on earth will not keep the people of the grey and helpless zones out of the power centres for ever.

Those who designed the new world order after 1918 and 1945 had the power to enforce it. They do not have that power any longer. We may be entering a time when the rich will be well protected but the rest will be subject to a new degree of lawlessness. I think we in Australia are aware of this situation. We grasp at the coat-tails of the United States for protection but feel anger and hurt when United States agricultural interests come before ours. Finally, Neal Acherson comments that:
To realise, suddenly, that a promised new world order is no more than the dim reflection of the old and dying one, that ahead there is only darkness, is a terrifying experience.

That is why I am very worried about the Prime Minister's statement. It reflected exactly what Neal Acherson wrote in his article. If it is to be a new world order, it must be based on non-military forms of conflict resolution, an equitable distribution of resources and a just price to be paid for commodities. I see no signs of those concerns when the proponents of the new world order speak, mainly because they are not saying anything clear about what the new world order is. In fact, it is the poorest nations which pay the highest price in the Gulf war and its aftermath. I quote from an article by Tom Aston in the Post Courier of Papua New Guinea:
It is the developing world which is paying the true cost of the Gulf war. For the price of five British Tornado jets or six American F15s-around K210 million-
this writer is from Papua New Guinea, a Third World country, which is significant-
the 20 million Africans threatened by famine could be fed for a month.
While the West turns its eyes to the Gulf, the huge impact of the war on the developing nations is being largely ignored.

A handful of oil-exporting countries in the south have made gains, but oil price rises have hit the poor hardest, forcing millions to walk rather than take public transport and denying slum-dwellers and villagers even the luxury of a kerosene lamp at night.
Weak economies have been drained of foreign exchange and, in effect, been hijacked by Washington.
The war, it seems, is not the beginning of a New World Order as President Bush claims, but rather a regression to the politics of insecurity and greed.
A rural clinic in Bangladesh could run for a month and afford to treat 4000 villagers for the price of just one bomb dropped by an American B-52 bomber-$11,000.

I do not have the latest count of how many of those bombs were dropped by B52s, but I know there were something like 75,000 bombing sorties from the US-led coalition forces. That is a lot of bombs; that is a lot of money; that is a lot of villagers going without health facilities, without adequate kerosene for their lamps, and without any transport facilities whatsoever because of this war. The article continues:
In two days, the operating costs of the British military run to $16 million, more than the British government's contribution to African famine relief for the whole of 1990.
For the price of 30 of Saddam's Scud missiles-$6 million-25,000 Eritrean families could be provided with enough seeds and tools to recover from the drought in northern Ethiopia.
Throughout Africa, Asia, the Caribbean and Latin America, it is the poor who are being hit hardest by the rise in oil prices since the Gulf crisis began.

It is very interesting. This writer, a Papua New Guinean, goes on to talk about the new world order and the way in which the United Nations has been largely nullified by the operation of this war. Tom Aston continues:
Rarely has the UN looked so powerless and irrelevant in influencing world events.
The war has halted the unravelling of the ideology of fear, insecurity and military posturing that appeared to have begun with the end of the Cold War.
The possibility of a peace dividend that could have benefitted both north and south has gone. The dividend that could have been used to rebuild the world, is being used to destroy it.

If this is the birth of a New Order then why, for instance, has Washington forsaken Liberia, for so long a client state, where a famine now rages that could be alleviated for the cost of a dozen or so B-52 bombloads?

If this is the birth of a New world Order then surely we can look forward to the West halting the indiscriminate sale of arms of the kind that created Saddam's military machine, that have destabilised so many parts of the developing world and which divert funds that should rightly be spent on agriculture, industry, health and education.

The awful sophistication of the weaponry of both sides in the Gulf conflict bears adequate testament to the fact that for decades the scientific world's most brilliant minds have been engaged in perfecting the means of mass destruction and governments are engaged in marketing the products of their labors abroad or happy to stand back while others do so.

The legacy of misery from the Gulf war will be immense, not just in terms of the suffering caused by the military personnel on both sides, but to the civilians who either perish amid the fighting or flee their homes.

I would urge caring Australians to support Community Aid Abroad's call for funds to assist victims of this war and to encourage the Government to match dollar for dollar the war effort to the tune of $52.5m with a restitution and a peace effort. As a nation, we should be prepared to pay as much for patching up as we have paid for destruction-and we have paid plenty for the destruction.

Another casualty in any war is truth. We were fed such a line of propaganda from our Government and from the American Pentagon machine that I have to admit that I, too, was sucked in to think that the Iraqi military capability was much stronger than in the end it proved to be. It was nothing like the huge military machine that we were led to believe it was.

The real losers in the war are the innocent civilians and military killed on both sides in the war; the scorched earth, which will take years and billions of dollars to clean up; the Third World economies-particularly in south Asia where many of the migrant workers in the Gulf came from; and the Middle East region itself, which faces long term political instability.

The tragedy is that, when there was an opportunity to solve an international crisis by non-military means, the United States led 30 of the world's nations into waging war. This war was protested in each of those countries. War degrades the human spirit. We are all collectively debased by war. It does not solve complex problems such as those of the Middle East. The jingoistic justifications for killing thousands of human beings and for the devastation that has been brought in the name of liberty and democracy ring hollow in the light of the United States' selective indignation to other invasions and tyrannical regimes. On the contrary, as the aftermath will demonstrate very painfully, we are all losers when we engage in the brutality and wastage of war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I am pleased to be able to speak on the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the Gulf crisis. In opening his statement the Prime Minister said that the allied military operations under resolution 678 had been outstandingly successful. He also went on to point out that there had been few losses to the allied forces and that that was a cause for great relief. He also said how proud he was of Australia's task force. If those are the sorts of jingoistic justifications for killing human beings that Senator Vallentine is talking about, I condemn Senator Vallentine while I support the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I am happy to associate myself with the Prime Minister's comments. Those sentiments are ones which I support, as indeed I support the detailed comments by Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Defence, earlier this evening when he spoke of the men and women, soldiers, sailors and airmen, who served in our forces and in the allied forces in the rescue of Kuwait in the Gulf. I too express my joy at the safe return of the first of our men from the Gulf and I look forward with great enthusiasm to the return of the remainder of our men and women. I am delighted that they have not been injured in the Gulf crisis.

What a wonderful word `cease-fire' is. For those of us who have worried and wondered and waited since 2 August, and particularly since the outbreak of the war in January, there could be no more magical word than `cease-fire', something we had all been waiting for and worrying about.

I also remember the debate we had in the Parliament in January. In the five years that I have been in the Parliament, I cannot remember another occasion on which the purpose of the Parliament was more clearly demonstrated. Senator Powell and some of the others in her Party who have opposed the war-and Senator Vallentine, too-have in the past made claims about the parliamentary debate that we had in January and have suggested that it was all a farce and that, decisions having been taken by the Government, the role of the Parliament was irrelevant. I would deny that strongly. I think that those two days of debate were extremely impressive. I was very glad to be one of the senators who took part in that debate. I will never forget it. I hope that I shall never again be in a parliament taking part in a debate on whether our troops should be at war. Having been in this place at that time, I believe it was a flowering of the purpose of the Parliament to see people struggling with the concepts, struggling with a competition of principles, if you like, as to how they stood personally on the issue. It brought out the worst perhaps in some people, perhaps a few people; but for many it brought out the best. I think that was one of the finest hours of the Parliament, certainly in my time.

After the joy of the cease-fire and the pride in our personnel has to come a quiet assessment of where we have arrived. For every death and disability caused by this war there will be lasting anguish. We have a responsibility now to do our utmost to ensure that a lasting peace is found to salve that pain and to prevent more anguish and pain.

Tonight I intend to leave it to others to discuss the issues relating to the Middle East. I have already spoken twice in this chamber on this issue; once in January and once a couple of weeks ago. Tonight I will speak briefly about Senators Coulter and Vallentine, because there were some comments made by both of them to which I took some exception.

Senator Coulter paid great attention to the massive use of greenhouse gases and the loss of oil.
