He told us that sanctions might have been kept in place for three or four months and then we might have been forced to use the military option. He seemed to have little or no concern for the massive loss of life, the torture, the rape and pillage in Kuwait; yet he was prepared to allow sanctions to continue even longer than they did. It was during this time that this loss of life, torture, rape and pillage took place in Kuwait. I cannot understand somebody who would give the effect of greenhouse gases and the loss of oil a higher priority than the damage to human beings in Kuwait.

Senator Vallentine spoke somewhat on the same theme. She got really worked up and told us that sanctions should have been given time to work and that we did not try every other way. She talked of the victims of the war seeming to have been forgotten. Senator Vallentine did her usual stunt of coming into the chamber when she was about to speak, speaking and leaving. I only wish that some of the people who returned her to Parliament were aware that this is her normal contribution to the Parliament; it is a very perfunctory attendance in the chamber.

Senator Vallentine seems to claim some moral ascendancy over the remainder of the Senate. I take great exception to this because if she had been here throughout the debate she would have heard numerous senators on both sides of the chamber express sincere and solemn regret in terms of the victims of this war. She would have heard the concern that people here have expressed, as I have just now. Once again, she, like Senator Coulter, gave little or no attention to the Kuwaiti victims-victims from 2 August onwards; not just since the air war or the land war broke out. It started with the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq.

Senator Vallentine also got into top gear when she started to talk about bases on Australian soil. I think it is against her religion to say `joint facilities'. She talked about them in relation to our war fighting capacity. When I suggested to her that those joint facilities might have had a large role to play in the precision bombing that took place in Baghdad-bombing which enabled airmen to select military targets with much greater precision and accuracy than has ever been achieved in any other war, thus leading to a saving of human life which otherwise would not have been possible-she got into the most enormous rage and fury. I think it did her blood pressure no good at all. But those are the facts, whether she accepts them or not. That precision bombing of military targets was, of course, helped by the information that was made available by our joint facilities. We should be proud of it, not ashamed of it.

I want to speak, as others have before me, about the lessons that we have to learn from the commitment which we have just made in the Gulf. These lessons are not ones which should be learnt, tucked away in a cupboard and forgotten.
I was interested when the other night, on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program Lateline, the Russian spokesman Gerardy Gerasimov said:
The most important lesson of this war is that aggression does not pay.
I hope that we do not forget that. I hope that all nations will remember that, because that is perhaps our greatest hope for peace. But aggression can and probably will happen again.

Today in the other place Dr Hewson talked about the principles, as old as the United Nations charter, on which order is based. He said that we are closer today to realising those principles than we have been for over 40 years; that we should be encouraged by that and not sceptical; but that it is right that we should be measured in our recognition of them. We should not delude ourselves that national rivalries and competition will suddenly disappear and that it is right to continue to value strong security relationships with our allies and to be prepared to bear the costs and burdens involved. He also said that the current optimism about international security issues is well placed but that there are many uncertainties. If and when aggression does occur again, we must be prepared. We must make sure that aggression will not pay in the future.

The second lesson is the speed at which the problem arrived last August. It gave us so little time. It gave the world so little time to prepare the forces and the equipment to deal with the problem. I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that when we committed our ships in August we sent them away with weapon systems and communication systems being installed. As they left our shores the systems were being installed and work-up training on them was being undertaken. It was marvellous that there was the ability to get up to speed in such a short time, but we should not have to rely on it. We should have our people trained to the capabilities that they need at all times.
Many of our defence specialists have rested a large part of Australia's strategic planning on the notion that we will have a long lead-up time. I have a copy of the Dibb report in which Dr Dibb said:
. . . Australia faces no presently-identifiable major military threat, and all conceivable threats would be preceded by a build-up of forces and a deterioration in relationships.

These judgements have been refined in successive reviews of Australia's strategic prospects and defence planning requirements, as mentioned earlier. The conclusion that Australia faces no specific military threat, and that substantial threat would take many years to emerge, continues to be valid.

But we had little or no warning of the crisis in the Gulf and we had little or no warning of the Fiji coups or the recent coup in Thailand. We cannot base our planning on warning times. We have to have a trained force with equipment ready to go.

The third lesson that we learn from this Gulf war is that high-tech equipment used on the modern battlefield cannot operate itself. The human component is as important as it ever was. Numbers are no longer the only criteria. Brain power and specialist training are absolutely critical. I was interested tonight in a comment which Senator Robert Ray made and which I support; that is, how interesting it is to compare a volunteer force with a conscript force, as we saw in the Gulf. One can think back to Vietnam, where the Americans last went to war with a conscript force, some of whom did not seem to know what they were fighting for. This time they knew. They were articulate, they understood and they had a commitment. We can compare that with the conscripts in Iraq. Motivation as well as training of intelligent human beings brought to a high level of ability is what we need for a modern defence force.

Precision bombing which so revolts Senator Vallentine can only take place with a combination of high technology equipment and well trained personnel. Today's weapon systems require long and intensive training in order to operate them effectively and with minimal harm to civilians. Training must be undertaken in peacetime so that we can never be caught unprepared. That, of course, applies not only to airmen and precision bombing but also to naval and ground forces and the job which we expect of them.

I was worried when I read evidence given to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade inquiry into the reserves. The Army gave a report to that Joint Committee about the 10 per cent reduction in activity levels applied to the Australian Regular Army in the financial year 1988-89 and the reserve having insufficient operating cost allocations to develop the White Paper directed capabilities, and it went on to say:
. . . to, in some cases, achieve even minimum safe training standards.

That was back in 1989, but the situation continues very much the same. It is at a time like this, when we have sent people away to war and we realise day after day the awful carnage that war can bring, that we must remember for the future that we must see that these people are given the opportunity in peacetime to train sufficiently. We cannot send them away with insufficient training.

I was alarmed recently when I read a report of a court martial into the officers of the HMAS Darwin, in which Commander Warwick Conlin, the officer in charge of the navigation school at HMAS Watson, said that the Navy was trying to train too many officers, but that standards could be improved by reducing the number to allow more people time at sea. The report said that standards of navigation in the Royal Australian Navy have declined. Commander Warwick Conlin said:
Officers spend less time at sea than what they have in the past and that's been the cause of this decline in standards.

We should take note of that warning. We cannot afford to allow the skills so basic to the safe operation of our Navy to be diminished. If that evidence is correct, we should all be concerned about it.

In addition, that court martial was told that HMAS Darwin, which ran aground during naval manoeuvres, had missed out on weeks of vital pre-exercise work-up. The purpose of the work-up was to identify any deficiencies in the ship and its organisation and to change them. HMAS Darwin's work-up was interrupted and it had insufficient time to carry it out. The end result was that HMAS Darwin had barely a week before she sailed for the RIMPAC exercises. That was evidence given by Captain Russell Shalders. We should be alarmed at that evidence.

Once again, I was concerned when only on Saturday, on HMAS Success, a senior sailor was talking to me and spoke about his worries at leaders in the non-commissioned officer (NCO) and officer levels in the Navy being promoted too early and without sufficient experience. All these pieces of evidence which I am putting together tonight seem to me to be directly related to the problems we have had with the retention of experienced personnel. They are a direct consequence, and we cannot allow them to go on. Having invested in recruiting and training the quality young people we need, we must make sure we make the services attractive enough to keep them because the loss of experience levels could be fatal for the training of those coming along behind. There is no substitute; we must pay the insurance premium for continuing peace by supporting a sufficient level of defence funding in peacetime.

Let us not forget that wars are fought by young people. It was clear to anybody visiting our ships that the majority of them are crewed by people under 25 years of age. Our best chance of preserving the peace for Australia is to make sure that Australia appears credibly able to defend itself. That is the best chance of ensuring that our young people will not be required to die for their country. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his speech at the submarine keel laying ceremony in Port Adelaide last Friday said:

A great deal is spoken about defence self reliance. Today, with this submarine and with this construction project, we see the proof of Australia's capacity to provide, as ever before, for its own defence.

However, the reality is that we remain unable to detect illegal entry into our country. We remain unable to protect our shipping from mines. We remain unable to effectively go to the rescue of our nationals in neighbouring countries if opposed. We remain unable to keep sufficient men in the field for any length of time to deal with sustained low level contingencies in northern Australia. As I have already said tonight, we had a mad rush to add weapons and communication systems to the frigates before they could get away to the Gulf and the mobility of our land forces must also be questioned.

In addition to this lack of essential capabilities, the size of the Defence Force has, over the last eight years, been reduced from 72,000 to 67,000. In 1989 wastage from the defence forces reached its highest for the decade. Nine thousand two hundred personnel left, nearly 30 per cent higher than in 1983, the year in which the Government took office. Australia has an armed force totalling 67,467 as at 31 December last year. In the last financial year we spent $9 billion on defence. Both the manpower and the spending are extremely small when compared with the figures for our regional neighbours.

The figures that I quote now are also from the Military Balance, 1989-90. Japan has an armed force totalling 245,000 and spent $US28 billion on defence. India has an armed force totalling 1.4 million personnel and spent $US9.25 billion on defence. Indonesia has an armed force totalling 284,000 and spent $US1.4 billion on defence. China has an armed force totalling 3.2 million and spent $US6.1 billion on defence.

All these countries have reserve and paramilitary forces ranging from 58,000 to 1.8 million. Our reserves total only 29,000. These figures alone would suggest that, in terms of regional threat or military build-up, Australia is not the defence giant of the region, despite what some pacifists would claim. In fact, we are well behind most countries-even those not listed, such as Malaysia, Thailand, and Taiwan-in terms of defence manpower and spending.

It is widely acknowledged by many political and defence analysts that the South East Asia-Pacific region is less stable than most would like to believe. One only has to look at the recent conflicts in Bougainville, Fiji, and Vanuatu, the continuing conflict in Cambodia, the recent military coup in Thailand, and the tensions in India-Pakistan as well as in Myanmar. While the rest of the region is prepared to take steps to defend itself if the need ever arises, some Australians still complain that too much is being spent on defence. Since the end of the Vietnam war, debate on defence has tended to be unfashionable. Only now, because the Gulf war confronted us every night on television, are people being forced to look at defence, and debate has started once again.

The Defence White Paper in 1976 which called for greater independence and self-reliance failed to be implemented and defence equipment was allowed to run down. Eleven years later, in 1987, another White Paper, predicated on self-reliance, was published and well received by many commentators. Four years later this plan is also faltering because the strategic situation is changing and because the necessary finance has not been provided. The Defence Budget has been at its lowest spending percentage of gross domestic product for 40-odd years, at 2.3 per cent GDP. In simple terms, the lack of resources has caused the White Paper to lose its credibility.

Perhaps that is why the Australian Medical Association (AMA) has been forced into taking up a collection to pay for our contribution of medical reservists to the Gulf allies. In his statement today, the Prime Minister said that these service people who are serving on exchange with allied forces, and up to 40 medical personnel serving on the hospital ship USS Comfort, including a number of reservists, have earned the respect of their colleagues and our gratitude for their service.

Some gratitude, when Dr Bruce Shepherd of the AMA says that the attitude of the Government is that these people are wealthy doctors and the Government does not care about the costs they have incurred in their practices while they have been away. The Government has refused to reimburse them for the cost of their practices; so some of them are up for $30,000 apiece to pay their staff, their rents and the leases on their medical equipment while they were away. It is a disgrace that people of Australia have to cough up in an appeal to meet the costs of our medical specialists. That is not just a mean-minded debating point, because the refusal by the Government to pay the costs incurred by the senior medical specialists in the reserve forces may result in our inability to provide experienced surgical and anaesthetic care to our front-line troops in future conflicts. That would be an awful reduction in our defence capability; it would have a serious effect on our ability to deploy in war.

The permanent Air Force made a submission to the joint committee inquiring into the reserves and talked about these vital specialist skills, which were not resident in the permanent Air Force on a full time basis. It said it would not be cost-effective for those skills to be provided on a full time basis. The same applies for the Navy and the Air Force. Come war, those senior surgeons and anaesthetists are needed. They need to be senior because they need to be experienced and able to train others; they need to have had the opportunity to deal with the trauma of war. Junior surgeons will not have had the same experience. We must not forget that lesson.

Before I conclude, I must again mention the fact that this Government has abolished war service loans. Something will have to be done immediately to restore the eligibility of defence personnel for a war service loan if they are deployed to a war zone. It is incredible that we could have sent people away having removed that entitlement which Defence Force personnel have had in Australia since 1917.

The Prime Minister mentioned a number of organisations and government agencies which supported Australia's effort in the Gulf. I shall not go through all the ones that he mentioned, but I note that he did not mention the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. That seems to me to be a strange omission because so much of our capabilities originated from the work of that organisation. The Defence Science and Technology Organisation may be unhonoured and unsung, but some of us recall the important contribution it makes to our defence forces and their capabilities. The Prime Minister also did not mention the 700 personnel who work at Pine Gap and who made a vital contribution to the allied effort in the Gulf. The contribution and the importance of the people at Pine Gap should never be forgotten.

The conclusion of the fighting in the Gulf comes as an enormous relief to us all-a number of speakers in the debate today have mentioned that-but it is especially so for the mothers, fathers, wives and friends of our service personnel. However, it cannot be allowed to signal the end of interest and debate on our ability to defend ourselves and to play our role for peace in the international community. The Opposition has already announced its own defence review. The Government has some serious reassessment to make for itself. The Government has had responsibility for Australia's defence for the past eight years. In many ways it has been lucky that it has not been required to make a greater contribution to our security during those years. Our contribution in the Gulf extended our Navy almost beyond capacity. An extended demand on both our Army and our Air Force would find our defences pretty threadbare and lacking in depth.

While the professionalism of our service men and women has done us proud and is not in question, the reduction in their numbers over the past eight years and the limits on their training resources should be realistically assessed now while the awful memory of war is fresh. While the Government has been lucky in the past, God forbid that we should bank on Australia staying a lucky country in the future. As Dr Hewson said in his response in Parliament today, it is time for a realistic reappraisal of our national defence strategy and the state of our defence resources.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Family Law Amendment Bill and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Family Law Amendment Bill 1990 will introduce a small number of significant amendments to the Family Law Act, particularly in relation to child custody, guardianship and access proceedings.

The most important of the amendments to be made by the Bill are aimed at improving the handling of custody and access disputes in which allegations of child abuse are made by one party against another. In preparing these amendments the Government has been guided by the findings and recommendations made by the Family Law Council in its 1988 Report on Child Sexual Abuse.

Honourable Senators will be aware of increases in recent years in reported instances of child abuse. Child sexual abuse in particular has become a significant issue for the Family Court in a number of cases.

A number of the uncertainties raised by early Family Court decisions on child abuse were resolved by decisions of the High Court in 1988. However other difficulties with the handling of child abuse allegations in Family Court proceedings remain. The Family Court has responded to the problems in this area by establishing appropriate procedures within the Court's administration to process cases involving child abuse allegations. Procedures have also been introduced for better co-ordination with State and Territory child welfare authorities.
The amendments to be made by this Bill are designed to complement the administrative steps already taken by the Family Court in the area of child abuse. The amendments will:
- provide for mandatory reporting of child abuse by Family Court staff to State and Territory child welfare authorities;
- provide legal protection for Family Court staff who report child abuse to child welfare authorities;
- provide for State and Territory child welfare authorities and other interested persons to intervene in cases involving alleged child abuse;
- limit the number of unnecessary medical and psychological examinations of children obtained by parents involved in custody and access disputes;
- insert an express statement in the Family Law Act requiring the Family Court to have regard to the need to protect children from abuse;
- provide protection for medical and other witnesses in child abuse cases from abusive or hectoring questioning.

One amendment to be made by the Bill will give statutory force to the Family Court's established practice of admitting hearsay evidence of statements made by children to adults about abuse they have suffered. The Family Court already admits evidence of this kind because of its long established policy that children should not be drawn into Family Court proceedings by being called as witnesses for either side in a custody or access dispute. The court will retain a discretion to decide whether to exclude the evidence.

Another area of family law in which the Bill will make changes is step-parent adoptions. For many years the formation of step-families usually resulted from the death of a parent. Today, however, many step-families are formed following the breakdown of previous marriages. In these cases both natural parents are still alive and usually maintain continuing relationships with their children.

It has long been an accepted principle in family law that continuing contact with both natural parents is usually desirable in the interests of the long term development of a child. If parents disagree about custody or access to a child following the breakdown of their marriage, the Family Court provides appropriate counselling and if necessary applies the relevant legal principles under the Family Law Act to resolve the dispute.

However in recent years a small number of parents have tried to use adoption to establish a new family unit consisting of the children, one natural parent and a new spouse-the step-parent. One reason a parent may have for seeking to adopt in these cases is that adoption may put an end to any rights the other natural parent may have to custody, guardianship or access to the child. It also puts an end to the other natural parent's liability to pay child support for the child.

In its 1986 Report on step-families the Family Law Council commented on the inappropriateness of adoption as a method of establishing the legal status of a step-child in a step-family. The Council preferred the alternative of a determination by the Family Court of the parties' custody, guardianship and access rights under the Family Law Act.

The Bill will amend the Family Law Act to make it clear that a step-parent adoption does not put an end to existing custody, guardianship or access rights under the Act unless the Family Court decides that the step-parent adoption is in the best interests of the child. The amendments will not affect adoptions other than step-parent adoptions.

The Bill includes other amendments recommended by the Family Law Council to protect the welfare of children. The Bill includes provisions which will stop parents transferring custody or guardianship of children to non-parents by means of Family Court consent orders or by registering child agreements with the Court. These provisions are aimed at ensuring that in future any arrangement that comes before the Family Court that involves conferral of custody or guardianship on non-parents will be scrutinised by the Court to determine whether those non-parents are suitable persons to have custody or guardianship of the child.

The Bill makes a number of other technical amendments to the Family Law Act. I need mention only two of these amendments. In 1989 the Family Law Act was amended to allow the parents of an ex-nuptial child to register an agreement with the Family Court which determines their rights and duties in relation to the custody, guardianship, access and maintenance of the child. The Bill will amend the Family Law Act to provide that these child agreements are exempt from stamp duties. This will ensure child agreements relating to ex-nuptial children enjoy the same exemption as maintenance agreements for children of a marriage.

The other technical amendment I mention is an amendment to clarify the powers of police who are responsible for the enforcement of Family Court orders. The Bill will empower police, who are authorised under the Family Law Act to arrest a person, to enter and search premises for the wanted person. This amendment is necessary to ensure that the police are able to apprehend people who breach domestic violence and other orders issued by the Family Court.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost 100 years ago to the very day, a meeting of historic importance in Australian history was convened in Sydney. This meeting was officially known as the National Australasian Convention. It produced a draft constitution which became the framework for the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia. The meeting was held between 2 March and 9 April 1891. In a well-known quotation Professor La Nauze summed up the work of the Sydney Convention:

SPEECH.PARA: The draft of 1891 is the Constitution of 1900, not its father or grandfather.
He went on to say:

In the years 1897-1900 it was to undergo fairly extensive plastic surgery but it is still recognisable, beneath its scars, its built-up features and the wrinkles of age, as the infant and innocent Constitution which momentarily so delighted its parents.

Australians in the last 90 years have shown a remarkable disinclination to change their Constitution. Since Federation, governments have tried to change the Constitution over 40 times. In fact, only eight referenda have been passed. Whether politicians like it or not, the public have shown a strong disinclination to change the Constitution by referendum.

The main draftsman of the constitutional Bill of 1891 was Sir Samuel Griffith, the then Queensland Premier. He was assisted by Andrew Inglis Clark of Tasmania and Charles Cameron Kingston of South Australia. The principal issue at the Convention, sometimes referred to as the `lion in the path' of Federation, concerned the power of the Senate in relation to money Bills. The debate on this particular issue occupied more time than any other issue at the Sydney Convention.

The Sydney Convention was, in my view, by any standard one of the most important events in Australian history. We can now, with hindsight, assess the achievement of the 45 delegates who attended that Convention. First, they established a framework which enabled the formation of the Australian nation some 10 years later, in 1901. Providing a basis for nationhood is a massive achievement in itself. Contrasting with the view so often promoted by the guilt industry, an industry which has been extremely active during the last decade or so, Australia is a remarkably cohesive and tolerant society by any standard. Opinion polls indicate a high degree of patriotism amongst our people. It is a society which attracts migrants from many different types of societies around the world.

Secondly, it is appropriate to say that our constitutional founders produced one of the world's most successful democracies. In a period when there is a fervent wish among many peoples throughout the world to establish working democracies, the august assembly-as it was called in the press-of 1891 stands as a landmark in the history of democracy. Indeed, it is true to say that there are only five countries in the world today which have a longer democratic history than Australia.

The delegates of the Convention of 1891 were able to draw on the constitutional lessons of Britain and the United States of America. The provision, for example, that there can be no taxation without an Act of parliament, that all revenues must be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund from which moneys can only be appropriated by law, records the victory of Parliament over the Executive in the seventeenth century-a victory which, I might add, needs constant defence.

A related point is that the delegates also produced the foundation for one of the world's most successful federations-a form of government which has tended to produce more failures than successes. A study on federalism around the world argued:
Australia must be regarded as one of the world's most successful federations along with the United States, Canada and Switzerland.

Given the current difficulties that Canada is experiencing, the list of successful federations may well shorten in the years to come. It is interesting that in reviewing their constitutional problems some Canadians are wondering whether the composition of the Australian Senate, based on equality of representation between the States, would have helped maintain more effectively the Canadian federation than the current position of a nominated, unelected Senate chamber. One of Australia's eminent constitutional experts, Professor Rufus Davis, summarised Australia's constitutional achievement as follows:
By the common standards of democratic societies, our constitution has succeeded in any number of ways. It has succeeded in authorising and holding a nation together.
Professor Davis went on to say, among other things:

It has succeeded in building and developing a will for law and order. It has succeeded in providing and proving the possibility for growth and development when there is initiative and consensus. It has succeeded in making and extending the virtues of choice by diffusing the centres of authority.

In view of some of the disasters that we are experiencing among State governments, I believe, speaking as a Victorian, that we can be very thankful that the experimentation of the Cain and Kirner governments was not able to be very effectively translated to Australia as a whole. That was the point that Professor Davis was making.

In view of the intermittent demands for wholesale constitutional change, Professor Davis makes an important observation about the achievements of our Constitution. He says that the Constitution `has succeeded in holding out the wisdom of change by evolution'. He points out that inevitably a constitution always is and must be a system of limitations-that is, the submission of government to an agreed system of restraints. Professor Davis says:

This is a fragile tradition that is so vital to preserve for Australia. But we cannot foster this tradition by a belief that a constitution can be treated like a suit, or a piece of furniture, or a machine that can be made over or discarded whenever a contentious mood, fashion or vision of public welfare occupies and obsesses the changing occupant of a throne.
Professor Davis concluded, and this is relevant to my conclusion:

If we cannot inculcate this understanding of our constitution, if we cannot foster the idea that constitutionalism and gradualism go hand in hand, we cannot build a confident basis for our future. Worse, we court caesarism if we believe that we can dramatise our passing prejudices every few years to rationalise the need for wholesale constitutional revision.

Despite our constitutional achievement, how many Australians know anything about the august assembly of 1891? I would suggest that a minuscule proportion of the Australian public would know anything about these individuals, who in many ways were the founders of the Commonwealth of Australia, and about their work.

A 1987 survey by the Constitutional Commission showed that some 46 per cent of Australians were not even aware that Australia had a Constitution. Ignorance of the Constitution is as high as 70 per cent in the 18 to 24 age group. A recent social studies survey by a leading public sector think-tank, the Institute of Public Affairs, revealed that only 20 per cent of year 10 students know that the Commonwealth of Australia was formed in 1901.

It is worth recording that, despite the massive achievement of the 1891 Convention, not one Australian newspaper on 2 March, 3 March or even today saw fit to commemorate or even mention in any way the centenary of the National Australasian Convention. Parliamentarians must take much of the blame for this ignorance of our history. Perhaps even former lecturers in constitutional law at the universities may also have to take some of the blame. If we show so little regard for the founders of our federation, how can we criticise the public?

As I recorded in an adjournment speech last year, we have virtually ignored the founders of Australia in the portraits and permanent displays in this new Parliament House. We have found space throughout Parliament House for contemporary art to be displayed in prominent positions, yet it has not been possible to hang the portraits of Sir Samuel Walker Griffith, Charles Kingston, Richard Baker, George Reid and Alfred Deakin, some of the leaders of the federation movement.

Nevertheless, I am happy to report that there are some signs that these problems are being addressed. I have received a very positive response from the President and the Speaker about my earlier concerns on the need to examine the historical displays in Parliament House. I hope that the noticeable gaps will be quickly filled. It is clear that the original instructions regarding displays in Parliament House were deficient and clearly lacked an appropriate historical perspective. I hope-indeed, I am confident-that the President and the Speaker will not allow a similar mistake to be continued.

I am also delighted that the President has encouraged the Department of the Senate to develop a temporary exhibition and hold a series of lectures to commemorate the centenary of the Convention of 1891. The Department of the Senate is now finalising a temporary display which will open in April. On Thursday this week, Sir Zelman Cowen will give the first lecture entitled, `Is it not time? The National Australasian Convention of 1891. A Milestone on the Road to Federation'.
Does it matter that Australians are so ignorant about their Constitution? As the Institute of Public Affairs points out:

The existence of widespread gaps in students' knowledge remains a problem of national significance, since it has damaging side-effects for both a liberal-democratic polity and an industrialised market economy.
The Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, in a report into active citizenship, argued as follows:

High levels of political ignorance in a community are therefore a danger sign. They point to a situation in which accountability is weak and where power may be concentrating in the hands of a few. They are warning that the quality of democracy may be under threat.

In the lead-up to the forthcoming centenary of the founding of Australia in 1901 and, of course, the adoption of the Constitution, we have a unique opportunity to honour the founders of the Australian nation and redress the appalling ignorance of our Constitution. Indeed, planning for the celebrations will undoubtedly commence in the next year or so.

There are some important lessons to be learned from the 1988 bicentennial celebrations to mark white settlement in Australia. Equally, it may be of value to look at the way the United States of America celebrated the bicentennial of its Constitution. Some five years ago the United States Government established a commission to celebrate the bicentennial of the US Constitution. The commission on the bicentennial of the United States Constitution believed that it was important to encourage citizens to learn more about their constitution and how it secured the nation's liberties. It aimed to ensure that through work in schools, business clubs, churches and so on, every citizen could become involved in the bicentennial.

Interestingly, the US commission did not make the same fundamental mistake as the Australian Bicentennial Authority in seeking to use a national celebration to promote political change. Honourable senators will recall that only action by the Government to change the direction and stop the excesses of the Australian Bicentennial Authority helped avoid widespread controversy and division. Honourable senators may recall that the Bicentennial Authority found its original slogan, `the Australian achievement' too embarrassing and decided instead to use the insipid and defensive slogan, `Living together'.

Political change and constitutional change will inevitably occur and should occur, but these should take place in the normal processes of continuing public debate and discussion. Therefore, the lesson we can draw from the 1988 experience is that the focal point of the celebrations in the year 2001 should be on our constitutional achievement, the nation it established and the liberties it secured.

Above all, it should be a period of national pride, of commemoration of the achievements of our people in war and peace, our liberties, freedoms and thanksgiving to our founders. With this goal in mind we can encourage all our citizens to learn about our constitutional achievement, honour the founders of our nation and help secure the legacy of liberty, freedom and federation for another 100 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most Australians are now aware of the fact that there are in circulation in this country a number of documents which reveal the magnitude of malpractice and corrupt practices in Australian banks-a theme which I have been pursuing for 2 1/2 years in this place and which seems to have finally arrived.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Is it possible to table a French letter?

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure Senator Alston that I am not trying to do something surreptitiously. The documents, as I say, to the best of my knowledge are not before the courts. I commend to honourable senators an analysis of these documents which Anne Lampe of the Sydney Morning Herald presented in an article which appeared on 26 February. Honourable senators are probably aware of the fact that Anne Lampe was the journalist who first made public comment about the documents which were referred to as the Belgium letters. As a result of that she is subject to an injunction, but she has persevered very courageously, I believe, on this issue. On 26 February she gave quite a comprehensive analysis of these documents. I commend that analysis to honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that those who are interested in gaining access to the documents will acknowledge on reading them that they are important for several reasons. By their own admission, they highlight the fact that a number of transactions undertaken by Westpac in relation to foreign currency loans were unauthorised foreign currency trading, carried out on behalf of Partnership Pacific Limited (PPL) clients by Westpac staff. The lack of authority for those transactions is emphasised in these documents, and that is important.

I have not explained that these are internal confidential memos from their exchanges of opinions between the Queensland manager of the Westpac arm-that is Partnership Pacific Ltd-and the head of funding and liquidity in PPL. In other words, they are internal discussions about the significance of some of the things that occurred in managing foreign currency loans. The first observation is that they acknowledge that at least some of these transactions were unauthorised. But in many respects the most significant thing they acknowledged was that the transactions were operated from a pool of money. The importance of this cannot be overemphasised because the vast majority of people who transacted foreign currency loans with Westpac at that time believed that they were transacting individual loans in their names.

These documents acknowledge the fact-and this is acknowledged in the other documents, and I have addressed this in this place before-that what happened was that when somebody advanced money in order to transact the loan the money actually went into a pool or a slush fund. The money was used to speculate in foreign currencies, some speculations were profitable and some were not. Some were a disaster. But the outcomes were allocated after the event to the names of individuals who believed that they had entered into quite specific transactions. It is acknowledged elsewhere that the bank incurred no losses, that the losses were all placed upon clients and that the profits were allocated to clients according to the subjective judgment of Westpac-PPL staff. This is quite an extraordinary management of these loans which is acknowledged in the pool concept and the pooling process which is acknowledged within these documents.

Honourable senators will be aware of the fact that previously I have tabled confidential memos of the Commonwealth Bank and outlined a procedure used by the Commonwealth Bank in relation to foreign currency loans which were referred to as simulated loans, pretend loans. I have incorporated in Hansard extracts from the handbook of the Commonwealth Bank as to how to set up simulated loans and how to manage them and project them to customers as having been real. Both of those processes are acknowledged in the internal confidential documents of both Westpac and the Commonwealth Bank. Frankly, the pooling process strikes me as being an extraordinary admission. I will return to the magnitude of this shortly.

The third significant thing about these documents is that they, in fact, openly admit to the suppression of-and they advocate the suppression of-certain documents and that they not be kept in files because they would clearly expose in subsequent litigation certain officers of the bank and the bank at large. They actually suggest that these documents should not appear in files. But on the second page of the document, and these are handwritten, it says that now the memo is written `it may be too late to destroy every copy'- this is the memo which elaborates this difficulty-so that Davis is to ask Phil Deer to speak to all State managers and tell them `not to use the memo as official file'. In other words, it is too late to destroy them all so they have to be suppressed in a way that they are not accessible subsequently to clients. With this concept of suppression and destruction it is absolutely vital that it is noted and recorded. The Senate would be aware that success in subsequent litigation is dependent upon the legal process of discovery of documents.

Those who have been following this case closely will remember the Quade case, which was a case directed at Westpac. A borrower took Westpac to court and lost because he did not have sufficient documentary evidence to carry the case. There were affidavits tabled in the court that the documents available were a total disclosure. Bank officers actually swore on affidavits and swore before the court that there had been total discovery. Subsequently, Quade's appeal was upheld because there was subsequent discovery and that discovery revealed that the affidavits were in contempt of the court. The previous decision of the court was overturned because of more adequate discovery. If one is going to succeed in these cases there must be total discovery. Therese Rahme is a case in relation to which I have tabled information in this place before. I have documented her circumstances at length. She finds herself having to proceed to the High Court of Australia to try to do the same thing that Quade did successfully; in other words, to ensure total discovery of the documents. These documents are saying that Westpac consciously entered into a process of destruction of documents and consciously entered into a process of suppression of documents so that they would not be discovered.

Let us go further and look at an interesting article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 28 February, two days after the previous article which I have referred to appeared. The article, by Tom Burton, refers to the leaked memo. On first reading it is a quite humorous article because it outlines the attempts by Westpac to suppress and to stop the process of leaking that is now occurring, but unfortunately its attempts were in turn leaked. What we had in front of us were extracts from a memo by the Chief General Manager of Westpac, Mr Bill McInnis, who put forward a 10-point action plan to plug up the leaks-damage control stuff. What Mr McInnis actually instructed officers of Westpac to do-and I quote from the article which quotes from the document-was this:
Westpac-related documents of any nature whatsoever shall be mechanically shredded at the end of their use and not disposed of in an ordinary wastepaper bin.

That was a directive to Westpac officers to turn on the shredders; that any Westpac-related documents whatsoever were to be mechanically shredded at the end of their use. There is no definition, to my understanding, within that document of what a document is by definition-in other words, what is to be included and what is to be excluded. There is no definition of the term `end of their use'.

I would suggest to you, Mr Deputy President, that the end of their use will probably be six years down line under the statute of limitations when they may or may not be admitted to the court. I would suggest to you that this is a directive of the Westpac Chief General Manager to initiate a process which may subsequently prove to be a conspiracy to subvert the course of justice. How do we know what documents are going to be relevant at some time in the future to litigation which may be undertaken by some future litigant? That is an extraordinary instruction-a recent instruction-which echoes right now, this month, the philosophy and the policy of these documents three years ago. The magnitude of this scam-it was a scam, a bonanza contrived and exploited at the expense of ordinary Australians-is mind blowing.

Today I received a confidential analysis of the Westpac foreign currency transactions between 1 July 1986 and 7 January 1987-a period slightly in excess of six months. It is an analysis which runs to 24 pages. I will not table the documents because they were given to me in confidence and I was asked not to table them. But I accept them as valid and I believe that, if necessary, they can be substantiated before the bank inquiry. The analysis is this: in that six-month period Westpac alone-Westpac was not the only bank into this bonanza, and I have tabled evidence to that effect over the last 2 1/2 years-traded $5.85 billion in foreign currency loans. The average trading volume per day was $43m from a pool traded speculatively, the outcome of which-profits and losses-was, by the admission of these letters, arbitrarily allocated to clients.

By the admission of other letters, losses were never allocated to banks; losses all fell on clients, and profits were allocated to some clients on an arbitrary basis. That is what was known as the deal switching referred to in the Westpac letters. So we have $5.85 billion traded in a period of six months, with average daily trading being $43m.

In the other letters a process of point taking is referred to, which is skimming off the top; taking a little bit of cream off the top. A conservative estimate of point taking in this period was referred to technically as 20 points, in other words, 0.0020 dollars point taking-0.2 of a cent in each dollar traded. At that conservative estimate, Westpac would have creamed $14m off the top by point taking. If that is a conservative estimate-and some estimates run up to 10 times that-this was a nice little earner that Westpac had going on the side and presumably the other major banks had going on the side as well. Westpac has admitted elsewhere that in doing this, the withholding tax which should have been paid by the bank was actually imposed upon the clients, and it has admitted also that it exceeded its statutory obligations to the Reserve Bank of Australia. The most significant thing was that this was done on a pool basis, on a subjective basis.

The final thing that is significant about these documents is that they clearly establish the bond between PPL and Westpac. Westpac recently began the tactic of distancing itself legally from PPL. The documents and the associated letters that are there for any senator to have access to clearly state that those who were working for PPL were also working for Westpac. I will read letters of clarification about this relationship that were directed to two employees. These letters listed the duties of the employees. Presumably they got a duty statement. The letters said that in performing tasks, they were acting solely as employees of PPL. That seems clear enough. They said they were subject, in the course of performing these duties, to the direction and supervision of PPL. That seems clear enough. Then the letters go on to say:

. . . during the course of your employment with PPL, you continue to be employed by Westpac Banking Corporation and continue to hold the office and perform the duties for Westpac as it may from time to time direct. Notwithstanding . . . your salary, annual leave, long-service leave, superannuation and other benefits (payable or accruing under the terms of your employment with Westpac) shall continue to be met by Westpac.

There seems to be an extraordinary contradiction within two paragraphs. On the one hand they are employed by PPL, and yet on the other hand they are employed by Westpac. The realities were that PPL was finally absorbed by Westpac and has now been totally absorbed by it. They are one and the same entity as far as this bonanza and scam are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, dear!

—Whether Senator Evans or others are prepared to accept the consequences of this, there are people out there, namely borrowers, who will pursue this until they go to their grave-and some of them have-because they know that they will not extract justice from the courts as these documents admit to the destruction of key documents. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: ACT School of Tourism and Hospitality

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer briefly to the Australian tourism awards, the awards which will take place this year and, in particular, the fact that as a consequence of changes to the guidelines for entry, the Reid School of Tourism and Hospitality is not able to take part this year. I am very sorry indeed that this is the case. I am not certain why it has come about or why it is that those who set the guidelines for the awards would set about excluding just one such food school, that is, the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) school.

SPEECH.PARA: To recap-the Australian tourism awards were established in 1984. The intention of, I think, the then Minister, Mr John Brown, was to promote excellence in the industry and encourage the pursuit of improved standards and further growth. The awards were funded through Commonwealth and the host State contributions and sponsorship from within the tourism industry. My clear recollection is that at the time the Minister hoped that they would be run by the private sector in the hospitality and tourism industry and that it would become primarily responsible. That in fact has been the case, although the Commonwealth still contributes about $20,000 each year towards the cost of the award night.

Under one of those categories, that is, training and education, there used to be two subparagraphs, one for private institutions and one for institutional or government. It is now at the national level that these two categories have been combined. As a consequence of that, the ACT school is no longer able to participate. It was apparently decided at a meeting last November that the two categories would be put into one.

The wording is specific. In 1990 the first category was industry, and in the second, under `institutions' it was stated that funding could come from any source, which included government. For 1991 it has been changed to one category and states, `where funding has predominantly come from the private sector'. Whether it was deliberately designed to exclude the ACT food and hospitality school I really do not know and am not able to say, but it is the only such food school in Australia which at this stage does not have its funding primarily from a private source.

I believe it is as a result of its now having a restaurant able to raise funds in a way that it was not able to before. I believe that until the new food school was opened it did not have the opportunity to pursue private sponsorship, as others have done. I believe that it does not have the same opportunity in Canberra to get sponsorship as is available in some of the States. As a consequence, the change which has been made really does discriminate against this very fine institution which is an important part of the tourism and hospitality industry in the ACT.

It seems to me that those responsible for making the decision either did not care or were not concerned about the discrimination against the ACT. If they wanted to change the guidelines to more diligently pursue private sector involvement, they could have at least given one year's notice so that the school could have had the opportunity to make changes to its management and not merely be excluded overnight. It is strange indeed that category one was worded in a particular way in 1990 while, in 1991, it refers to `privately or nationally owned', which would indicate that, in that category at least, government funding does not preclude a tourist attraction from being entered into the tourism awards.

I totally support the concept of the awards being to promote and to encourage the private sector in the tourism and hospitality industry. I just want to place on the record that I think it is very important that in one fell swoop at a meeting at which the ACT was not present, the Australian Tourism Industry Association should have taken a step which eliminated just one of the food schools in this country-that is, the ACT food school.

I urge the Australian Tourism Industry Association next year to so correct its guidelines as to see that this is not the case for the future. By all means it should encourage our school to develop private sector sponsorship to as great an extent as possible, but it should not adopt this sort of attitude.

I urge Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) to look closely at the funding that the Commonwealth gives to the awards, and hopefully it will still continue it. But I think it should be very careful to see that the situation does not arise where in one category alone Government funding is fatal whereas in another category it is still allowed and considered to be an appropriate part of the awards.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that Senator Reid will forgive me if I do not seek to comment on her latest enterprise with the parish pump.
—We cannot all be world statesmen!

—Some of us can work at it; others of us fall comprehensively short. I am sure that the Minister for Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) will be as fascinated as I was with Senator Reid's contribution tonight, and no doubt the record of the Hansard will be passed over.

SPEECH.PARA: The contribution of Senator McLean was yet another instalment in an endless saga. I do not think that it is appropriate for me to comment about the substantive issues he raises. Obviously there are serious public interest questions, and it is entirely appropriate that they be debated in this Parliament.

I simply add to what Senator Alston said earlier on the subject of the tabling of the documents tonight-that is, had Senator McLean been prepared, as a matter of courtesy and familiar procedure, to make available earlier the documents in question, explaining their nature, there would have been no question of his being denied leave earlier in the day. It is unfortunate that he did not take advantage of that process.

As to the contribution of the Senate's resident young fogy, Senator Kemp, on the subject of nationalism, constitutionalism and anniversaries, let me say this: we can admire the work of the 1891 founders and we can deplore the lack of contemporary knowledge of their work without, however, having to commit ourselves to the glory of the changeless and timeless character of all that they produced. As the author of a book back in 1983 on the need to change the Constitution--

TALK.START.PARA: —Author?

—Primary begetter and co-author, I think it would be fair to say. As such, I could not be expected to share Senator Kemp's perception of the current glory of it all, particularly on matters such as Senate powers, some aspects of the distribution of federal powers as between the Commonwealth and the States, not to mention matters such as the absence of a Bill of Rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole concept of federalism is a wonderful way of building a nation out of disparate parts. My longstanding belief-shared by most observers of contemporary federal scenes around the world; not just of the Australian scene-is that it is a somewhat less than admirable and wholly wonderful way of actually carrying out the work of contemporary complex nations. It is a matter of paying attention not to the original glory of the foundations but to the need to constantly renovate the superstructure and to make it relevant to contemporary circumstances.

In that respect I draw attention to the efforts of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to regenerate a debate on the whole question of the contemporary application and operation of federalism, his attempt to get a dialogue going in something of the nature of a consensus about how we might move forward not only to make more workable the practical arrangements that are necessary in the Federal system but also ultimately to change some of the rules themselves. I simply express the hope that if a consensus should be reached as a result of this type of process, as in the past it has been reached, at least on a temporary basis in relation to other changes, that consensus for change will survive the process of carrying through to referendum.

One of the ironic and unhappy features of Australian constitutional referenda is just how many of them over the decades have been supported by one party or the other when it has been in government but, faced by the temptations of opposition and the temptation to score political points at the time that the referendum has gone to the judgment of the people, have resulted in some U-turn by the party in question. I will not recite now some of the more inglorious examples of that, but they have been many. Some of them my Party has shared, and more recently the honour of such can be described as largely being carried by the conservatives. It is most unfortunate that the way in which commitments to things such as extensions to terms of parliament and a number of other matters of that kind have not been able to command bipartisan support all the way to the line. I simply hope that that process will change in the future. With those few remarks I believe that it is time that we at last now adjourn.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.21 p.m.
